First Citizen:
Before we proceed any further, hear[SEQ_SPLITTER] me speak.

All:
Speak, speak.

First Citizen:
You[SEQ_SPLITTER] are all resolved rather to die than to famish?

A[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll:
Resolved. resolved.

First Citizen:
First, you[SEQ_SPLITTER] know Caius Marcius is chief enemy to the people.
[SEQ_SPLITTER]
All:
We know't, we know't.

First Citizen:
Let us[SEQ_SPLITTER] kill him, and we'll have corn at our own price.
I[SEQ_SPLITTER]s't a verdict?

All:
No more talking on't; let it [SEQ_SPLITTER]be done: away, away!

Second Citizen:
One word, go[SEQ_SPLITTER]od citizens.

First Citizen:
We are accounted poor[SEQ_SPLITTER] citizens, the patricians good.
What authority sur[SEQ_SPLITTER]feits on would relieve us: if they
would yield us [SEQ_SPLITTER]but the superfluity, while it were
wholesome, we m[SEQ_SPLITTER]ight guess they relieved us humanely;
but they thi[SEQ_SPLITTER]nk we are too dear: the leanness that
afflicts us,[SEQ_SPLITTER] the object of our misery, is as an
inventory to p[SEQ_SPLITTER]articularise their abundance; our
sufferance is a [SEQ_SPLITTER]gain to them Let us revenge this with
our pikes, e[SEQ_SPLITTER]re we become rakes: for the gods know I
speak this[SEQ_SPLITTER] in hunger for bread, not in thirst for revenge.

[SEQ_SPLITTER]Second Citizen:
Would you proceed especially again[SEQ_SPLITTER]st Caius Marcius?

All:
Against him first: he's a [SEQ_SPLITTER]very dog to the commonalty.

Second Citizen:
Consi[SEQ_SPLITTER]der you what services he has done for his country?[SEQ_SPLITTER]

First Citizen:
Very well; and could be content t[SEQ_SPLITTER]o give him good
report fort, but that he pays hims[SEQ_SPLITTER]elf with being proud.

Second Citizen:
Nay, but sp[SEQ_SPLITTER]eak not maliciously.

First Citizen:
I say unto yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]u, what he hath done famously, he did

content to [SEQ_SPLITTER]say it was for his country he did it to
please his[SEQ_SPLITTER] mother and to be partly proud; which he
is, even [SEQ_SPLITTER]till the altitude of his virtue.

Second Citizen:
[SEQ_SPLITTER]What he cannot help in his nature, you account a
v[SEQ_SPLITTER]ice in him. You must in no way say he is covetous.[SEQ_SPLITTER]

First Citizen:
If I must not, I need not be barr[SEQ_SPLITTER]en of accusations;

What shouts are these? The o[SEQ_SPLITTER]ther side o' the city
is risen: why stay we pratin[SEQ_SPLITTER]g here? to the Capitol!

All:

First C[SEQ_SPLITTER]itizen:
Soft! who comes here?

Second Citizen:
Wor[SEQ_SPLITTER]thy Menenius Agrippa; one that hath always loved
t[SEQ_SPLITTER]he people.

First Citizen:

MENENIUS:
What work'[SEQ_SPLITTER]s, my countrymen, in hand? where go you
With bats [SEQ_SPLITTER]and clubs? The matter? speak, I pray you.

First C[SEQ_SPLITTER]itizen:
Our business is not unknown to the senate;[SEQ_SPLITTER] they have
had inkling this fortnight what we inte[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd to do,

We cannot, si[SEQ_SPLITTER]r, we are undone already.

MENENIUS:
I tell you, f[SEQ_SPLITTER]riends, most charitable care
Have the patricians o[SEQ_SPLITTER]f you. For your wants,
Your suffering in this dear[SEQ_SPLITTER]th, you may as well
Strike at the heaven with your[SEQ_SPLITTER] staves as lift them
Against the Roman state, whos[SEQ_SPLITTER]e course will on
The way it takes, cracking ten th[SEQ_SPLITTER]ousand curbs
Of more strong link asunder than can [SEQ_SPLITTER]ever
Appear in your impediment. For the dearth,
Th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e gods, not the patricians, make it, and
Your knee[SEQ_SPLITTER]s to them, not arms, must help. Alack,
You are tra[SEQ_SPLITTER]nsported by calamity
Thither where more attends yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]u, and you slander
The helms o' the state, who car[SEQ_SPLITTER]e for you like fathers,
When you curse them as ene[SEQ_SPLITTER]mies.

First Citizen:

crammed with grain; make edi[SEQ_SPLITTER]cts for usury, to

there's all the love they bear us.

MENENIUS:
Either you must
Confess yourselves wond[SEQ_SPLITTER]rous malicious,
Or be accused of folly. I shall te[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll you
A pretty tale: it may be you have heard it;[SEQ_SPLITTER]
But, since it serves my purpose, I will venture
T[SEQ_SPLITTER]o stale 't a little more.

First Citizen:

fob off[SEQ_SPLITTER] our disgrace with a tale: but, an 't please

MENENIUS:
There was a time when all the [SEQ_SPLITTER]body's members
Rebell'd against the belly, thus ac[SEQ_SPLITTER]cused it:
That only like a gulf it did remain
I' t[SEQ_SPLITTER]he midst o' the body, idle and unactive,
Still cup[SEQ_SPLITTER]boarding the viand, never bearing
Like labour with[SEQ_SPLITTER] the rest, where the other instruments
Did see and[SEQ_SPLITTER] hear, devise, instruct, walk, feel,
And, mutually[SEQ_SPLITTER] participate, did minister
Unto the appetite and a[SEQ_SPLITTER]ffection common
Of the whole body. The belly answe[SEQ_SPLITTER]r'd--

First Citizen:
Well, sir, what answer made [SEQ_SPLITTER]the belly?

MENENIUS:
Sir, I shall tell you. With [SEQ_SPLITTER]a kind of smile,
Which ne'er came from the lungs, [SEQ_SPLITTER]but even thus--
For, look you, I may make the bell[SEQ_SPLITTER]y smile
As well as speak--it tauntingly replied
To[SEQ_SPLITTER] the discontented members, the mutinous parts
That[SEQ_SPLITTER] envied his receipt; even so most fitly
As you mal[SEQ_SPLITTER]ign our senators for that
They are not such as you[SEQ_SPLITTER].

First Citizen:

The k[SEQ_SPLITTER]ingly-crowned head, the vigilant eye,

'Fore me, this fellow speaks! [SEQ_SPLITTER]What then? what then?

Your most grave bel[SEQ_SPLITTER]ly was deliberate,

'True is it, my incorporate friend[SEQ_SPLITTER]s,' quoth he,

Which you do live upon; and fit it is,
Beca[SEQ_SPLITTER]use I am the store-house and the shop

Even to the court, the h[SEQ_SPLITTER]eart, to the seat o' the brain;

But it proc[SEQ_SPLITTER]eeds or comes from them to you

I the great toe! wh[SEQ_SPLITTER]y the great toe?

Thou rascal, that ar[SEQ_SPLITTER]t worst in blood to run,
Lead'st first to win some[SEQ_SPLITTER] vantage.

Rome and her rats are at the point of battle[SEQ_SPLITTER];

Hail, noble Marcius[SEQ_SPLITTER]!

MARCIUS:

That, rubbing the poor itch of your o[SEQ_SPLITTER]pinion,

First Citizen:
We [SEQ_SPLITTER]have ever your good word.

MARCIUS:
He that will g[SEQ_SPLITTER]ive good words to thee will flatter
Beneath abhorr[SEQ_SPLITTER]ing. What would you have, you curs,
That like nor [SEQ_SPLITTER]peace nor war? the one affrights you,
The other ma[SEQ_SPLITTER]kes you proud. He that trusts to you,
Where he sho[SEQ_SPLITTER]uld find you lions, finds you hares;
Where foxes, [SEQ_SPLITTER]geese: you are no surer, no,
Than is the coal of f[SEQ_SPLITTER]ire upon the ice,
Or hailstone in the sun. Your vi[SEQ_SPLITTER]rtue is
To make him worthy whose offence subdues h[SEQ_SPLITTER]im
And curse that justice did it.
Who deserves gre[SEQ_SPLITTER]atness
Deserves your hate; and your affections are[SEQ_SPLITTER]
A sick man's appetite, who desires most that
Whic[SEQ_SPLITTER]h would increase his evil. He that depends
Upon yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]ur favours swims with fins of lead
And hews down o[SEQ_SPLITTER]aks with rushes. Hang ye! Trust Ye?
With every min[SEQ_SPLITTER]ute you do change a mind,
And call him noble that [SEQ_SPLITTER]was now your hate,
Him vile that was your garland.[SEQ_SPLITTER] What's the matter,
That in these several places o[SEQ_SPLITTER]f the city
You cry against the noble senate, who,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Under the gods, keep you in awe, which else
Would [SEQ_SPLITTER]feed on one another? What's their seeking?

MENENI[SEQ_SPLITTER]US:
For corn at their own rates; whereof, they say[SEQ_SPLITTER],
The city is well stored.

MARCIUS:

They'll sit by the fire, and presume to kno[SEQ_SPLITTER]w

and gi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ve out

They are dissolved: hang 'em!
They said they [SEQ_SPLITTER]were an-hungry; sigh'd forth proverbs,
That hunger[SEQ_SPLITTER] broke stone walls, that dogs must eat,
That meat [SEQ_SPLITTER]was made for mouths, that the gods sent not

To break th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e heart of generosity,
And make bold power look pa[SEQ_SPLITTER]le--they threw their caps
As they would hang them [SEQ_SPLITTER]on the horns o' the moon,

Too proud to[SEQ_SPLITTER] be so valiant.

Tickled [SEQ_SPLITTER]with good success, disdains the shadow

[SEQ_SPLITTER]That they of Rome are entered in our counsels

'They have press'd a powe[SEQ_SPLITTER]r, but it is not known

The people mutinous; and it is[SEQ_SPLITTER] rumour'd,

Who i[SEQ_SPLITTER]s of Rome worse hated than of you,

Whither 'tis bent: most likely 'tis f[SEQ_SPLITTER]or you:

First Senator:
Our army'[SEQ_SPLITTER]s in the field
We never yet made doubt but Rome wa[SEQ_SPLITTER]s ready

VOLUMNI[SEQ_SPLITTER]A:
I pray you, daughter, sing; or express yourself[SEQ_SPLITTER] in a
more comfortable sort: if my son were my hus[SEQ_SPLITTER]band, I
should freelier rejoice in that absence wh[SEQ_SPLITTER]erein he
won honour than in the embracements of hi[SEQ_SPLITTER]s bed where
he would show most love. When yet he w[SEQ_SPLITTER]as but
tender-bodied and the only son of my womb, [SEQ_SPLITTER]when
youth with comeliness plucked all gaze his wa[SEQ_SPLITTER]y, when
for a day of kings' entreaties a mother sh[SEQ_SPLITTER]ould not
sell him an hour from her beholding, I, c[SEQ_SPLITTER]onsidering
how honour would become such a person. [SEQ_SPLITTER]that it was
no better than picture-like to hang by[SEQ_SPLITTER] the wall, if
renown made it not stir, was pleased[SEQ_SPLITTER] to let him seek
danger where he was like to find [SEQ_SPLITTER]fame. To a cruel
war I sent him; from whence he re[SEQ_SPLITTER]turned, his brows
bound with oak. I tell thee, dau[SEQ_SPLITTER]ghter, I sprang not
more in joy at first hearing h[SEQ_SPLITTER]e was a man-child
than now in first seeing he had [SEQ_SPLITTER]proved himself a
man.

VIRGILIA:
But had he died i[SEQ_SPLITTER]n the business, madam; how then?

VOLUMNIA:
Then h[SEQ_SPLITTER]is good report should have been my son; I
therein [SEQ_SPLITTER]would have found issue. Hear me profess
sincerely:[SEQ_SPLITTER] had I a dozen sons, each in my love
alike and non[SEQ_SPLITTER]e less dear than thine and my good
Marcius, I had [SEQ_SPLITTER]rather had eleven die nobly for their
country than[SEQ_SPLITTER] one voluptuously surfeit out of action.

Gentlewo[SEQ_SPLITTER]man:
Madam, the Lady Valeria is come to visit you.[SEQ_SPLITTER]

VIRGILIA:
Beseech you, give me leave to retire m[SEQ_SPLITTER]yself.

VOLUMNIA:
Indeed, you shall not.
Methinks [SEQ_SPLITTER]I hear hither your husband's drum,
See him pluck A[SEQ_SPLITTER]ufidius down by the hair,
As children from a bear,[SEQ_SPLITTER] the Volsces shunning him:
Methinks I see him stam[SEQ_SPLITTER]p thus, and call thus:
'Come on, you cowards! you [SEQ_SPLITTER]were got in fear,
Though you were born in Rome:' h[SEQ_SPLITTER]is bloody brow
With his mail'd hand then wiping, f[SEQ_SPLITTER]orth he goes,
Like to a harvest-man that's task'd [SEQ_SPLITTER]to mow
Or all or lose his hire.

VIRGILIA:
His blo[SEQ_SPLITTER]ody brow! O Jupiter, no blood!

VOLUMNIA:
Away, yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]u fool! it more becomes a man
Than gilt his trophy[SEQ_SPLITTER]: the breasts of Hecuba,
When she did suckle Hecto[SEQ_SPLITTER]r, look'd not lovelier
Than Hector's forehead when[SEQ_SPLITTER] it spit forth blood
At Grecian sword, contemning.[SEQ_SPLITTER] Tell Valeria,
We are fit to bid her welcome.

He'll beat Aufidius 'head below his knee[SEQ_SPLITTER]

Not for the flier[SEQ_SPLITTER]s: mark me, and do the like.

[SEQ_SPLITTER]I' the field prove flatterers, let courts and citi[SEQ_SPLITTER]es be
Made all of false-faced soothing!
When steel[SEQ_SPLITTER] grows soft as the parasite's silk,
Let him be mad[SEQ_SPLITTER]e a coverture for the wars!
No more, I say! For th[SEQ_SPLITTER]at I have not wash'd
My nose that bled, or foil'd [SEQ_SPLITTER]some debile wretch.--
Which, without note, here's [SEQ_SPLITTER]many else have done,--
You shout me forth
In accla[SEQ_SPLITTER]mations hyperbolical;
As if I loved my little shou[SEQ_SPLITTER]ld be dieted
In praises sauced with lies.

More cruel to your good rep[SEQ_SPLITTER]ort than grateful

With all his trim belonging; and from t[SEQ_SPLITTER]his time,

To the fairness[SEQ_SPLITTER] of my power.

So, to our tent;
Where, e[SEQ_SPLITTER]re we do repose us, we will write
To Rome of our s[SEQ_SPLITTER]uccess. You, Titus Lartius,
Must to Corioli back: [SEQ_SPLITTER]send us to Rome
The best, with whom we may articul[SEQ_SPLITTER]ate,
For their own good and ours.

LARTIUS:
I shal[SEQ_SPLITTER]l, my lord.

CORIOLANUS:
The gods begin to mock me[SEQ_SPLITTER]. I, that now
Refused most princely gifts, am boun[SEQ_SPLITTER]d to beg
Of my lord general.

COMINIUS:
Take't; 't[SEQ_SPLITTER]is yours. What is't?

CORIOLANUS:
I sometime lay h[SEQ_SPLITTER]ere in Corioli
At a poor man's house; he used me k[SEQ_SPLITTER]indly:
He cried to me; I saw him prisoner;
But the[SEQ_SPLITTER]n Aufidius was within my view,
And wrath o'erwhelm[SEQ_SPLITTER]'d my pity: I request you
To give my poor host fre[SEQ_SPLITTER]edom.

COMINIUS:
O, well begg'd!
Were he the butch[SEQ_SPLITTER]er of my son, he should
Be free as is the wind. De[SEQ_SPLITTER]liver him, Titus.

LARTIUS:
Marcius, his name?

CO[SEQ_SPLITTER]RIOLANUS:
By Jupiter! forgot.
I am weary; yea, my [SEQ_SPLITTER]memory is tired.
Have we no wine here?

COMINIUS:
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Go we to our tent:
The blood upon your visage drie[SEQ_SPLITTER]s; 'tis time
It should be look'd to: come.

AUFIDI[SEQ_SPLITTER]US:
The town is ta'en!

First Soldier:
'Twill be d[SEQ_SPLITTER]eliver'd back on good condition.

AUFIDIUS:
Condit[SEQ_SPLITTER]ion!
I would I were a Roman; for I cannot,
Being a[SEQ_SPLITTER] Volsce, be that I am. Condition!
What good condit[SEQ_SPLITTER]ion can a treaty find
I' the part that is at mercy[SEQ_SPLITTER]? Five times, Marcius,
I have fought with thee: so[SEQ_SPLITTER] often hast thou beat me,
And wouldst do so, I thi[SEQ_SPLITTER]nk, should we encounter
As often as we eat. By the[SEQ_SPLITTER] elements,
If e'er again I meet him beard to beard[SEQ_SPLITTER],
He's mine, or I am his: mine emulation
Hath not [SEQ_SPLITTER]that honour in't it had; for where
I thought to cr[SEQ_SPLITTER]ush him in an equal force,
True sword to sword, I'[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll potch at him some way
Or wrath or craft may get[SEQ_SPLITTER] him.

First Soldier:
He's the devil.

AUFIDIUS:
B[SEQ_SPLITTER]older, though not so subtle. My valour's poison'd
[SEQ_SPLITTER]With only suffering stain by him; for him
Shall fl[SEQ_SPLITTER]y out of itself: nor sleep nor sanctuary,
Being na[SEQ_SPLITTER]ked, sick, nor fane nor Capitol,
The prayers of pr[SEQ_SPLITTER]iests nor times of sacrifice,
Embarquements all of[SEQ_SPLITTER] fury, shall lift up
Their rotten privilege and cu[SEQ_SPLITTER]stom 'gainst
My hate to Marcius: where I find him,[SEQ_SPLITTER] were it
At home, upon my brother's guard, even th[SEQ_SPLITTER]ere,
Against the hospitable canon, would I
Wash my[SEQ_SPLITTER] fierce hand in's heart. Go you to the city;
Learn[SEQ_SPLITTER] how 'tis held; and what they are that must
Be hos[SEQ_SPLITTER]tages for Rome.

First Soldier:
Will not you go?

[SEQ_SPLITTER]AUFIDIUS:
I am attended at the cypress grove: I pr[SEQ_SPLITTER]ay you--
'Tis south the city mills--bring me word [SEQ_SPLITTER]thither
How the world goes, that to the pace of it[SEQ_SPLITTER]
I may spur on my journey.

First Soldier:
I shall[SEQ_SPLITTER], sir.

MENENIUS:
The augurer tells me we shall ha[SEQ_SPLITTER]ve news to-night.

BRUTUS:

Wel[SEQ_SPLITTER]l, sir.

BRUTUS:[SEQ_SPLITTER]

BRUTUS:

BRUTUS:
All tongues speak of him, an[SEQ_SPLITTER]d the bleared sights
Are spectacled to see him: yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]ur prattling nurse
Into a rapture lets her baby cr[SEQ_SPLITTER]y

Are[SEQ_SPLITTER] smother'd up, leads fill'd, and ridges horsed
Wit[SEQ_SPLITTER]h variable complexions, all agreeing

Shall darken him for ever[SEQ_SPLITTER].

Messenger:
You are [SEQ_SPLITTER]sent for to the Capitol. 'Tis thought
That Marcius[SEQ_SPLITTER] shall be consul:
I have seen the dumb men throng [SEQ_SPLITTER]to see him and
The blind to bear him speak: matron[SEQ_SPLITTER]s flung gloves,
Ladies and maids their scarfs and [SEQ_SPLITTER]handkerchers,
Upon him as he pass'd: the nobles be[SEQ_SPLITTER]nded,
As to Jove's statue, and the commons made
A [SEQ_SPLITTER]shower and thunder with their caps and shouts:
I n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ever saw the like.

BRUTUS:

SICINIUS:

F[SEQ_SPLITTER]irst Officer:
Come, come, they are almost here. Ho[SEQ_SPLITTER]w many stand
for consulships?

Second Officer:
Thr[SEQ_SPLITTER]ee, they say: but 'tis thought of every one
Coriol[SEQ_SPLITTER]anus will carry it.

First Officer:
That's a brave[SEQ_SPLITTER] fellow; but he's vengeance proud, and
loves not t[SEQ_SPLITTER]he common people.

Second Officer:
Faith, there ha[SEQ_SPLITTER]d been many great men that have
flattered the peop[SEQ_SPLITTER]le, who ne'er loved them; and there
be many that t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hey have loved, they know not
wherefore: so that, [SEQ_SPLITTER]if they love they know not why,
they hate upon no [SEQ_SPLITTER]better a ground: therefore, for
Coriolanus neither[SEQ_SPLITTER] to care whether they love or hate
him manifests t[SEQ_SPLITTER]he true knowledge he has in their
disposition; and[SEQ_SPLITTER] out of his noble carelessness lets
them plainly s[SEQ_SPLITTER]ee't.

First Officer:
If he did not care whether h[SEQ_SPLITTER]e had their love or no,
he waved indifferently 'tw[SEQ_SPLITTER]ixt doing them neither
good nor harm: but he seeks[SEQ_SPLITTER] their hate with greater
devotion than can render [SEQ_SPLITTER]it him; and leaves
nothing undone that may fully d[SEQ_SPLITTER]iscover him their
opposite. Now, to seem to affect[SEQ_SPLITTER] the malice and
displeasure of the people is as ba[SEQ_SPLITTER]d as that which he
dislikes, to flatter them for t[SEQ_SPLITTER]heir love.

Second Officer:
He hath deserved worth[SEQ_SPLITTER]ily of his country: and his
ascent is not by such [SEQ_SPLITTER]easy degrees as those who,
having been supple and [SEQ_SPLITTER]courteous to the people,
bonneted, without any fur[SEQ_SPLITTER]ther deed to have them at
an into their estimation[SEQ_SPLITTER] and report: but he hath so
planted his honours in[SEQ_SPLITTER] their eyes, and his actions
in their hearts, that[SEQ_SPLITTER] for their tongues to be
silent, and not confess s[SEQ_SPLITTER]o much, were a kind of
ingrateful injury; to repor[SEQ_SPLITTER]t otherwise, were a
malice, that, giving itself th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e lie, would pluck
reproof and rebuke from every e[SEQ_SPLITTER]ar that heard it.

First Officer:
No more of him; [SEQ_SPLITTER]he is a worthy man: make way, they

ME[SEQ_SPLITTER]NENIUS:
Having determined of the Volsces and
To se[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd for Titus Lartius, it remains,
As the main poin[SEQ_SPLITTER]t of this our after-meeting,
To gratify his noble [SEQ_SPLITTER]service that
Hath thus stood for his country: ther[SEQ_SPLITTER]efore,
please you,
Most reverend and grave elders,[SEQ_SPLITTER] to desire
The present consul, and last general
In[SEQ_SPLITTER] our well-found successes, to report
A little of t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hat worthy work perform'd
By Caius Marcius Coriola[SEQ_SPLITTER]nus, whom
We met here both to thank and to remembe[SEQ_SPLITTER]r
With honours like himself.

First Senator:
Speak[SEQ_SPLITTER], good Cominius:
Leave nothing out for length, and[SEQ_SPLITTER] make us think
Rather our state's defective for re[SEQ_SPLITTER]quital
Than we to stretch it out.

We do request your kindest ears, and after,[SEQ_SPLITTER]

To yie[SEQ_SPLITTER]ld what passes here.

SICINIUS:
We are convented
U[SEQ_SPLITTER]pon a pleasing treaty, and have hearts
Inclinable [SEQ_SPLITTER]to honour and advance
The theme of our assembly.

Which the rather
We shall be blest to do, [SEQ_SPLITTER]if he remember

H[SEQ_SPLITTER]e hath hereto prized them at.

But tie him not to be their bedfellow.

Your horror's[SEQ_SPLITTER] pardon:
I had rather have my wounds to heal again[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Than hear say how I got them.

BRUTUS:
Sir, I hop[SEQ_SPLITTER]e
My words disbench'd you not.

When blows have made me stay, I fled f[SEQ_SPLITTER]rom words.
You soothed not, therefore hurt not: bu[SEQ_SPLITTER]t
your people,
I love them as they weigh.

MENENIU[SEQ_SPLITTER]S:
Pray now, sit down.

I had rather h[SEQ_SPLITTER]ave one scratch my head i' the sun
When the alarum[SEQ_SPLITTER] were struck than idly sit
To hear my nothings mon[SEQ_SPLITTER]ster'd.

MENENIUS:
Masters of the people,
Your mul[SEQ_SPLITTER]tiplying spawn how can he flatter--
That's thousan[SEQ_SPLITTER]d to one good one--when you now see
He had rather [SEQ_SPLITTER]venture all his limbs for honour
Than one on's ear[SEQ_SPLITTER]s to hear it? Proceed, Cominius.

COMINIUS:
I shal[SEQ_SPLITTER]l lack voice: the deeds of Coriolanus
Should not b[SEQ_SPLITTER]e utter'd feebly. It is held
That valour is the ch[SEQ_SPLITTER]iefest virtue, and
Most dignifies the haver: if it[SEQ_SPLITTER] be,
The man I speak of cannot in the world
Be sin[SEQ_SPLITTER]gly counterpoised. At sixteen years,
When Tarquin [SEQ_SPLITTER]made a head for Rome, he fought
Beyond the mark of[SEQ_SPLITTER] others: our then dictator,
Whom with all praise I[SEQ_SPLITTER] point at, saw him fight,
When with his Amazonian [SEQ_SPLITTER]chin he drove
The bristled lips before him: be bes[SEQ_SPLITTER]trid
An o'er-press'd Roman and i' the consul's vie[SEQ_SPLITTER]w
Slew three opposers: Tarquin's self he met,
And [SEQ_SPLITTER]struck him on his knee: in that day's feats,
When [SEQ_SPLITTER]he might act the woman in the scene,
He proved bes[SEQ_SPLITTER]t man i' the field, and for his meed
Was brow-boun[SEQ_SPLITTER]d with the oak. His pupil age
Man-enter'd thus, he[SEQ_SPLITTER] waxed like a sea,
And in the brunt of seventeen b[SEQ_SPLITTER]attles since
He lurch'd all swords of the garland.[SEQ_SPLITTER] For this last,
Before and in Corioli, let me say,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
I cannot speak him home: he stopp'd the fliers;
A[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd by his rare example made the coward
Turn terror[SEQ_SPLITTER] into sport: as weeds before
A vessel under sail, [SEQ_SPLITTER]so men obey'd
And fell below his stem: his sword, [SEQ_SPLITTER]death's stamp,
Where it did mark, it took; from fa[SEQ_SPLITTER]ce to foot
He was a thing of blood, whose every mo[SEQ_SPLITTER]tion
Was timed with dying cries: alone he enter'd
[SEQ_SPLITTER]The mortal gate of the city, which he painted
With[SEQ_SPLITTER] shunless destiny; aidless came off,
And with a su[SEQ_SPLITTER]dden reinforcement struck
Corioli like a planet: n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ow all's his:
When, by and by, the din of war gan [SEQ_SPLITTER]pierce
His ready sense; then straight his doubled [SEQ_SPLITTER]spirit
Re-quicken'd what in flesh was fatigate,
An[SEQ_SPLITTER]d to the battle came he; where he did
Run reeking [SEQ_SPLITTER]o'er the lives of men, as if
'Twere a perpetual sp[SEQ_SPLITTER]oil: and till we call'd
Both field and city ours, [SEQ_SPLITTER]he never stood
To ease his breast with panting.

M[SEQ_SPLITTER]ENENIUS:
Worthy man!

First Senator:
He cannot but[SEQ_SPLITTER] with measure fit the honours
Which we devise him.[SEQ_SPLITTER]

COMINIUS:
Our spoils he kick'd at,
And look'd up[SEQ_SPLITTER]on things precious as they were
The common muck of[SEQ_SPLITTER] the world: he covets less
Than misery itself woul[SEQ_SPLITTER]d give; rewards
His deeds with doing them, and is [SEQ_SPLITTER]content
To spend the time to end it.

MENENIUS:
He[SEQ_SPLITTER]'s right noble:
Let him be call'd for.

First Cit[SEQ_SPLITTER]izen:

Second Citizen:
We may, sir, if [SEQ_SPLITTER]we will.

Third Citizen:

were to make a monster[SEQ_SPLITTER] of the multitude: of the

monstrous members.

F[SEQ_SPLITTER]irst Citizen:
And to make us no better thought of,[SEQ_SPLITTER] a little help

himself stuck not to call us the [SEQ_SPLITTER]many-headed multitude.

Third Citizen:
We have bee[SEQ_SPLITTER]n called so of many; not that our heads

Second Citizen:
T[SEQ_SPLITTER]hink you so? Which way do you judge my wit would
f[SEQ_SPLITTER]ly?

Second Citizen:
You are never[SEQ_SPLITTER] without your tricks: you may, you may.

Most sweet voices!

What custom wills, in all things should we do[SEQ_SPLITTER]'t,
The dust on antique time would lie unswept,
An[SEQ_SPLITTER]d mountainous error be too highly heapt
For truth [SEQ_SPLITTER]to o'er-peer. Rather than fool it so,

Watch'd for your [SEQ_SPLITTER]voices; for Your voices bear

As you [SEQ_SPLITTER]were lesson'd, when he had no power,
But was a pet[SEQ_SPLITTER]ty servant to the state,
He was your enemy, ever s[SEQ_SPLITTER]pake against

That as his worthy deeds did [SEQ_SPLITTER]claim no less

Translate his malice towards you into love,
Stan[SEQ_SPLITTER]ding your friendly lord.

SICINIUS:

As you were fore-advised, had touch'd his spi[SEQ_SPLITTER]rit

As cau[SEQ_SPLITTER]se had call'd you up, have held him to
Or else it [SEQ_SPLITTER]would have gall'd his surly nature,
Which easily e[SEQ_SPLITTER]ndures not article

And pass'd him unelected.

Cast your election on him.

SICINIUS:
Say, you[SEQ_SPLITTER] chose him
More after our commandment than as guid[SEQ_SPLITTER]ed
By your own true affections, and that your mind[SEQ_SPLITTER]s,
Preoccupied with what you rather must do
Than w[SEQ_SPLITTER]hat you should, made you against the grain
To voic[SEQ_SPLITTER]e him consul: lay the fault on us.

BRUTUS:
Ay, sp[SEQ_SPLITTER]are us not. Say we read lectures to you.
How young[SEQ_SPLITTER]ly he began to serve his country,
How long continu[SEQ_SPLITTER]ed, and what stock he springs of,
The noble house [SEQ_SPLITTER]o' the Marcians, from whence came
That Ancus Marci[SEQ_SPLITTER]us, Numa's daughter's son,
Who, after great Hostil[SEQ_SPLITTER]ius, here was king;
Of the same house Publius and [SEQ_SPLITTER]Quintus were,
That our beat water brought by condu[SEQ_SPLITTER]its hither;
And  
Twice being  
Was his great ance[SEQ_SPLITTER]stor.

SICINIUS:
One thus descended,
That hath bes[SEQ_SPLITTER]ide well in his person wrought
To be set high in p[SEQ_SPLITTER]lace, we did commend
To your remembrances: but you[SEQ_SPLITTER] have found,
Scaling his present bearing with his [SEQ_SPLITTER]past,
That he's your fixed enemy, and revoke
Your [SEQ_SPLITTER]sudden approbation.

BRUTUS:
Say, you ne'er had do[SEQ_SPLITTER]ne't--
Harp on that still--but by our putting on;
[SEQ_SPLITTER]And presently, when you have drawn your number,
Re[SEQ_SPLITTER]pair to the Capitol.

All:
We will so: almost all
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Repent in their election.

BRUTUS:
Let them go on;[SEQ_SPLITTER]
This mutiny were better put in hazard,
Than stay,[SEQ_SPLITTER] past doubt, for greater:
If, as his nature is, he[SEQ_SPLITTER] fall in rage
With their refusal, both observe and[SEQ_SPLITTER] answer
The vantage of his anger.

SICINIUS:
To th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e Capitol, come:
We will be there before the strea[SEQ_SPLITTER]m o' the people;
And this shall seem, as partly 't[SEQ_SPLITTER]is, their own,
Which we have goaded onward.

CORIO[SEQ_SPLITTER]LANUS:
Tullus Aufidius then had made new head?

LA[SEQ_SPLITTER]RTIUS:
He had, my lord; and that it was which caus[SEQ_SPLITTER]ed
Our swifter composition.

So then t[SEQ_SPLITTER]he Volsces stand but as at first,
Ready, when time[SEQ_SPLITTER] shall prompt them, to make road.
Upon's again.

That we s[SEQ_SPLITTER]hall hardly in our ages see
Their banners wave aga[SEQ_SPLITTER]in.

Yielded the town: [SEQ_SPLITTER]he is retired to Antium.

LARTIUS:
He did, my lord.

That of all things upon the earth he hated
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Your person most, that he would pawn his fortunes
[SEQ_SPLITTER]To hopeless restitution, so he might
Be call'd you[SEQ_SPLITTER]r vanquisher.

LA[SEQ_SPLITTER]RTIUS:
At Antium.

The tongues o' the common mouth: I do des[SEQ_SPLITTER]pise them;
For they do prank them in authority,
Ag[SEQ_SPLITTER]ainst all noble sufferance.

your offices?

Have you not set them on?

This was my speech[SEQ_SPLITTER], and I will speak't again--

For the mutable, ra[SEQ_SPLITTER]nk-scented many, let them
Regard me as I do not fl[SEQ_SPLITTER]atter, and
Therein behold themselves: I say again,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
In soothing them, we nourish 'gainst our senate
T[SEQ_SPLITTER]he cockle of rebellion, insolence, sedition,
Which[SEQ_SPLITTER] we ourselves have plough'd for, sow'd,
and scatte[SEQ_SPLITTER]r'd,

Whi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ch they have given to beggars.

Coin words till their decay agains[SEQ_SPLITTER]t those measles,
Which we disdain should tatter us[SEQ_SPLITTER], yet sought
The very way to catch them.

[SEQ_SPLITTER]

Hear you this Triton of[SEQ_SPLITTER] the minnows? mark you

'Twas from the canon.

CORIOLANUS:
'Shall'!
[SEQ_SPLITTER]O good but most unwise patricians! why,
You grave [SEQ_SPLITTER]but reckless senators, have you thus
Given Hydra h[SEQ_SPLITTER]ere to choose an officer,
That with his peremptory[SEQ_SPLITTER] 'shall,' being but
The horn and noise o' the mons[SEQ_SPLITTER]ter's, wants not spirit
To say he'll turn your cur[SEQ_SPLITTER]rent in a ditch,
And make your channel his? If he [SEQ_SPLITTER]have power
Then vail your ignorance; if none, awak[SEQ_SPLITTER]e
Your dangerous lenity. If you are learn'd,
Be no[SEQ_SPLITTER]t as common fools; if you are not,
Let them have c[SEQ_SPLITTER]ushions by you. You are plebeians,
If they be sena[SEQ_SPLITTER]tors: and they are no less,
When, both your voices[SEQ_SPLITTER] blended, the great'st taste
Most palates theirs. [SEQ_SPLITTER]They choose their magistrate,
And such a one as he[SEQ_SPLITTER], who puts his 'shall,'
His popular 'shall' agains[SEQ_SPLITTER]t a graver bench
Than ever frown in Greece. By Jov[SEQ_SPLITTER]e himself!
It makes the consuls base: and my soul [SEQ_SPLITTER]aches
To know, when two authorities are up,
Neithe[SEQ_SPLITTER]r supreme, how soon confusion
May enter 'twixt the[SEQ_SPLITTER] gap of both and take
The one by the other.

COMIN[SEQ_SPLITTER]IUS:
Well, on to the market-place.

More worthier than t[SEQ_SPLITTER]heir voices. They know the corn
Was not our recomp[SEQ_SPLITTER]ense, resting well assured
That ne'er did service [SEQ_SPLITTER]for't: being press'd to the war,
Even when the nav[SEQ_SPLITTER]el of the state was touch'd,
They would not thread[SEQ_SPLITTER] the gates. This kind of service
Did not deserve c[SEQ_SPLITTER]orn gratis. Being i' the war
Their mutinies and re[SEQ_SPLITTER]volts, wherein they show'd
Most valour, spoke not [SEQ_SPLITTER]for them: the accusation
Which they have often mad[SEQ_SPLITTER]e against the senate,
All cause unborn, could neve[SEQ_SPLITTER]r be the motive
Of our so frank donation. Well, wh[SEQ_SPLITTER]at then?
How shall this bisson multitude digest
Th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e senate's courtesy? Let deeds express
What's like[SEQ_SPLITTER] to be their words: 'we did request it;
We are the[SEQ_SPLITTER] greater poll, and in true fear
They gave us our d[SEQ_SPLITTER]emands.' Thus we debase
The nature of our seats an[SEQ_SPLITTER]d make the rabble
Call our cares fears; which will[SEQ_SPLITTER] in time
Break ope the locks o' the senate and bri[SEQ_SPLITTER]ng in
The crows to peck the eagles.

Com[SEQ_SPLITTER]e, enough.

What may be sworn by, bot[SEQ_SPLITTER]h divine and human,

Cannot conclude but by the ye[SEQ_SPLITTER]a and no
Of general ignorance,--it must omit
Real [SEQ_SPLITTER]necessities, and give way the while
To unstable sl[SEQ_SPLITTER]ightness: purpose so barr'd,
it follows,
Nothing i[SEQ_SPLITTER]s done to purpose. Therefore, beseech you,--
You t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hat will be less fearful than discreet,
That love [SEQ_SPLITTER]the fundamental part of state
More than you doubt [SEQ_SPLITTER]the change on't, that prefer
A noble life before a[SEQ_SPLITTER] long, and wish
To jump a body with a dangerous ph[SEQ_SPLITTER]ysic
That's sure of death without it, at once pluc[SEQ_SPLITTER]k out

Ma[SEQ_SPLITTER]ngles true judgment and bereaves the state

For the in which dot[SEQ_SPLITTER]h control't.

MENENIUS:
O, he's a limb that has but a di[SEQ_SPLITTER]sease;
Mortal, to cut it off; to cure it, easy.
Wh[SEQ_SPLITTER]at has he done to Rome that's worthy death?
Killin[SEQ_SPLITTER]g our enemies, the blood he hath lost--
Which, I d[SEQ_SPLITTER]are vouch, is more than that he hath,
By many an o[SEQ_SPLITTER]unce--he dropp'd it for his country;
And what is l[SEQ_SPLITTER]eft, to lose it by his country,
Were to us all, th[SEQ_SPLITTER]at do't and suffer it,
A brand to the end o' the w[SEQ_SPLITTER]orld.

Now the red pestilence strike[SEQ_SPLITTER] all trades in Rome,
And occupations perish!

CORI[SEQ_SPLITTER]OLANUS:
What, what, what!
I shall be loved when I [SEQ_SPLITTER]am lack'd. Nay, mother.
Resume that spirit, when y[SEQ_SPLITTER]ou were wont to say,
If you had been the wife of H[SEQ_SPLITTER]ercules,
Six of his labours you'ld have done, and [SEQ_SPLITTER]saved
Your husband so much sweat. Cominius,
Droop [SEQ_SPLITTER]not; adieu. Farewell, my wife, my mother:
I'll do [SEQ_SPLITTER]well yet. Thou old and true Menenius,
Thy tears ar[SEQ_SPLITTER]e salter than a younger man's,
And venomous to thi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ne eyes. My sometime general,
I have seen thee ste[SEQ_SPLITTER]m, and thou hast oft beheld
Heart-hardening specta[SEQ_SPLITTER]cles; tell these sad women
'Tis fond to wail inevi[SEQ_SPLITTER]table strokes,
As 'tis to laugh at 'em. My mother,[SEQ_SPLITTER] you wot well
My hazards still have been your sola[SEQ_SPLITTER]ce: and
Believe't not lightly--though I go alone,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Like to a lonely dragon, that his fen
Makes fear'd[SEQ_SPLITTER] and talk'd of more than seen--your son
Will or ex[SEQ_SPLITTER]ceed the common or be caught
With cautelous baits [SEQ_SPLITTER]and practise.

VOLUMNIA:
My first son.
Whither wil[SEQ_SPLITTER]t thou go? Take good Cominius
With thee awhile: de[SEQ_SPLITTER]termine on some course,
More than a wild exposture[SEQ_SPLITTER] to each chance
That starts i' the way before thee[SEQ_SPLITTER].

O the gods!

And we of thee: so [SEQ_SPLITTER]if the time thrust forth
A cause for thy repeal, w[SEQ_SPLITTER]e shall not send

And lose advantage, which doth ever cool
[SEQ_SPLITTER]I' the absence of the needer.

Thou hast years upon thee; and thou art too[SEQ_SPLITTER] full
Of the wars' surfeits, to go rove with one
T[SEQ_SPLITTER]hat's yet unbruised: bring me but out at gate.
Com[SEQ_SPLITTER]e, my sweet wife, my dearest mother, and
My friend[SEQ_SPLITTER]s of noble touch, when I am forth,
Bid me farewell[SEQ_SPLITTER], and smile. I pray you, come.
While I remain abov[SEQ_SPLITTER]e the ground, you shall
Hear from me still, and ne[SEQ_SPLITTER]ver of me aught
But what is like me formerly.

As any ear can hear. Come, [SEQ_SPLITTER]let's not weep.
If I could shake off but one seven[SEQ_SPLITTER] years
From these old arms and legs, by the good g[SEQ_SPLITTER]ods,
I'ld with thee every foot.

O world, thy slippery turns! F[SEQ_SPLITTER]riends now fast sworn,
Whose double bosoms seem to[SEQ_SPLITTER] wear one heart,
Whose house, whose bed, whose mea[SEQ_SPLITTER]l, and exercise,

Whose passions and wh[SEQ_SPLITTER]ose plots have broke their sleep,
To take the one [SEQ_SPLITTER]the other, by some chance,

And interjoin their [SEQ_SPLITTER]issues. So with me:
My birth-place hate I, and my [SEQ_SPLITTER]love's upon
This enemy town. I'll enter: if he sla[SEQ_SPLITTER]y me,
He does fair justice; if he give me way,
I'l[SEQ_SPLITTER]l do his country service.

The cruelty and envy of the people,
Perm[SEQ_SPLITTER]itted by our dastard nobles, who
Have all forsook [SEQ_SPLITTER]me, hath devour'd the rest;
And suffer'd me by the[SEQ_SPLITTER] voice of slaves to be

Hath brought me to thy hearth; not ou[SEQ_SPLITTER]t of hope--
Mistake me not--to save my life, for i[SEQ_SPLITTER]f
I had fear'd death, of all the men i' the world
[SEQ_SPLITTER]I would have 'voided thee, but in mere spite,

Of shame seen through thy co[SEQ_SPLITTER]untry, speed
thee straight,

That my revengeful services[SEQ_SPLITTER] may prove
As benefits to thee, for I will fight
A[SEQ_SPLITTER]gainst my canker'd country with the spleen
Of all [SEQ_SPLITTER]the under fiends. But if so be

Dr[SEQ_SPLITTER]awn tuns of blood out of thy country's breast,
And[SEQ_SPLITTER] cannot live but to thy shame, unless
It be to do [SEQ_SPLITTER]thee service.

AUFIDIUS:

Each [SEQ_SPLITTER]word thou hast spoke hath weeded from my heart

[SEQ_SPLITTER]And scarr'd the moon with splinters: here I clip
T[SEQ_SPLITTER]he anvil of my sword, and do contest

I loved the maid I married; never man

We have a power on foot;[SEQ_SPLITTER] and I had purpose
Once more to hew thy target fro[SEQ_SPLITTER]m thy brawn,
Or lose mine arm fort: thou hast beat[SEQ_SPLITTER] me out
Twelve several times, and I have nightly s[SEQ_SPLITTER]ince
Dreamt of encounters 'twixt thyself and me;
W[SEQ_SPLITTER]e have been down together in my sleep,

L[SEQ_SPLITTER]ike a bold flood o'er-bear. O, come, go in,

Who now are[SEQ_SPLITTER] here, taking their leaves of me,
Who am prepared [SEQ_SPLITTER]against your territories,
Though not for Rome itse[SEQ_SPLITTER]lf.

Wherefore? wherefore?

Third Servingman:
Why, her[SEQ_SPLITTER]e's he that was wont to thwack our general,
Caius [SEQ_SPLITTER]Marcius.

First Servingman:
Why do you say 'thwack[SEQ_SPLITTER] our general '?

Third Servingman:
I do not say 't[SEQ_SPLITTER]hwack our general;' but he was always
good enough [SEQ_SPLITTER]for him.

Second Servingman:
Come, we are fellows [SEQ_SPLITTER]and friends: he was ever too
hard for him; I have [SEQ_SPLITTER]heard him say so himself.

First Servingman:
He wa[SEQ_SPLITTER]s too hard for him directly, to say the troth
on't[SEQ_SPLITTER]: before Corioli he scotched him and notched
him l[SEQ_SPLITTER]ike a carbon ado.

Second Servingman:
An he had be[SEQ_SPLITTER]en cannibally given, he might have
broiled and eat[SEQ_SPLITTER]en him too.

First Servingman:
But, more of thy ne[SEQ_SPLITTER]ws?

Third Servingman:
Why, he is so made on here [SEQ_SPLITTER]within, as if he were son
and heir to Mars; set at[SEQ_SPLITTER] upper end o' the table; no
question asked him by [SEQ_SPLITTER]any of the senators, but they
stand bald before hi[SEQ_SPLITTER]m: our general himself makes a
mistress of him: sa[SEQ_SPLITTER]nctifies himself with's hand and
turns up the whit[SEQ_SPLITTER]e o' the eye to his discourse. But
the bottom of t[SEQ_SPLITTER]he news is that our general is cut i'
the middle a[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd but one half of what he was
yesterday; for the [SEQ_SPLITTER]other has half, by the entreaty
and grant of the w[SEQ_SPLITTER]hole table. He'll go, he says,
and sowl the porter[SEQ_SPLITTER] of Rome gates by the ears: he
will mow all down b[SEQ_SPLITTER]efore him, and leave his passage polled.

Second S[SEQ_SPLITTER]ervingman:
And he's as like to do't as any man I c[SEQ_SPLITTER]an imagine.

Third Servingman:
Do't! he will do't;[SEQ_SPLITTER] for, look you, sir, he has as
many friends as ene[SEQ_SPLITTER]mies; which friends, sir, as it
were, durst not, l[SEQ_SPLITTER]ook you, sir, show themselves, as
we term it, his [SEQ_SPLITTER]friends whilst he's in directitude.

First Serving[SEQ_SPLITTER]man:
Directitude! what's that?

Third Servingman:
[SEQ_SPLITTER]But when they shall see, sir, his crest up again,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]and the man in blood, they will out of their
burro[SEQ_SPLITTER]ws, like conies after rain, and revel all with
him[SEQ_SPLITTER].

First Servingman:
But when goes this forward?

[SEQ_SPLITTER]Third Servingman:
To-morrow; to-day; presently; yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]u shall have the
drum struck up this afternoon: 't[SEQ_SPLITTER]is, as it were, a
parcel of their feast, and to be[SEQ_SPLITTER] executed ere they
wipe their lips.

Second Servin[SEQ_SPLITTER]gman:
Why, then we shall have a stirring world aga[SEQ_SPLITTER]in.
This peace is nothing, but to rust iron, incre[SEQ_SPLITTER]ase
tailors, and breed ballad-makers.

First Servi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ngman:
Let me have war, say I; it exceeds peace as[SEQ_SPLITTER] far as
day does night; it's spritely, waking, aud[SEQ_SPLITTER]ible, and
full of vent. Peace is a very apoplexy, [SEQ_SPLITTER]lethargy;
mulled, deaf, sleepy, insensible; a gett[SEQ_SPLITTER]er of more
bastard children than war's a destroyer[SEQ_SPLITTER] of men.

Second Servingman:
'Tis so: and as war, [SEQ_SPLITTER]in some sort, may be said to
be a ravisher, so it [SEQ_SPLITTER]cannot be denied but peace is a
great maker of cuc[SEQ_SPLITTER]kolds.

First Servingman:
Ay, and it makes men hat[SEQ_SPLITTER]e one another.

Third Servingman:
Reason; because [SEQ_SPLITTER]they then less need one another.
The wars for my m[SEQ_SPLITTER]oney. I hope to see Romans as cheap
as Volscians. [SEQ_SPLITTER]They are rising, they are rising.

All:
In, in, in[SEQ_SPLITTER], in!

SICINIUS:
We hear not of him, neither need [SEQ_SPLITTER]we fear him;
His remedies are tame i' the present [SEQ_SPLITTER]peace
And quietness of the people, which before
We[SEQ_SPLITTER]re in wild hurry. Here do we make his friends
Blus[SEQ_SPLITTER]h that the world goes well, who rather had,
Though[SEQ_SPLITTER] they themselves did suffer by't, behold
Dissentio[SEQ_SPLITTER]us numbers pestering streets than see
Our tradesme[SEQ_SPLITTER]n with in their shops and going
About their functi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ons friendly.

BRUTUS:
We stood to't in good time.[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Is this Menenius?

SICINIUS:
'Tis he,'tis he: O, [SEQ_SPLITTER]he is grown most kind of late.

Hai[SEQ_SPLITTER]l sir!

The commonwealth doth stand, and so would do,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Were he more angry at it.

MENENIUS:

This is a h[SEQ_SPLITTER]appier and more comely time
Than when these fellow[SEQ_SPLITTER]s ran about the streets,

BRUTUS[SEQ_SPLITTER]:
Caius Marcius was

O'ercome with pride, ambitious past a[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll thinking,
Self-loving,--

Without assistance.

MENENIUS:[SEQ_SPLITTER]

If he had gone forth consul, [SEQ_SPLITTER]found it so.

BRUTUS:
The gods have well prevented[SEQ_SPLITTER] it, and Rome
Sits safe and still without him.

AE[SEQ_SPLITTER]dile:
Worthy tribunes,
There is a slave, whom we h[SEQ_SPLITTER]ave put in prison,
Reports, the Volsces with two s[SEQ_SPLITTER]everal powers
Are enter'd in the Roman territories[SEQ_SPLITTER],
And with the deepest malice of the war
Destroy w[SEQ_SPLITTER]hat lies before 'em.

MENENIUS:
'Tis Aufidius,
Who[SEQ_SPLITTER], hearing of our Marcius' banishment,
Thrusts fort[SEQ_SPLITTER]h his horns again into the world;
Which were inshe[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll'd when Marcius stood for Rome,
And durst not on[SEQ_SPLITTER]ce peep out.

SICINIUS:

Of Mar[SEQ_SPLITTER]cius?

BRUTUS:
Go see this rumourer whipp'd. It ca[SEQ_SPLITTER]nnot be

And beat the messenger wh[SEQ_SPLITTER]o bids beware
Of what is to be dreaded.

SICINIUS:[SEQ_SPLITTER]

Not [SEQ_SPLITTER]possible.

The nobles in great earnestn[SEQ_SPLITTER]ess are going

That turns their countenances.

Nothing but his report.

More fearful, is deliver'd.

Second Messenger:

A fearful army, led by Caius[SEQ_SPLITTER] Marcius
Associated with Aufidius, rages
Upon our [SEQ_SPLITTER]territories; and have already

What lay before them[SEQ_SPLITTER].

Into an auger's bore.

You have made fair work, I fear me.[SEQ_SPLITTER]--Pray, your news?--
If Marcius should be join'd w[SEQ_SPLITTER]ith Volscians,--

He is their god: h[SEQ_SPLITTER]e leads them like a thing
Made by some other deity[SEQ_SPLITTER] than nature,
That shapes man better; and they fol[SEQ_SPLITTER]low him,
Against us brats, with no less confidence[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Than boys pursuing summer butterflies,
Or butcher[SEQ_SPLITTER]s killing flies.

Did shake do[SEQ_SPLITTER]wn mellow fruit.

Before you find it other. All the region[SEQ_SPLITTER]s

Are mock'd f[SEQ_SPLITTER]or valiant ignorance,
And perish constant fools. W[SEQ_SPLITTER]ho is't can blame him?
Your enemies and his find s[SEQ_SPLITTER]omething in him.

The noble man have mercy.

Shou[SEQ_SPLITTER]ld say 'Be good to Rome,' they charged him even
As[SEQ_SPLITTER] those should do that had deserved his hate,
And t[SEQ_SPLITTER]herein show'd like enemies.

[SEQ_SPLITTER]If he were putting to my house the brand

You and yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]ur crafts! you have crafted fair!

That Rom[SEQ_SPLITTER]e can make against them.

AUFIDIUS:
Do they still fly to the Roman?

Lieut[SEQ_SPLITTER]enant:

Your soldiers use him as the grace 'fore meat,
Th[SEQ_SPLITTER]eir talk at table, and their thanks at end;
And yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]u are darken'd in this action, sir,
Even by your o[SEQ_SPLITTER]wn.

AUFIDIUS:

Unless, by us[SEQ_SPLITTER]ing means, I lame the foot
Of our design. He bears[SEQ_SPLITTER] himself more proudlier,
Even to my person, than I[SEQ_SPLITTER] thought he would

In that's no changeling; and I must e[SEQ_SPLITTER]xcuse
What cannot be amended.

Lieutenant:

Join'd in commission with him; but either
Had b[SEQ_SPLITTER]orne the action of yourself, or else
To him had le[SEQ_SPLITTER]ft it solely.

AUFIDIUS:

when he shall come to his account[SEQ_SPLITTER], he knows not
What I can urge against him. Althou[SEQ_SPLITTER]gh it seems,
And so he thinks, and is no less appa[SEQ_SPLITTER]rent
To the vulgar eye, that he bears all things f[SEQ_SPLITTER]airly.
And shows good husbandry for the Volscian s[SEQ_SPLITTER]tate,
Fights dragon-like, and does achieve as soon[SEQ_SPLITTER]
As draw his sword; yet he hath left undone
That w[SEQ_SPLITTER]hich shall break his neck or hazard mine,
Whene'er[SEQ_SPLITTER] we come to our account.

Lieutenant:
Sir, I besee[SEQ_SPLITTER]ch you, think you he'll carry Rome?

AUFIDIUS:
All[SEQ_SPLITTER] places yield to him ere he sits down;
And the nob[SEQ_SPLITTER]ility of Rome are his:
The senators and patricians[SEQ_SPLITTER] love him too:
The tribunes are no soldiers; and t[SEQ_SPLITTER]heir people
Will be as rash in the repeal, as hast[SEQ_SPLITTER]y
To expel him thence. I think he'll be to Rome
As[SEQ_SPLITTER] is the osprey to the fish, who takes it
By sovere[SEQ_SPLITTER]ignty of nature. First he was
A noble servant to t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hem; but he could not
Carry his honours even: whet[SEQ_SPLITTER]her 'twas pride,
Which out of daily fortune ever t[SEQ_SPLITTER]aints
The happy man; whether defect of judgment,
T[SEQ_SPLITTER]o fail in the disposing of those chances
Which he [SEQ_SPLITTER]was lord of; or whether nature,
Not to be other th[SEQ_SPLITTER]an one thing, not moving
From the casque to the cu[SEQ_SPLITTER]shion, but commanding peace
Even with the same aus[SEQ_SPLITTER]terity and garb
As he controll'd the war; but one [SEQ_SPLITTER]of these--
As he hath spices of them all, not all,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
For I dare so far free him--made him fear'd,
So h[SEQ_SPLITTER]ated, and so banish'd: but he has a merit,
To chok[SEQ_SPLITTER]e it in the utterance. So our virtues
Lie in the i[SEQ_SPLITTER]nterpretation of the time:
And power, unto itself [SEQ_SPLITTER]most commendable,
Hath not a tomb so evident as a [SEQ_SPLITTER]chair
To extol what it hath done.
One fire drives [SEQ_SPLITTER]out one fire; one nail, one nail;
Rights by rights[SEQ_SPLITTER] falter, strengths by strengths do fail.
Come, let[SEQ_SPLITTER]'s away. When, Caius, Rome is thine,
Thou art poor[SEQ_SPLITTER]'st of all; then shortly art thou mine.

MENENIUS:[SEQ_SPLITTER]

Which[SEQ_SPLITTER] was sometime his general; who loved him

But what o'[SEQ_SPLITTER] that? Go, you that banish'd him;

The way into his mercy:[SEQ_SPLITTER] nay, if he coy'd
To hear Cominius speak, I'll kee[SEQ_SPLITTER]p at home.

COMINIUS:
He would not seem to know me[SEQ_SPLITTER].

I urged our old acquain[SEQ_SPLITTER]tance, and the drops
That we have bled together. C[SEQ_SPLITTER]oriolanus
He would not answer to: forbad all names[SEQ_SPLITTER];
He was a kind of nothing, titleless,
Till he had[SEQ_SPLITTER] forged himself a name o' the fire
Of burning Rome[SEQ_SPLITTER].

MENENIUS:
Why, so: you have made good work!
A p[SEQ_SPLITTER]air of tribunes that have rack'd for Rome,
To make[SEQ_SPLITTER] coals cheap,--a noble memory!

COMINIUS:
I minded[SEQ_SPLITTER] him how royal 'twas to pardon
When it was less ex[SEQ_SPLITTER]pected: he replied,
It was a bare petition of a st[SEQ_SPLITTER]ate
To one whom they had punish'd.

MENENIUS:
Very[SEQ_SPLITTER] well:
Could he say less?

I offer'd to [SEQ_SPLITTER]awaken his regard
For's private friends: his answe[SEQ_SPLITTER]r to me was,
He could not stay to pick them in a p[SEQ_SPLITTER]ile
Of noisome musty chaff: he said 'twas folly,
F[SEQ_SPLITTER]or one poor grain or two, to leave unburnt,
And st[SEQ_SPLITTER]ill to nose the offence.

MENENIUS:
For one poor g[SEQ_SPLITTER]rain or two!
I am one of those; his mother, wife, [SEQ_SPLITTER]his child,
And this brave fellow too, we are the g[SEQ_SPLITTER]rains:
You are the musty chaff; and you are smelt
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Above the moon: we must be burnt for you.

SICINIU[SEQ_SPLITTER]S:

More than th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e instant army we can make,
Might stop our country[SEQ_SPLITTER]man.

must have that thanks from Ro[SEQ_SPLITTER]me, after the measure

MENEN[SEQ_SPLITTER]IUS:
I'll undertake 't:
I think he'll hear me. Yet[SEQ_SPLITTER], to bite his lip
And hum at good Cominius, much u[SEQ_SPLITTER]nhearts me.
He was not taken well; he had not dine[SEQ_SPLITTER]d:
The veins unfill'd, our blood is cold, and then[SEQ_SPLITTER]
We pout upon the morning, are unapt
To give or to[SEQ_SPLITTER] forgive; but when we have stuff'd
These and these[SEQ_SPLITTER] conveyances of our blood
With wine and feeding, w[SEQ_SPLITTER]e have suppler souls
Than in our priest-like fasts[SEQ_SPLITTER]: therefore I'll watch him
Till he be dieted to my[SEQ_SPLITTER] request,
And then I'll set upon him.

BRUTUS:
You[SEQ_SPLITTER] know the very road into his kindness,
And cannot [SEQ_SPLITTER]lose your way.

MENENIUS:

Speed how it will. I shall ere long have knowl[SEQ_SPLITTER]edge
Of my success.

COMINIUS:

SICINIUS:

COMINIUS:

The gaoler to his pity. I kneel'd befo[SEQ_SPLITTER]re him;
'Twas very faintly he said 'Rise;' dismiss[SEQ_SPLITTER]'d me
Thus, with his speechless hand: what he woul[SEQ_SPLITTER]d do,
He sent in writing after me; what he would n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ot,
Bound with an oath to yield to his conditions:[SEQ_SPLITTER]
So that all hope is vain.
Unless his noble mother[SEQ_SPLITTER], and his wife;
Who, as I hear, mean to solicit hi[SEQ_SPLITTER]m
For mercy to his country. Therefore, let's hence[SEQ_SPLITTER],
And with our fair entreaties haste them on.

Fir[SEQ_SPLITTER]st Senator:
Stay: whence are you?

Second Senator:[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Stand, and go back.

H[SEQ_SPLITTER]is name unparallel'd, haply amplified;
For I have [SEQ_SPLITTER]ever verified my friends,

In the same time '[SEQ_SPLITTER]tis made? I will not.
My wife comes foremost; then[SEQ_SPLITTER] the honour'd mould
Wherein this trunk was framed,[SEQ_SPLITTER] and in her hand
The grandchild to her blood. But,[SEQ_SPLITTER] out, affection!
All bond and privilege of nature,[SEQ_SPLITTER] break!
Let it be virtuous to be obstinate.
What i[SEQ_SPLITTER]s that curt'sy worth? or those doves' eyes,

Sir, if you[SEQ_SPLITTER]'ld save your life, fly to your house:
The plebeia[SEQ_SPLITTER]ns have got your fellow-tribune
And hale him up an[SEQ_SPLITTER]d down, all swearing, if
The Roman ladies bring no[SEQ_SPLITTER]t comfort home,
They'll give him death by inches.
[SEQ_SPLITTER]
SICINIUS:
What's the news?

Second Messenger:
Goo[SEQ_SPLITTER]d news, good news; the ladies have prevail'd,
The [SEQ_SPLITTER]Volscians are dislodged, and Marcius gone:
A merri[SEQ_SPLITTER]er day did never yet greet Rome,
No, not the expul[SEQ_SPLITTER]sion of the Tarquins.

SICINIUS:
Friend,
Art thou [SEQ_SPLITTER]certain this is true? is it most certain?

Second [SEQ_SPLITTER]Messenger:
As certain as I know the sun is fire:
W[SEQ_SPLITTER]here have you lurk'd, that you make doubt of it?
N[SEQ_SPLITTER]e'er through an arch so hurried the blown tide,
As[SEQ_SPLITTER] the recomforted through the gates. Why, hark you![SEQ_SPLITTER]
The trumpets, sackbuts, psalteries and fifes,
Tab[SEQ_SPLITTER]ours and cymbals and the shouting Romans,
Make the[SEQ_SPLITTER] sun dance. Hark you!

MENENIUS:
This is good news[SEQ_SPLITTER]:
I will go meet the ladies. This Volumnia
Is wort[SEQ_SPLITTER]h of consuls, senators, patricians,
A city full; o[SEQ_SPLITTER]f tribunes, such as you,
A sea and land full. You [SEQ_SPLITTER]have pray'd well to-day:
This morning for ten thou[SEQ_SPLITTER]sand of your throats
I'd not have given a doit. Ha[SEQ_SPLITTER]rk, how they joy!

Accept my thankfulnes[SEQ_SPLITTER]s.

Great cause[SEQ_SPLITTER] to give great thanks.

And help the joy.[SEQ_SPLITTER]

First Senator:

AUFIDIUS:

[SEQ_SPLITTER]Bid them repair to the market place; where I,
Even[SEQ_SPLITTER] in theirs and in the commons' ears,
Will vouch th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e truth of it. Him I accuse
The city ports by this[SEQ_SPLITTER] hath enter'd and
Intends to appear before the peo[SEQ_SPLITTER]ple, hoping
To purge herself with words: dispatch.[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Most welcome!

Even so
As with a man by h[SEQ_SPLITTER]is own alms empoison'd,

You wish'd us parties,[SEQ_SPLITTER] we'll deliver you

AUFIDIUS[SEQ_SPLITTER]:

We must proceed as we do fin[SEQ_SPLITTER]d the people.

Third Conspirator:
The people will [SEQ_SPLITTER]remain uncertain whilst
'Twixt you there's differe[SEQ_SPLITTER]nce; but the fall of either
Makes the survivor hei[SEQ_SPLITTER]r of all.

AUFIDIUS:
I know it;
And my pretext to [SEQ_SPLITTER]strike at him admits
A good construction. I raised[SEQ_SPLITTER] him, and I pawn'd
Mine honour for his truth: who [SEQ_SPLITTER]being so heighten'd,
He water'd his new plants wit[SEQ_SPLITTER]h dews of flattery,
Seducing so my friends; and, t[SEQ_SPLITTER]o this end,
He bow'd his nature, never known befor[SEQ_SPLITTER]e
But to be rough, unswayable and free.

Third Con[SEQ_SPLITTER]spirator:
Sir, his stoutness
When he did stand for[SEQ_SPLITTER] consul, which he lost
By lack of stooping,--

AUF[SEQ_SPLITTER]IDIUS:
That I would have spoke of:
Being banish'd [SEQ_SPLITTER]for't, he came unto my hearth;
Presented to my kni[SEQ_SPLITTER]fe his throat: I took him;
Made him joint-servant [SEQ_SPLITTER]with me; gave him way
In all his own desires; nay,[SEQ_SPLITTER] let him choose

In mine own person; holp to reap the fam[SEQ_SPLITTER]e
Which he did end all his; and took some pride
To[SEQ_SPLITTER] do myself this wrong: till, at the last,
I seem'd[SEQ_SPLITTER] his follower, not partner, and
He waged me with h[SEQ_SPLITTER]is countenance, as if
I had been mercenary.

First[SEQ_SPLITTER] Conspirator:

The army marvell[SEQ_SPLITTER]'d at it, and, in the last,

And I'll renew me in his fall. But, h[SEQ_SPLITTER]ark!

First Conspirator:
Your native town you ente[SEQ_SPLITTER]r'd like a post,

CORIOLANUS:

No more infected with my country's[SEQ_SPLITTER] love

Under your great command. You are to know
That [SEQ_SPLITTER]prosperously I have attempted and
With bloody pass[SEQ_SPLITTER]age led your wars even to
The gates of Rome. Our s[SEQ_SPLITTER]poils we have brought home
Do more than counterpoi[SEQ_SPLITTER]se a full third part

With no less honour to the Antiat[SEQ_SPLITTER]es

Together[SEQ_SPLITTER] with the seal o' the senate, what
We have compoun[SEQ_SPLITTER]ded on.

GLOUCESTER:
Now is the winter [SEQ_SPLITTER]of our discontent
Made glorious summer by this sun[SEQ_SPLITTER] of York;
And all the clouds that lour'd upon our [SEQ_SPLITTER]house
In the deep bosom of the ocean buried.
Now a[SEQ_SPLITTER]re our brows bound with victorious wreaths;
Our br[SEQ_SPLITTER]uised arms hung up for monuments;
Our stern alarum[SEQ_SPLITTER]s changed to merry meetings,
Our dreadful marches [SEQ_SPLITTER]to delightful measures.
Grim-visaged war hath smoo[SEQ_SPLITTER]th'd his wrinkled front;
And now, instead of mount[SEQ_SPLITTER]ing barded steeds
To fright the souls of fearful a[SEQ_SPLITTER]dversaries,
He capers nimbly in a lady's chamber
T[SEQ_SPLITTER]o the lascivious pleasing of a lute.
But I, that a[SEQ_SPLITTER]m not shaped for sportive tricks,
Nor made to cour[SEQ_SPLITTER]t an amorous looking-glass;
I, that am rudely stam[SEQ_SPLITTER]p'd, and want love's majesty
To strut before a wan[SEQ_SPLITTER]ton ambling nymph;
I, that am curtail'd of this fa[SEQ_SPLITTER]ir proportion,
Cheated of feature by dissembling n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ature,
Deformed, unfinish'd, sent before my time
I[SEQ_SPLITTER]nto this breathing world, scarce half made up,
And[SEQ_SPLITTER] that so lamely and unfashionable
That dogs bark a[SEQ_SPLITTER]t me as I halt by them;
Why, I, in this weak pipin[SEQ_SPLITTER]g time of peace,
Have no delight to pass away the [SEQ_SPLITTER]time,
Unless to spy my shadow in the sun
And desca[SEQ_SPLITTER]nt on mine own deformity:
And therefore, since I c[SEQ_SPLITTER]annot prove a lover,
To entertain these fair well-[SEQ_SPLITTER]spoken days,
I am determined to prove a villain
An[SEQ_SPLITTER]d hate the idle pleasures of these days.
Plots hav[SEQ_SPLITTER]e I laid, inductions dangerous,
By drunken prophec[SEQ_SPLITTER]ies, libels and dreams,
To set my brother Clarence[SEQ_SPLITTER] and the king
In deadly hate the one against the o[SEQ_SPLITTER]ther:
And if King Edward be as true and just
As I [SEQ_SPLITTER]am subtle, false and treacherous,
This day should [SEQ_SPLITTER]Clarence closely be mew'd up,
About a prophecy, wh[SEQ_SPLITTER]ich says that 'G'
Of Edward's heirs the murderer s[SEQ_SPLITTER]hall be.
Dive, thoughts, down to my soul: here
Cla[SEQ_SPLITTER]rence comes.
Brother, good day; what means this ar[SEQ_SPLITTER]med guard
That waits upon your grace?

H[SEQ_SPLITTER]is majesty

As yet I do not: but, as I can learn,
He hearkens[SEQ_SPLITTER] after prophecies and dreams;
And from the cross-r[SEQ_SPLITTER]ow plucks the letter G.
And says a wizard told him[SEQ_SPLITTER] that by G
His issue disinherited should be;
And, [SEQ_SPLITTER]for my name of George begins with G,
It follows in[SEQ_SPLITTER] his thought that I am he.
These, as I learn, and [SEQ_SPLITTER]such like toys as these
Have moved his highness to[SEQ_SPLITTER] commit me now.

GLOUCESTER:
Why, this it is, when[SEQ_SPLITTER] men are ruled by women:
'Tis not the king that se[SEQ_SPLITTER]nds you to the Tower:
My Lady Grey his wife, Clare[SEQ_SPLITTER]nce, 'tis she
That tempers him to this extremity.

Antho[SEQ_SPLITTER]ny Woodville, her brother there,

From whence this pre[SEQ_SPLITTER]sent day he is deliver'd?
We are not safe, Clarenc[SEQ_SPLITTER]e; we are not safe.

CLARENCE:

If we will keep in f[SEQ_SPLITTER]avour with the king,

Sinc[SEQ_SPLITTER]e that our brother dubb'd them gentlewomen.

[SEQ_SPLITTER]

[SEQ_SPLITTER]The King is sickly, weak and melancholy,
And his p[SEQ_SPLITTER]hysicians fear him mightily.

'Tis very grievous to be thought upon.[SEQ_SPLITTER]

HASTINGS:
He is.

GLOUCE[SEQ_SPLITTER]STER:
Go you before, and I will follow you.
He can[SEQ_SPLITTER]not live, I hope; and must not die
Till George be [SEQ_SPLITTER]pack'd with post-horse up to heaven.
I'll in, to u[SEQ_SPLITTER]rge his hatred more to Clarence,
With lies well st[SEQ_SPLITTER]eel'd with weighty arguments;
And, if I fall not i[SEQ_SPLITTER]n my deep intent,
Clarence hath not another day to[SEQ_SPLITTER] live:
Which done, God take King Edward to his mer[SEQ_SPLITTER]cy,
And leave the world for me to bustle in!
For t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hen I'll marry Warwick's youngest daughter.
What t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hough I kill'd her husband and her father?
The rea[SEQ_SPLITTER]diest way to make the wench amends
Is to become he[SEQ_SPLITTER]r husband and her father:
The which will I; not al[SEQ_SPLITTER]l so much for love
As for another secret close int[SEQ_SPLITTER]ent,
By marrying her which I must reach unto.
But [SEQ_SPLITTER]yet I run before my horse to market:
Clarence stil[SEQ_SPLITTER]l breathes; Edward still lives and reigns:
When th[SEQ_SPLITTER]ey are gone, then must I count my gains.

LADY ANN[SEQ_SPLITTER]E:
Set down, set down your honourable load,
If hon[SEQ_SPLITTER]our may be shrouded in a hearse,
Whilst I awhile o[SEQ_SPLITTER]bsequiously lament
The untimely fall of virtuous L[SEQ_SPLITTER]ancaster.
Poor key-cold figure of a holy king!

Thou bloodless [SEQ_SPLITTER]remnant of that royal blood!
Be it lawful that I i[SEQ_SPLITTER]nvocate thy ghost,
To hear the lamentations of Poo[SEQ_SPLITTER]r Anne,
Wife to thy Edward, to thy slaughter'd son[SEQ_SPLITTER],
Stabb'd by the selfsame hand that made these wou[SEQ_SPLITTER]nds!
Lo, in these windows that let forth thy life,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
I pour the helpless balm of my poor eyes.
Cursed [SEQ_SPLITTER]be the hand that made these fatal holes!
Cursed be[SEQ_SPLITTER] the heart that had the heart to do it!
Cursed the[SEQ_SPLITTER] blood that let this blood from hence!
More direfu[SEQ_SPLITTER]l hap betide that hated wretch,
That makes us wret[SEQ_SPLITTER]ched by the death of thee,
Than I can wish to adde[SEQ_SPLITTER]rs, spiders, toads,
Or any creeping venom'd thing [SEQ_SPLITTER]that lives!
If ever he have child, abortive be it,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Prodigious, and untimely brought to light,
Whose [SEQ_SPLITTER]ugly and unnatural aspect
May fright the hopeful m[SEQ_SPLITTER]other at the view;
And that be heir to his unhappi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ness!
If ever he have wife, let her he made
A mise[SEQ_SPLITTER]rable by the death of him
As I am made by my poor [SEQ_SPLITTER]lord and thee!
Come, now towards Chertsey with you[SEQ_SPLITTER]r holy load,
Taken from Paul's to be interred ther[SEQ_SPLITTER]e;
And still, as you are weary of the weight,
Rest[SEQ_SPLITTER] you, whiles I lament King Henry's corse.

She may h[SEQ_SPLITTER]elp you to many fair preferments,
And then deny he[SEQ_SPLITTER]r aiding hand therein,
And lay those honours on yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]ur high deserts.
What may she not? She may, yea, m[SEQ_SPLITTER]arry, may she--

A bachelor, a handsome stripling too:
I wis your [SEQ_SPLITTER]grandam had a worser match.

By heaven, I[SEQ_SPLITTER] will acquaint his majesty

Than a great queen, with this conditio[SEQ_SPLITTER]n,
To be thus taunted, scorn'd, and baited at:
Sma[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll joy have I in being England's queen.

And, in my company, my brother Gloucester;[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Who from my cabin tempted me to walk

And cited u[SEQ_SPLITTER]p a thousand fearful times,
During the wars of Yor[SEQ_SPLITTER]k and Lancaster
That had befall'n us. As we paced [SEQ_SPLITTER]along
Upon the giddy footing of the hatches,
Metho[SEQ_SPLITTER]ught that Gloucester stumbled; and, in falling,
St[SEQ_SPLITTER]ruck me, that thought to stay him, overboard,
Into[SEQ_SPLITTER] the tumbling billows of the main.

What dreadful n[SEQ_SPLITTER]oise of waters in mine ears!
What ugly sights of d[SEQ_SPLITTER]eath within mine eyes!

Which almost b[SEQ_SPLITTER]urst to belch it in the sea.

T[SEQ_SPLITTER]he first that there did greet my stranger soul,
Wa[SEQ_SPLITTER]s my great father-in-law, renowned Warwick;
Who cr[SEQ_SPLITTER]ied aloud, 'What scourge for perjury

And so he vanish[SEQ_SPLITTER]'d: then came wandering by

'Clarence is come; false, fleeting, p[SEQ_SPLITTER]erjured Clarence,
That stabb'd me in the field by [SEQ_SPLITTER]Tewksbury;

BRAKENBURY:

Sorrow breaks seasons[SEQ_SPLITTER] and reposing hours,
Makes the night morning, and [SEQ_SPLITTER]the noon-tide night.
Princes have but their tides [SEQ_SPLITTER]for their glories,
An outward honour for an inward[SEQ_SPLITTER] toil;
And, for unfelt imagination,
They often fee[SEQ_SPLITTER]l a world of restless cares:
So that, betwixt thei[SEQ_SPLITTER]r tides and low names,
There's nothing differs but[SEQ_SPLITTER] the outward fame.

Oh, who shall hinder me to wail and weep,
To chi[SEQ_SPLITTER]de my fortune, and torment myself?
I'll join with [SEQ_SPLITTER]black despair against my soul,
And to myself becom[SEQ_SPLITTER]e an enemy.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
What means this scen[SEQ_SPLITTER]e of rude impatience?

To make an[SEQ_SPLITTER] act of tragic violence:
Edward, my lord, your son[SEQ_SPLITTER], our king, is dead.
Why grow the branches now the[SEQ_SPLITTER] root is wither'd?
Why wither not the leaves the s[SEQ_SPLITTER]ap being gone?
If you will live, lament; if die, b[SEQ_SPLITTER]e brief,
That our swift-winged souls may catch the[SEQ_SPLITTER] king's;
Or, like obedient subjects, follow him
To[SEQ_SPLITTER] his new kingdom of perpetual rest.

DUCHESS OF YO[SEQ_SPLITTER]RK:

And lived by looking on his[SEQ_SPLITTER] images:

And[SEQ_SPLITTER] I for comfort have but one false glass,
Which gri[SEQ_SPLITTER]eves me when I see my shame in him.

First Citizen:

And the queen's sons and brothers haught and pro[SEQ_SPLITTER]ud:

Th[SEQ_SPLITTER]is sickly land might solace as before.

When the sun sets, who doth not [SEQ_SPLITTER]look for night?

'[SEQ_SPLITTER]Tis more than we deserve, or I expect.

That ever wretched age hath look'd upon.

They smile[SEQ_SPLITTER] at me that shortly shall be dead.

GLOUCESTER:
Co[SEQ_SPLITTER]me, cousin, canst thou quake, and change thy colou[SEQ_SPLITTER]r,
Murder thy breath in the middle of a word,
And [SEQ_SPLITTER]then begin again, and stop again,
As if thou wert [SEQ_SPLITTER]distraught and mad with terror?

BUCKINGHAM:

Speak and lo[SEQ_SPLITTER]ok back, and pry on every side,
Tremble and start [SEQ_SPLITTER]at wagging of a straw,
Intending deep suspicion: g[SEQ_SPLITTER]hastly looks
Are at my service, like enforced smil[SEQ_SPLITTER]es;
And both are ready in their offices,
At any ti[SEQ_SPLITTER]me, to grace my stratagems.

Scrivener:
This is the indictment of the good Lo[SEQ_SPLITTER]rd Hastings;
Which in a set hand fairly is engross[SEQ_SPLITTER]'d,
That it may be this day read over in Paul's.
A[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd mark how well the sequel hangs together:
Eleven[SEQ_SPLITTER] hours I spent to write it over,
For yesternight b[SEQ_SPLITTER]y Catesby was it brought me;
The precedent was ful[SEQ_SPLITTER]l as long a-doing:
And yet within these five hours[SEQ_SPLITTER] lived Lord Hastings,
Untainted, unexamined, free,[SEQ_SPLITTER] at liberty
Here's a good world the while! Why who[SEQ_SPLITTER]'s so gross,
That seeth not this palpable device?
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Yet who's so blind, but says he sees it not?
Bad i[SEQ_SPLITTER]s the world; and all will come to nought,
When suc[SEQ_SPLITTER]h bad dealings must be seen in thought.

Now, by the holy mother of our Lord,
The ci[SEQ_SPLITTER]tizens are mum and speak not a word.

[SEQ_SPLITTER]Touch'd you the bastardy of Edward's children?

BU[SEQ_SPLITTER]CKINGHAM:
I did; with his contract with Lady Lucy,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
And his contract by deputy in France;
The insatia[SEQ_SPLITTER]te greediness of his desires,
And his enforcement [SEQ_SPLITTER]of the city wives;
His tyranny for trifles; his ow[SEQ_SPLITTER]n bastardy,
As being got, your father then in Fran[SEQ_SPLITTER]ce,
His resemblance, being not like the duke;
With[SEQ_SPLITTER]al I did infer your lineaments,
Being the right id[SEQ_SPLITTER]ea of your father,
Both in your form and nobleness[SEQ_SPLITTER] of mind;
Laid open all your victories in Scotland[SEQ_SPLITTER],
Your dicipline in war, wisdom in peace,
Your bou[SEQ_SPLITTER]nty, virtue, fair humility:
Indeed, left nothing f[SEQ_SPLITTER]itting for the purpose
Untouch'd, or slightly hand[SEQ_SPLITTER]led, in discourse
And when mine oratory grew to an[SEQ_SPLITTER] end
I bid them that did love their country's good[SEQ_SPLITTER]

But, like dum[SEQ_SPLITTER]b statues or breathing stones,

Which when I saw, I repr[SEQ_SPLITTER]ehended them;
And ask'd the mayor what meant this [SEQ_SPLITTER]wilful silence:
His answer was, the people were no[SEQ_SPLITTER]t wont
To be spoke to but by the recorder.
Then he[SEQ_SPLITTER] was urged to tell my tale again,
'Thus saith the [SEQ_SPLITTER]duke, thus hath the duke inferr'd;'
But nothing sp[SEQ_SPLITTER]ake in warrant from himself.
When he had done, som[SEQ_SPLITTER]e followers of mine own,

And thus I took the va[SEQ_SPLITTER]ntage of those few,

W[SEQ_SPLITTER]hich God defend that I should wring from him!

For first he was contract to[SEQ_SPLITTER] Lady Lucy--
Your mother lives a witness to that v[SEQ_SPLITTER]ow--
And afterward by substitute betroth'd

These both put by [SEQ_SPLITTER]a poor petitioner,
A care-crazed mother of a many [SEQ_SPLITTER]children,

Ev[SEQ_SPLITTER]en in the afternoon of her best days,
Made prize a[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd purchase of his lustful eye,
Seduced the pitch [SEQ_SPLITTER]and height of all his thoughts
To base declension [SEQ_SPLITTER]and loathed bigamy

More bitterly could I expostulate,

I give a sparing limit [SEQ_SPLITTER]to my tongue.

No[SEQ_SPLITTER] farther than the Tower; and, as I guess,
Upon the[SEQ_SPLITTER] like devotion as yourselves,
To gratulate the gen[SEQ_SPLITTER]tle princes there.

QUEEN ELIZABET[SEQ_SPLITTER]H:

That[SEQ_SPLITTER] I should wish for thee to help me curse
That bott[SEQ_SPLITTER]led spider, that foul bunch-back'd toad!

QUEEN MA[SEQ_SPLITTER]RGARET:
I call'd thee then vain flourish of my for[SEQ_SPLITTER]tune;
I call'd thee then poor shadow, painted quee[SEQ_SPLITTER]n;
The presentation of but what I was;
The flatter[SEQ_SPLITTER]ing index of a direful pageant;
One heaved a-high,[SEQ_SPLITTER] to be hurl'd down below;
A mother only mock'd wit[SEQ_SPLITTER]h two sweet babes;
A dream of what thou wert, a br[SEQ_SPLITTER]eath, a bubble,
A sign of dignity, a garish flag,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]To be the aim of every dangerous shot,
A queen in [SEQ_SPLITTER]jest, only to fill the scene.
Where is thy husband[SEQ_SPLITTER] now? where be thy brothers?
Where are thy childre[SEQ_SPLITTER]n? wherein dost thou, joy?
Who sues to thee and cr[SEQ_SPLITTER]ies 'God save the queen'?
Where be the bending pee[SEQ_SPLITTER]rs that flatter'd thee?
Where be the thronging tro[SEQ_SPLITTER]ops that follow'd thee?
Decline all this, and see [SEQ_SPLITTER]what now thou art:
For happy wife, a most distress[SEQ_SPLITTER]ed widow;
For joyful mother, one that wails the na[SEQ_SPLITTER]me;
For queen, a very caitiff crown'd with care;
F[SEQ_SPLITTER]or one being sued to, one that humbly sues;
For on[SEQ_SPLITTER]e that scorn'd at me, now scorn'd of me;
For one b[SEQ_SPLITTER]eing fear'd of all, now fearing one;
For one comma[SEQ_SPLITTER]nding all, obey'd of none.
Thus hath the course of[SEQ_SPLITTER] justice wheel'd about,
And left thee but a very p[SEQ_SPLITTER]rey to time;
Having no more but thought of what th[SEQ_SPLITTER]ou wert,
To torture thee the more, being what thou[SEQ_SPLITTER] art.
Thou didst usurp my place, and dost thou not[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Usurp the just proportion of my sorrow?
Now thy p[SEQ_SPLITTER]roud neck bears half my burthen'd yoke;
From which[SEQ_SPLITTER] even here I slip my weary neck,
And leave the bur[SEQ_SPLITTER]then of it all on thee.
Farewell, York's wife, and[SEQ_SPLITTER] queen of sad mischance:
These English woes will m[SEQ_SPLITTER]ake me smile in France.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
O thou w[SEQ_SPLITTER]ell skill'd in curses, stay awhile,
And teach me h[SEQ_SPLITTER]ow to curse mine enemies!

QUEEN MARGARET:
Forbear[SEQ_SPLITTER] to sleep the nights, and fast the days;
Compare d[SEQ_SPLITTER]ead happiness with living woe;
Think that thy babe[SEQ_SPLITTER]s were fairer than they were,
And he that slew the[SEQ_SPLITTER]m fouler than he is:
Bettering thy loss makes the [SEQ_SPLITTER]bad causer worse:
Revolving this will teach thee h[SEQ_SPLITTER]ow to curse.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:

QUEEN MARGARET:
Thy w[SEQ_SPLITTER]oes will make them sharp, and pierce like mine.

Let them have scope[SEQ_SPLITTER]: though what they do impart

It cannot be avoided but by this[SEQ_SPLITTER];
It will not be avoided but by this.

Plead what I will be, not what I[SEQ_SPLITTER] have been;
Not my deserts, but what I will deserv[SEQ_SPLITTER]e:
Urge the necessity and state of times,
And be n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ot peevish-fond in great designs.

KING RICH[SEQ_SPLITTER]ARD III:
Ay, if the devil tempt thee to do good.

KING RICHARD III:
Give me a[SEQ_SPLITTER]nother horse: bind up my wounds.
Have mercy, Jesu![SEQ_SPLITTER]--Soft! I did but dream.
O coward conscience, how [SEQ_SPLITTER]dost thou afflict me!
The lights burn blue. It is [SEQ_SPLITTER]now dead midnight.
Cold fearful drops stand on my [SEQ_SPLITTER]trembling flesh.
What do I fear?  myself?  there's[SEQ_SPLITTER] none else by:
Richard loves Richard; that is, I a[SEQ_SPLITTER]m I.
Is there a murderer here?  No. Yes, I am:
The[SEQ_SPLITTER]n fly. What, from myself?   Great reason why:
Lest[SEQ_SPLITTER] I revenge. What, myself upon myself?
Alack. I lov[SEQ_SPLITTER]e myself. Wherefore?  for any good
That I myself h[SEQ_SPLITTER]ave done unto myself?
O, no! alas, I rather hate m[SEQ_SPLITTER]yself
For hateful deeds committed by myself!
I am [SEQ_SPLITTER]a villain: yet I lie. I am not.
Fool, of thyself s[SEQ_SPLITTER]peak well: fool, do not flatter.
My conscience hat[SEQ_SPLITTER]h a thousand several tongues,
And every tongue bri[SEQ_SPLITTER]ngs in a several tale,
And every tale condemns me [SEQ_SPLITTER]for a villain.
Perjury, perjury, in the high'st de[SEQ_SPLITTER]gree
Murder, stem murder, in the direst degree;
Al[SEQ_SPLITTER]l several sins, all used in each degree,
Throng to[SEQ_SPLITTER] the bar, crying all, Guilty! guilty!
I shall desp[SEQ_SPLITTER]air. There is no creature loves me;
And if I die, [SEQ_SPLITTER]no soul shall pity me:
Nay, wherefore should they,[SEQ_SPLITTER] since that I myself
Find in myself no pity to mys[SEQ_SPLITTER]elf?
Methought the souls of all that I had murder'[SEQ_SPLITTER]d
Came to my tent; and every one did threat
To-mor[SEQ_SPLITTER]row's vengeance on the head of Richard.

What thinkest thou, will our friend[SEQ_SPLITTER]s prove all true?

No doubt, my lord.

Have struck more terror to the soul of R[SEQ_SPLITTER]ichard

Armed in proof, and led by shallow Richmond.
[SEQ_SPLITTER]It is not yet near day. Come, go with me;
Under ou[SEQ_SPLITTER]r tents I'll play the eaves-dropper,
To see if any[SEQ_SPLITTER] mean to shrink from me.

Forbids to dwell upon: yet remember this,
Go[SEQ_SPLITTER]d and our good cause fight upon our side;

Like high-re[SEQ_SPLITTER]ar'd bulwarks, stand before our faces;

If you do sweat to put a tyran[SEQ_SPLITTER]t down,

You[SEQ_SPLITTER]r country's fat shall pay your pains the hire;
If [SEQ_SPLITTER]you do fight in safeguard of your wives,
Your wive[SEQ_SPLITTER]s shall welcome home the conquerors;

The least of you shall share his part thereof[SEQ_SPLITTER].

[SEQ_SPLITTER]God and Saint George! Richmond and victory!

Will rain hot vengeance on o[SEQ_SPLITTER]ffenders' heads.

DUCHESS:
Finds brotherhood in th[SEQ_SPLITTER]ee no sharper spur?
Hath love in thy old blood no [SEQ_SPLITTER]living fire?
Edward's seven sons, whereof thyself [SEQ_SPLITTER]art one,
Were as seven vials of his sacred blood,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Or seven fair branches springing from one root:
So[SEQ_SPLITTER]me of those seven are dried by nature's course,
So[SEQ_SPLITTER]me of those branches by the Destinies cut;
But Tho[SEQ_SPLITTER]mas, my dear lord, my life, my Gloucester,
One via[SEQ_SPLITTER]l full of Edward's sacred blood,
One flourishing b[SEQ_SPLITTER]ranch of his most royal root,
Is crack'd, and all [SEQ_SPLITTER]the precious liquor spilt,
Is hack'd down, and his[SEQ_SPLITTER] summer leaves all faded,
By envy's hand and murde[SEQ_SPLITTER]r's bloody axe.
Ah, Gaunt, his blood was thine! th[SEQ_SPLITTER]at bed, that womb,
That metal, that self-mould, th[SEQ_SPLITTER]at fashion'd thee
Made him a man; and though thou [SEQ_SPLITTER]livest and breathest,
Yet art thou slain in him: t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hou dost consent
In some large measure to thy fath[SEQ_SPLITTER]er's death,
In that thou seest thy wretched brothe[SEQ_SPLITTER]r die,
Who was the model of thy father's life.
Cal[SEQ_SPLITTER]l it not patience, Gaunt; it is despair:
In suffer[SEQ_SPLITTER]ing thus thy brother to be slaughter'd,
Thou showe[SEQ_SPLITTER]st the naked pathway to thy life,
Teaching stern m[SEQ_SPLITTER]urder how to butcher thee:
That which in mean men [SEQ_SPLITTER]we intitle patience
Is pale cold cowardice in nobl[SEQ_SPLITTER]e breasts.
What shall I say? to safeguard thine ow[SEQ_SPLITTER]n life,
The best way is to venge my Gloucester's d[SEQ_SPLITTER]eath.

Le[SEQ_SPLITTER]t heaven revenge; for I may never lift

To God, t[SEQ_SPLITTER]he widow's champion and defence.

DUCHESS:

Not with the empty hollowness,[SEQ_SPLITTER] but weight:
I take my leave before I have begun,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]For sorrow ends not when it seemeth done.
Commend [SEQ_SPLITTER]me to thy brother, Edmund York.
Lo, this is all:--[SEQ_SPLITTER]nay, yet depart not so;
Though this be all, do not[SEQ_SPLITTER] so quickly go;
I shall remember more. Bid him--ah[SEQ_SPLITTER], what?--

[SEQ_SPLITTER]Alack, and what shall good old York there see

Desolate, desolate, will I hence and d[SEQ_SPLITTER]ie:

Draw near,

For that o[SEQ_SPLITTER]ur kingdom's earth should not be soil'd
With that [SEQ_SPLITTER]dear blood which it hath fostered;
And for our eye[SEQ_SPLITTER]s do hate the dire aspect

JOHN OF GAUN[SEQ_SPLITTER]T:

Teach thy nece[SEQ_SPLITTER]ssity to reason thus;
There is no virtue like nece[SEQ_SPLITTER]ssity.
Think not the king did banish thee,
But tho[SEQ_SPLITTER]u the king. Woe doth the heavier sit,
Where it per[SEQ_SPLITTER]ceives it is but faintly borne.

Suppose t[SEQ_SPLITTER]he singing birds musicians,

For gnarling sorrow hath less pow[SEQ_SPLITTER]er to bite
The man that mocks at it and sets it li[SEQ_SPLITTER]ght.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:

JOHN OF GAUNT:
