Had I thy youth and cause, I w[SEQ_SPLITTER]ould not stay.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Then, England's[SEQ_SPLITTER] ground, farewell; sweet soil, adieu;
My mother, a[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd my nurse, that bears me yet!
Where'er I wander,[SEQ_SPLITTER] boast of this I can,
Though banish'd, yet a trueb[SEQ_SPLITTER]orn Englishman.

KING RICHARD II:
We did observe. [SEQ_SPLITTER]Cousin Aumerle,
How far brought you high Hereford [SEQ_SPLITTER]on his way?

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
I brought high Heref[SEQ_SPLITTER]ord, if you call him so,
But to the next highway, [SEQ_SPLITTER]and there I left him.

KING RICHARD II:
And say, w[SEQ_SPLITTER]hat store of parting tears were shed?

DUKE OF AUM[SEQ_SPLITTER]ERLE:
Faith, none for me; except the north-east wi[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd,
Which then blew bitterly against our faces,
Aw[SEQ_SPLITTER]aked the sleeping rheum, and so by chance
Did grac[SEQ_SPLITTER]e our hollow parting with a tear.

KING RICHARD II[SEQ_SPLITTER]:
What said our cousin when you parted with him?

[SEQ_SPLITTER]DUKE OF AUMERLE:
'Farewell:'
And, for my heart dis[SEQ_SPLITTER]dained that my tongue
Should so profane the word, [SEQ_SPLITTER]that taught me craft
To counterfeit oppression of [SEQ_SPLITTER]such grief
That words seem'd buried in my sorrow's[SEQ_SPLITTER] grave.
Marry, would the word 'farewell' have leng[SEQ_SPLITTER]then'd hours
And added years to his short banishme[SEQ_SPLITTER]nt,
He should have had a volume of farewells;
But [SEQ_SPLITTER]since it would not, he had none of me.

KING RICHA[SEQ_SPLITTER]RD II:
He is our cousin, cousin; but 'tis doubt,
W[SEQ_SPLITTER]hen time shall call him home from banishment,
Whet[SEQ_SPLITTER]her our kinsman come to see his friends.
Ourself a[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd Bushy, Bagot here and Green
Observed his courts[SEQ_SPLITTER]hip to the common people;
How he did seem to dive [SEQ_SPLITTER]into their hearts
With humble and familiar courtes[SEQ_SPLITTER]y,
What reverence he did throw away on slaves,
Woo[SEQ_SPLITTER]ing poor craftsmen with the craft of smiles
And pa[SEQ_SPLITTER]tient underbearing of his fortune,
As 'twere to ba[SEQ_SPLITTER]nish their affects with him.
Off goes his bonnet t[SEQ_SPLITTER]o an oyster-wench;
A brace of draymen bid God spee[SEQ_SPLITTER]d him well
And had the tribute of his supple knee,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
With 'Thanks, my countrymen, my loving friends;'
[SEQ_SPLITTER]As were our England in reversion his,
And he our s[SEQ_SPLITTER]ubjects' next degree in hope.

GREEN:
Well, he is [SEQ_SPLITTER]gone; and with him go these thoughts.
Now for the [SEQ_SPLITTER]rebels which stand out in Ireland,
Expedient manag[SEQ_SPLITTER]e must be made, my liege,
Ere further leisure yiel[SEQ_SPLITTER]d them further means
For their advantage and your [SEQ_SPLITTER]highness' loss.

KING RICHARD II:
We will ourself [SEQ_SPLITTER]in person to this war:
And, for our coffers, with [SEQ_SPLITTER]too great a court
And liberal largess, are grown s[SEQ_SPLITTER]omewhat light,
We are inforced to farm our royal r[SEQ_SPLITTER]ealm;
The revenue whereof shall furnish us
For our[SEQ_SPLITTER] affairs in hand: if that come short,
Our substitu[SEQ_SPLITTER]tes at home shall have blank charters;
Whereto, wh[SEQ_SPLITTER]en they shall know what men are rich,
They shall s[SEQ_SPLITTER]ubscribe them for large sums of gold
And send them[SEQ_SPLITTER] after to supply our wants;
For we will make for I[SEQ_SPLITTER]reland presently.
Bushy, what news?

BUSHY:
Old Jo[SEQ_SPLITTER]hn of Gaunt is grievous sick, my lord,
Suddenly ta[SEQ_SPLITTER]ken; and hath sent post haste
To entreat your maje[SEQ_SPLITTER]sty to visit him.

KING RICHARD II:
Where lies he?[SEQ_SPLITTER]

BUSHY:
At Ely House.

KING RICHARD II:
Now put i[SEQ_SPLITTER]t, God, in the physician's mind
To help him to his[SEQ_SPLITTER] grave immediately!
The lining of his coffers shal[SEQ_SPLITTER]l make coats
To deck our soldiers for these Irish [SEQ_SPLITTER]wars.
Come, gentlemen, let's all go visit him:
Pra[SEQ_SPLITTER]y God we may make haste, and come too late!

All:
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Amen.

JOHN OF GAUNT:
Will the king come, that I m[SEQ_SPLITTER]ay breathe my last
In wholesome counsel to his uns[SEQ_SPLITTER]taid youth?

DUKE OF YORK:
Vex not yourself, nor s[SEQ_SPLITTER]trive not with your breath;
For all in vain comes [SEQ_SPLITTER]counsel to his ear.

JOHN OF GAUNT:
O, but they sa[SEQ_SPLITTER]y the tongues of dying men
Enforce attention like [SEQ_SPLITTER]deep harmony:
Where words are scarce, they are sel[SEQ_SPLITTER]dom spent in vain,
For they breathe truth that bre[SEQ_SPLITTER]athe their words in pain.
He that no more must say[SEQ_SPLITTER] is listen'd more
Than they whom youth and ease ha[SEQ_SPLITTER]ve taught to glose;
More are men's ends mark'd tha[SEQ_SPLITTER]n their lives before:
The setting sun, and music a[SEQ_SPLITTER]t the close,
As the last taste of sweets, is sweet[SEQ_SPLITTER]est last,
Writ in remembrance more than things lon[SEQ_SPLITTER]g past:
Though Richard my life's counsel would not[SEQ_SPLITTER] hear,
My death's sad tale may yet undeaf his ear.[SEQ_SPLITTER]

DUKE OF YORK:
No; it is stopp'd with other flatt[SEQ_SPLITTER]ering sounds,
As praises, of whose taste the wise [SEQ_SPLITTER]are fond,
Lascivious metres, to whose venom sound
[SEQ_SPLITTER]The open ear of youth doth always listen;
Report o[SEQ_SPLITTER]f fashions in proud Italy,
Whose manners still our[SEQ_SPLITTER] tardy apish nation
Limps after in base imitation.[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Where doth the world thrust forth a vanity--
So i[SEQ_SPLITTER]t be new, there's no respect how vile--
That is no[SEQ_SPLITTER]t quickly buzzed into his ears?
Then all too late [SEQ_SPLITTER]comes counsel to be heard,
Where will doth mutiny [SEQ_SPLITTER]with wit's regard.
Direct not him whose way himsel[SEQ_SPLITTER]f will choose:
'Tis breath thou lack'st, and that [SEQ_SPLITTER]breath wilt thou lose.

JOHN OF GAUNT:
Methinks I [SEQ_SPLITTER]am a prophet new inspired
And thus expiring do for[SEQ_SPLITTER]etell of him:
His rash fierce blaze of riot cannot[SEQ_SPLITTER] last,
For violent fires soon burn out themselves;[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Small showers last long, but sudden storms are sh[SEQ_SPLITTER]ort;
He tires betimes that spurs too fast betimes;[SEQ_SPLITTER]
With eager feeding food doth choke the feeder:
Li[SEQ_SPLITTER]ght vanity, insatiate cormorant,
Consuming means, [SEQ_SPLITTER]soon preys upon itself.
This royal throne of kings[SEQ_SPLITTER], this scepter'd isle,
This earth of majesty, this[SEQ_SPLITTER] seat of Mars,
This other Eden, demi-paradise,
Thi[SEQ_SPLITTER]s fortress built by Nature for herself
Against inf[SEQ_SPLITTER]ection and the hand of war,
This happy breed of me[SEQ_SPLITTER]n, this little world,
This precious stone set in t[SEQ_SPLITTER]he silver sea,
Which serves it in the office of a [SEQ_SPLITTER]wall,
Or as a moat defensive to a house,
Against t[SEQ_SPLITTER]he envy of less happier lands,
This blessed plot, [SEQ_SPLITTER]this earth, this realm, this England,
This nurse, [SEQ_SPLITTER]this teeming womb of royal kings,
Fear'd by their [SEQ_SPLITTER]breed and famous by their birth,
Renowned for thei[SEQ_SPLITTER]r deeds as far from home,
For Christian service an[SEQ_SPLITTER]d true chivalry,
As is the sepulchre in stubborn J[SEQ_SPLITTER]ewry,
Of the world's ransom, blessed Mary's Son,
T[SEQ_SPLITTER]his land of such dear souls, this dear dear land,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Dear for her reputation through the world,
Is now [SEQ_SPLITTER]leased out, I die pronouncing it,
Like to a teneme[SEQ_SPLITTER]nt or pelting farm:
England, bound in with the tri[SEQ_SPLITTER]umphant sea
Whose rocky shore beats back the envio[SEQ_SPLITTER]us siege
Of watery Neptune, is now bound in with s[SEQ_SPLITTER]hame,
With inky blots and rotten parchment bonds:
[SEQ_SPLITTER]That England, that was wont to conquer others,
Hat[SEQ_SPLITTER]h made a shameful conquest of itself.
Ah, would th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e scandal vanish with my life,
How happy then were[SEQ_SPLITTER] my ensuing death!

DUKE OF YORK:
The king is come[SEQ_SPLITTER]: deal mildly with his youth;
For young hot colts [SEQ_SPLITTER]being raged do rage the more.

QUEEN:
How fares ou[SEQ_SPLITTER]r noble uncle, Lancaster?

KING RICHARD II:
What c[SEQ_SPLITTER]omfort, man? how is't with aged Gaunt?

JOHN OF GA[SEQ_SPLITTER]UNT:
O how that name befits my composition!
Old Ga[SEQ_SPLITTER]unt indeed, and gaunt in being old:
Within me grie[SEQ_SPLITTER]f hath kept a tedious fast;
And who abstains from [SEQ_SPLITTER]meat that is not gaunt?
For sleeping England long [SEQ_SPLITTER]time have I watch'd;
Watching breeds leanness, lea[SEQ_SPLITTER]nness is all gaunt:
The pleasure that some fathers[SEQ_SPLITTER] feed upon,
Is my strict fast; I mean, my children[SEQ_SPLITTER]'s looks;
And therein fasting, hast thou made me g[SEQ_SPLITTER]aunt:
Gaunt am I for the grave, gaunt as a grave,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Whose hollow womb inherits nought but bones.

KING[SEQ_SPLITTER] RICHARD II:
Can sick men play so nicely with thei[SEQ_SPLITTER]r names?

JOHN OF GAUNT:
No, misery makes sport to[SEQ_SPLITTER] mock itself:
Since thou dost seek to kill my name[SEQ_SPLITTER] in me,
I mock my name, great king, to flatter the[SEQ_SPLITTER]e.

KING RICHARD II:
Should dying men flatter with[SEQ_SPLITTER] those that live?

JOHN OF GAUNT:
No, no, men livi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ng flatter those that die.

KING RICHARD II:
Thou,[SEQ_SPLITTER] now a-dying, say'st thou flatterest me.

JOHN OF [SEQ_SPLITTER]GAUNT:
O, no! thou diest, though I the sicker be.
[SEQ_SPLITTER]
KING RICHARD II:
I am in health, I breathe, and s[SEQ_SPLITTER]ee thee ill.

JOHN OF GAUNT:
Now He that made me k[SEQ_SPLITTER]nows I see thee ill;
Ill in myself to see, and in [SEQ_SPLITTER]thee seeing ill.
Thy death-bed is no lesser than t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hy land
Wherein thou liest in reputation sick;
And[SEQ_SPLITTER] thou, too careless patient as thou art,
Commit'st[SEQ_SPLITTER] thy anointed body to the cure
Of those physicians[SEQ_SPLITTER] that first wounded thee:
A thousand flatterers si[SEQ_SPLITTER]t within thy crown,
Whose compass is no bigger tha[SEQ_SPLITTER]n thy head;
And yet, incaged in so small a verge,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]The waste is no whit lesser than thy land.
O, had [SEQ_SPLITTER]thy grandsire with a prophet's eye
Seen how his so[SEQ_SPLITTER]n's son should destroy his sons,
From forth thy re[SEQ_SPLITTER]ach he would have laid thy shame,
Deposing thee be[SEQ_SPLITTER]fore thou wert possess'd,
Which art possess'd now [SEQ_SPLITTER]to depose thyself.
Why, cousin, wert thou regent o[SEQ_SPLITTER]f the world,
It were a shame to let this land by l[SEQ_SPLITTER]ease;
But for thy world enjoying but this land,
Is[SEQ_SPLITTER] it not more than shame to shame it so?
Landlord o[SEQ_SPLITTER]f England art thou now, not king:
Thy state of law[SEQ_SPLITTER] is bondslave to the law; And thou--

KING RICHARD[SEQ_SPLITTER] II:
A lunatic lean-witted fool,
Presuming on an a[SEQ_SPLITTER]gue's privilege,
Darest with thy frozen admonition[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Make pale our cheek, chasing the royal blood
With[SEQ_SPLITTER] fury from his native residence.
Now, by my seat's[SEQ_SPLITTER] right royal majesty,
Wert thou not brother to gre[SEQ_SPLITTER]at Edward's son,
This tongue that runs so roundly [SEQ_SPLITTER]in thy head
Should run thy head from thy unreveren[SEQ_SPLITTER]t shoulders.

For that I was his father Edw[SEQ_SPLITTER]ard's son;
That blood already, like the pelican,
H[SEQ_SPLITTER]ast thou tapp'd out and drunkenly caroused:
My bro[SEQ_SPLITTER]ther Gloucester, plain well-meaning soul,
Whom fai[SEQ_SPLITTER]r befal in heaven 'mongst happy souls!
May be a pr[SEQ_SPLITTER]ecedent and witness good
That thou respect'st not [SEQ_SPLITTER]spilling Edward's blood:
Join with the present sic[SEQ_SPLITTER]kness that I have;
And thy unkindness be like croo[SEQ_SPLITTER]ked age,
To crop at once a too long wither'd flowe[SEQ_SPLITTER]r.
Live in thy shame, but die not shame with thee![SEQ_SPLITTER]
These words hereafter thy tormentors be!
Convey m[SEQ_SPLITTER]e to my bed, then to my grave:
Love they to live t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hat love and honour have.

KING RICHARD II:
And le[SEQ_SPLITTER]t them die that age and sullens have;
For both has[SEQ_SPLITTER]t thou, and both become the grave.

As Harry Duke of Herefo[SEQ_SPLITTER]rd, were he here.

As theirs, so m[SEQ_SPLITTER]ine; and all be as it is.

Though death be poor, it ends a mo[SEQ_SPLITTER]rtal woe.

His time is spent, our pil[SEQ_SPLITTER]grimage must be.

We must supplant those rough rug-headed k[SEQ_SPLITTER]erns,

And for these [SEQ_SPLITTER]great affairs do ask some charge,

Whereof our uncle Gaunt did stand [SEQ_SPLITTER]possess'd.

DUKE OF YORK:

Shall tender duty make me suffer[SEQ_SPLITTER] wrong?
Not Gloucester's death, nor Hereford's ban[SEQ_SPLITTER]ishment

Ab[SEQ_SPLITTER]out his marriage, nor my own disgrace,
Have ever m[SEQ_SPLITTER]ade me sour my patient cheek,

I am the last of noble Edw[SEQ_SPLITTER]ard's sons,
Of whom thy father, Prince of Wales, w[SEQ_SPLITTER]as first:
In war was never lion raged more fierce,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
In peace was never gentle lamb more mild,
Than wa[SEQ_SPLITTER]s that young and princely gentleman.

Accomplish'd with th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e number of thy hours;

And not against his friends; h[SEQ_SPLITTER]is noble hand
Did will what he did spend and spent[SEQ_SPLITTER] not that
Which his triumphant father's hand had w[SEQ_SPLITTER]on;
His hands were guilty of no kindred blood,
But[SEQ_SPLITTER] bloody with the enemies of his kin.
O Richard! Yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]rk is too far gone with grief,
Or else he never wo[SEQ_SPLITTER]uld compare between.

KING RICHARD II:

O my liege,

Is not Gaunt dead, and doth [SEQ_SPLITTER]not Hereford live?

Be not thyself; for how art thou a [SEQ_SPLITTER]king
But by fair sequence and succession?
Now, afo[SEQ_SPLITTER]re God--God forbid I say true!--
If you do wrongfu[SEQ_SPLITTER]lly seize Hereford's rights,

NO[SEQ_SPLITTER]RTHUMBERLAND:

LORD ROSS:
And living too; for now his so[SEQ_SPLITTER]n is duke.

LORD WILLOUGHBY:
Barely in title, not [SEQ_SPLITTER]in revenue.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Richly in both, if ju[SEQ_SPLITTER]stice had her right.

LORD ROSS:
My heart is great[SEQ_SPLITTER]; but it must break with silence,
Ere't be disburd[SEQ_SPLITTER]en'd with a liberal tongue.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Nay, [SEQ_SPLITTER]speak thy mind; and let him ne'er speak more
That [SEQ_SPLITTER]speaks thy words again to do thee harm!

Tends that thou wouldst speak to the Duke [SEQ_SPLITTER]of Hereford?
If it be so, out with it boldly, man;[SEQ_SPLITTER]

L[SEQ_SPLITTER]ORD ROSS:
No good at all that I can do for him;
Un[SEQ_SPLITTER]less you call it good to pity him,
Bereft and geld[SEQ_SPLITTER]ed of his patrimony.

In him, a roy[SEQ_SPLITTER]al prince, and many moe
Of noble blood in this dec[SEQ_SPLITTER]lining land.
The king is not himself, but basely l[SEQ_SPLITTER]ed
By flatterers; and what they will inform,
Merel[SEQ_SPLITTER]y in hate, 'gainst any of us all,
That will the ki[SEQ_SPLITTER]ng severely prosecute
'Gainst us, our lives, our c[SEQ_SPLITTER]hildren, and our heirs.

LORD ROSS:
The commons ha[SEQ_SPLITTER]th he pill'd with grievous taxes,
And quite lost t[SEQ_SPLITTER]heir hearts: the nobles hath he fined
For ancient [SEQ_SPLITTER]quarrels, and quite lost their hearts.

LORD WILLO[SEQ_SPLITTER]UGHBY:
And daily new exactions are devised,
As bla[SEQ_SPLITTER]nks, benevolences, and I wot not what:
But what, o[SEQ_SPLITTER]' God's name, doth become of this?

NORTHUMBERLAND[SEQ_SPLITTER]:
Wars have not wasted it, for warr'd he hath not,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
But basely yielded upon compromise
That which his[SEQ_SPLITTER] noble ancestors achieved with blows:
More hath he[SEQ_SPLITTER] spent in peace than they in wars.

LORD ROSS:
The[SEQ_SPLITTER] Earl of Wiltshire hath the realm in farm.

LORD W[SEQ_SPLITTER]ILLOUGHBY:
The king's grown bankrupt, like a broke[SEQ_SPLITTER]n man.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Reproach and dissolution h[SEQ_SPLITTER]angeth over him.

LORD ROSS:
He hath not money for[SEQ_SPLITTER] these Irish wars,
His burthenous taxations notwit[SEQ_SPLITTER]hstanding,

But, lords, we hear this fearful tempest[SEQ_SPLITTER] sing,
Yet see no shelter to avoid the storm;
We s[SEQ_SPLITTER]ee the wind sit sore upon our sails,
And yet we st[SEQ_SPLITTER]rike not, but securely perish.

LORD ROSS:
We see [SEQ_SPLITTER]the very wreck that we must suffer;
And unavoided [SEQ_SPLITTER]is the danger now,

NORTHUMBERLAND:

NORTHUMBERLAND:

In Brittany, received[SEQ_SPLITTER] intelligence
That Harry Duke of Hereford, Rainold[SEQ_SPLITTER] Lord Cobham,
That late broke from the Duke of Exe[SEQ_SPLITTER]ter,
His brother, Archbishop late of Canterbury,
S[SEQ_SPLITTER]ir Thomas Erpingham, Sir John Ramston,

All[SEQ_SPLITTER] these well furnish'd by the Duke of Bretagne
With[SEQ_SPLITTER] eight tall ships, three thousand men of war,
Are [SEQ_SPLITTER]making hither with all due expedience
And shortly [SEQ_SPLITTER]mean to touch our northern shore:
Perhaps they had[SEQ_SPLITTER] ere this, but that they stay
The first departing [SEQ_SPLITTER]of the king for Ireland.
If then we shall shake of[SEQ_SPLITTER]f our slavish yoke,
Imp out our drooping country's[SEQ_SPLITTER] broken wing,
Redeem from broking pawn the blemish[SEQ_SPLITTER]'d crown,
Wipe off the dust that hides our sceptre[SEQ_SPLITTER]'s gilt
And make high majesty look like itself,
Aw[SEQ_SPLITTER]ay with me in post to Ravenspurgh;
But if you fain[SEQ_SPLITTER]t, as fearing to do so,
Stay and be secret, and my[SEQ_SPLITTER]self will go.

LORD ROSS:
To horse, to horse! urge[SEQ_SPLITTER] doubts to them that fear.

LORD WILLOUGHBY:
Hold [SEQ_SPLITTER]out my horse, and I will first be there.

BUSHY:
M[SEQ_SPLITTER]adam, your majesty is too much sad:
You promised, [SEQ_SPLITTER]when you parted with the king,
To lay aside life-h[SEQ_SPLITTER]arming heaviness
And entertain a cheerful disposit[SEQ_SPLITTER]ion.

QUEEN:
To please the king I did; to please m[SEQ_SPLITTER]yself
I cannot do it; yet I know no cause
Why I sh[SEQ_SPLITTER]ould welcome such a guest as grief,
Save bidding f[SEQ_SPLITTER]arewell to so sweet a guest
As my sweet Richard: y[SEQ_SPLITTER]et again, methinks,
Some unborn sorrow, ripe in fo[SEQ_SPLITTER]rtune's womb,
Is coming towards me, and my inward [SEQ_SPLITTER]soul
With nothing trembles: at some thing it griev[SEQ_SPLITTER]es,
More than with parting from my lord the king.
[SEQ_SPLITTER]
BUSHY:
Each substance of a grief hath twenty shad[SEQ_SPLITTER]ows,
Which shows like grief itself, but is not so;[SEQ_SPLITTER]
For sorrow's eye, glazed with blinding tears,
Div[SEQ_SPLITTER]ides one thing entire to many objects;
Like perspe[SEQ_SPLITTER]ctives, which rightly gazed upon
Show nothing but [SEQ_SPLITTER]confusion, eyed awry
Distinguish form: so your swe[SEQ_SPLITTER]et majesty,
Looking awry upon your lord's departur[SEQ_SPLITTER]e,
Find shapes of grief, more than himself, to wai[SEQ_SPLITTER]l;
Which, look'd on as it is, is nought but shadow[SEQ_SPLITTER]s
Of what it is not. Then, thrice-gracious queen,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]More than your lord's departure weep not: more's n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ot seen;
Or if it be, 'tis with false sorrow's eye[SEQ_SPLITTER],
Which for things true weeps things imaginary.

Q[SEQ_SPLITTER]UEEN:
It may be so; but yet my inward soul
Persuad[SEQ_SPLITTER]es me it is otherwise: howe'er it be,
I cannot but[SEQ_SPLITTER] be sad; so heavy sad
As, though on thinking on no[SEQ_SPLITTER] thought I think,
Makes me with heavy nothing fain[SEQ_SPLITTER]t and shrink.

BUSHY:
'Tis nothing but conceit, my[SEQ_SPLITTER] gracious lady.

QUEEN:
'Tis nothing less: conceit[SEQ_SPLITTER] is still derived
From some forefather grief; mine[SEQ_SPLITTER] is not so,
For nothing had begot my something gri[SEQ_SPLITTER]ef;
Or something hath the nothing that I grieve:
'[SEQ_SPLITTER]Tis in reversion that I do possess;
But what it is[SEQ_SPLITTER], that is not yet known; what
I cannot name; 'tis [SEQ_SPLITTER]nameless woe, I wot.

GREEN:

I hope the king is not [SEQ_SPLITTER]yet shipp'd for Ireland.

QUEEN:

For his designs crave h[SEQ_SPLITTER]aste, his haste good hope:
Then wherefore dost tho[SEQ_SPLITTER]u hope he is not shipp'd?

GREEN:
That he, our hop[SEQ_SPLITTER]e, might have retired his power,

Who strongly hath set foot[SEQ_SPLITTER]ing in this land:
The banish'd Bolingbroke repeals[SEQ_SPLITTER] himself,
And with uplifted arms is safe arrived
A[SEQ_SPLITTER]t Ravenspurgh.

QUEEN:

The Lord Northumberland, his son young Henry Per[SEQ_SPLITTER]cy,

W[SEQ_SPLITTER]ith all their powerful friends, are fled to him.

Have woe to woe, sorrow[SEQ_SPLITTER] to sorrow join'd.

BUSHY:

QU[SEQ_SPLITTER]EEN:

I will despair, and be a[SEQ_SPLITTER]t enmity
With cozening hope: he is a flatterer,
A [SEQ_SPLITTER]parasite, a keeper back of death,
Who gently would[SEQ_SPLITTER] dissolve the bands of life,
Which false hope ling[SEQ_SPLITTER]ers in extremity.

Comfort's in heaven; and we are on the earth,
Wh[SEQ_SPLITTER]ere nothing lives but crosses, cares and grief.
Yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]ur husband, he is gone to save far off,
Whilst oth[SEQ_SPLITTER]ers come to make him lose at home:
Here am I left [SEQ_SPLITTER]to underprop his land,

Now shall he try his friends that fla[SEQ_SPLITTER]tter'd him.

And eve[SEQ_SPLITTER]ry thing is left at six and seven.

By so much fills their hearts[SEQ_SPLITTER] with deadly hate.

'Tis thought the king is dead; we will not [SEQ_SPLITTER]stay.
The bay-trees in our country are all wither'[SEQ_SPLITTER]d
And meteors fright the fixed stars of heaven;
Th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e pale-faced moon looks bloody on the earth
And le[SEQ_SPLITTER]an-look'd prophets whisper fearful change;
Rich me[SEQ_SPLITTER]n look sad and ruffians dance and leap,
The one in[SEQ_SPLITTER] fear to lose what they enjoy,
The other to enjoy [SEQ_SPLITTER]by rage and war:
These signs forerun the death or [SEQ_SPLITTER]fall of kings.

As well assured Richard their king is dea[SEQ_SPLITTER]d.

And crossly to thy good all f[SEQ_SPLITTER]ortune goes.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:

Since presently your souls must part your bodies-[SEQ_SPLITTER]-

Eating the bitte[SEQ_SPLITTER]r bread of banishment;
Whilst you have fed upon my[SEQ_SPLITTER] signories,
Dispark'd my parks and fell'd my fores[SEQ_SPLITTER]t woods,
From my own windows torn my household coa[SEQ_SPLITTER]t,
Razed out my imprese, leaving me no sign,
Save [SEQ_SPLITTER]men's opinions and my living blood,
To show the wo[SEQ_SPLITTER]rld I am a gentleman.
This and much more, much mor[SEQ_SPLITTER]e than twice all this,
Condemns you to the death. [SEQ_SPLITTER]See them deliver'd over
To execution and the hand [SEQ_SPLITTER]of death.

BUSHY:
More welcome is the stroke of de[SEQ_SPLITTER]ath to me
Than Bolingbroke to England. Lords, fare[SEQ_SPLITTER]well.

My comfort is that heaven will take [SEQ_SPLITTER]our souls
And plague injustice with the pains of h[SEQ_SPLITTER]ell.

T[SEQ_SPLITTER]ake special care my greetings be deliver'd.

KING RICHARD II:
Bark[SEQ_SPLITTER]loughly castle call they this at hand?

K[SEQ_SPLITTER]ING RICHARD II:
Needs must I like it well: I weep [SEQ_SPLITTER]for joy
To stand upon my kingdom once again.
Dear [SEQ_SPLITTER]earth, I do salute thee with my hand,
Though rebel[SEQ_SPLITTER]s wound thee with their horses' hoofs:
As a long-p[SEQ_SPLITTER]arted mother with her child
Plays fondly with her [SEQ_SPLITTER]tears and smiles in meeting,

And do thee favours with [SEQ_SPLITTER]my royal hands.

The means that [SEQ_SPLITTER]heaven yields must be embraced,
And not neglected;[SEQ_SPLITTER] else, if heaven would,

Stand bare and naked[SEQ_SPLITTER], trembling at themselves?

Who all this while hath re[SEQ_SPLITTER]vell'd in the night

An[SEQ_SPLITTER]d nothing can we call our own but death

That rounds the mortal temples of a king
Keeps De[SEQ_SPLITTER]ath his court and there the antic sits,

Fear and be slain; no w[SEQ_SPLITTER]orse can come to fight:
And fight and die is death[SEQ_SPLITTER] destroying death;
Where fearing dying pays death [SEQ_SPLITTER]servile breath.

O God, O God! tha[SEQ_SPLITTER]t e'er this tongue of mine,
That laid the sentence[SEQ_SPLITTER] of dread banishment
On yon proud man, should take[SEQ_SPLITTER] it off again
With words of sooth! O that I were a[SEQ_SPLITTER]s great
As is my grief, or lesser than my name!
Or[SEQ_SPLITTER] that I could forget what I have been,
Or not reme[SEQ_SPLITTER]mber what I must be now!
Swell'st thou, proud hear[SEQ_SPLITTER]t? I'll give thee scope to beat,
Since foes have s[SEQ_SPLITTER]cope to beat both thee and me.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
N[SEQ_SPLITTER]orthumberland comes back from Bolingbroke.

KING R[SEQ_SPLITTER]ICHARD II:
What must the king do now? must he subm[SEQ_SPLITTER]it?
The king shall do it: must he be deposed?
The [SEQ_SPLITTER]king shall be contented: must he lose
The name of [SEQ_SPLITTER]king? o' God's name, let it go:
I'll give my jewel[SEQ_SPLITTER]s for a set of beads,
My gorgeous palace for a her[SEQ_SPLITTER]mitage,
My gay apparel for an almsman's gown,
My f[SEQ_SPLITTER]igured goblets for a dish of wood,
My sceptre for [SEQ_SPLITTER]a palmer's walking staff,
My subjects for a pair o[SEQ_SPLITTER]f carved saints
And my large kingdom for a little [SEQ_SPLITTER]grave,
A little little grave, an obscure grave;
Or[SEQ_SPLITTER] I'll be buried in the king's highway,
Some way of[SEQ_SPLITTER] common trade, where subjects' feet
May hourly tra[SEQ_SPLITTER]mple on their sovereign's head;
For on my heart th[SEQ_SPLITTER]ey tread now whilst I live;
And buried once, why n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ot upon my head?

We'll make foul weather with despi[SEQ_SPLITTER]sed tears;
Our sighs and they shall lodge the summ[SEQ_SPLITTER]er corn,
And make a dearth in this revolting land.[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Or shall we play the wantons with our woes,
And m[SEQ_SPLITTER]ake some pretty match with shedding tears?
As thus[SEQ_SPLITTER], to drop them still upon one place,
Till they hav[SEQ_SPLITTER]e fretted us a pair of graves
Within the earth; an[SEQ_SPLITTER]d, therein laid,--there lies
Two kinsmen digg'd th[SEQ_SPLITTER]eir graves with weeping eyes.
Would not this ill d[SEQ_SPLITTER]o well? Well, well, I see
I talk but idly, and you[SEQ_SPLITTER] laugh at me.

What says King Bolingbroke? will his majes[SEQ_SPLITTER]ty
Give Richard leave to live till Richard die?
Yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]u make a leg, and Bolingbroke says ay.

QUEEN:

And what I want it boots not to complai[SEQ_SPLITTER]n.

My wretchedne[SEQ_SPLITTER]ss unto a row of pins,

Against a change; woe is forerun[SEQ_SPLITTER] with woe.

Gardener:

All must be even in our gover[SEQ_SPLITTER]nment.

The [SEQ_SPLITTER]noisome weeds, which without profit suck
The soil'[SEQ_SPLITTER]s fertility from wholesome flowers.

Servant:

I mean the Ea[SEQ_SPLITTER]rl of Wiltshire, Bushy, Green.

H[SEQ_SPLITTER]ath seized the wasteful king. O, what pity is it

Do wound the ba[SEQ_SPLITTER]rk, the skin of our fruit-trees,

With too much riches it co[SEQ_SPLITTER]nfound itself:

They might have lived to bear and he to tast[SEQ_SPLITTER]e

Which waste of id[SEQ_SPLITTER]le hours hath quite thrown down.

To Henry Bolingbroke[SEQ_SPLITTER].

KING RICHARD II:
Give me the crown. Here, cousi[SEQ_SPLITTER]n, seize the crown;
Here cousin:
On this side my h[SEQ_SPLITTER]and, and on that side yours.
Now is this golden cr[SEQ_SPLITTER]own like a deep well
That owes two buckets, fillin[SEQ_SPLITTER]g one another,
The emptier ever dancing in the air[SEQ_SPLITTER],
The other down, unseen and full of water:
That b[SEQ_SPLITTER]ucket down and full of tears am I,
Drinking my gri[SEQ_SPLITTER]efs, whilst you mount up on high.

HENRY BOLINGBRO[SEQ_SPLITTER]KE:
I thought you had been willing to resign.

KIN[SEQ_SPLITTER]G RICHARD II:
My crown I am; but still my griefs a[SEQ_SPLITTER]re mine:
You may my glories and my state depose,
B[SEQ_SPLITTER]ut not my griefs; still am I king of those.

HENRY[SEQ_SPLITTER] BOLINGBROKE:
Part of your cares you give me with [SEQ_SPLITTER]your crown.

KING RICHARD II:
Your cares set up do[SEQ_SPLITTER] not pluck my cares down.
My care is loss of care,[SEQ_SPLITTER] by old care done;
Your care is gain of care, by n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ew care won:
The cares I give I have, though given[SEQ_SPLITTER] away;
They tend the crown, yet still with me they[SEQ_SPLITTER] stay.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Are you contented to re[SEQ_SPLITTER]sign the crown?

KING RICHARD II:
Ay, no; no, ay; [SEQ_SPLITTER]for I must nothing be;
Therefore no no, for I resi[SEQ_SPLITTER]gn to thee.
Now mark me, how I will undo myself;
I[SEQ_SPLITTER] give this heavy weight from off my head
And this [SEQ_SPLITTER]unwieldy sceptre from my hand,
The pride of kingly[SEQ_SPLITTER] sway from out my heart;
With mine own tears I was[SEQ_SPLITTER]h away my balm,
With mine own hands I give away my[SEQ_SPLITTER] crown,
With mine own tongue deny my sacred state,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
With mine own breath release all duty's rites:
Al[SEQ_SPLITTER]l pomp and majesty I do forswear;
My manors, rents[SEQ_SPLITTER], revenues I forego;
My acts, decrees, and statute[SEQ_SPLITTER]s I deny:
God pardon all oaths that are broke to m[SEQ_SPLITTER]e!
God keep all vows unbroke that swear to thee!
M[SEQ_SPLITTER]ake me, that nothing have, with nothing grieved,
A[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd thou with all pleased, that hast all achieved!
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Long mayst thou live in Richard's seat to sit,
And[SEQ_SPLITTER] soon lie Richard in an earthly pit!
God save King[SEQ_SPLITTER] Harry, unking'd Richard says,
And send him many y[SEQ_SPLITTER]ears of sunshine days!
What more remains?

NORTHUM[SEQ_SPLITTER]BERLAND:
No more, but that you read
These accusati[SEQ_SPLITTER]ons and these grievous crimes
Committed by your pe[SEQ_SPLITTER]rson and your followers
Against the state and prof[SEQ_SPLITTER]it of this land;
That, by confessing them, the sou[SEQ_SPLITTER]ls of men
May deem that you are worthily deposed.
[SEQ_SPLITTER]
KING RICHARD II:
Must I do so? and must I ravel o[SEQ_SPLITTER]ut
My weaved-up folly? Gentle Northumberland,
If t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hy offences were upon record,
Would it not shame t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hee in so fair a troop
To read a lecture of them? [SEQ_SPLITTER]If thou wouldst,
There shouldst thou find one hein[SEQ_SPLITTER]ous article,
Containing the deposing of a king
And[SEQ_SPLITTER] cracking the strong warrant of an oath,
Mark'd wi[SEQ_SPLITTER]th a blot, damn'd in the book of heaven:
Nay, all [SEQ_SPLITTER]of you that stand and look upon,
Whilst that my wr[SEQ_SPLITTER]etchedness doth bait myself,
Though some of you wi[SEQ_SPLITTER]th Pilate wash your hands
Showing an outward pity;[SEQ_SPLITTER] yet you Pilates
Have here deliver'd me to my sour[SEQ_SPLITTER] cross,
And water cannot wash away your sin.

NORT[SEQ_SPLITTER]HUMBERLAND:
My lord, dispatch; read o'er these art[SEQ_SPLITTER]icles.

KING RICHARD II:
Mine eyes are full of tea[SEQ_SPLITTER]rs, I cannot see:
And yet salt water blinds them n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ot so much
But they can see a sort of traitors her[SEQ_SPLITTER]e.
Nay, if I turn mine eyes upon myself,
I find my[SEQ_SPLITTER]self a traitor with the rest;
For I have given her[SEQ_SPLITTER]e my soul's consent
To undeck the pompous body of [SEQ_SPLITTER]a king;
Made glory base and sovereignty a slave,
P[SEQ_SPLITTER]roud majesty a subject, state a peasant.

NORTHUMB[SEQ_SPLITTER]ERLAND:
My lord,--

KING RICHARD II:
No lord of th[SEQ_SPLITTER]ine, thou haught insulting man,
Nor no man's lord;[SEQ_SPLITTER] I have no name, no title,
No, not that name was g[SEQ_SPLITTER]iven me at the font,
But 'tis usurp'd: alack the h[SEQ_SPLITTER]eavy day,
That I have worn so many winters out,
An[SEQ_SPLITTER]d know not now what name to call myself!
O that I [SEQ_SPLITTER]were a mockery king of snow,
Standing before the s[SEQ_SPLITTER]un of Bolingbroke,
To melt myself away in water-dr[SEQ_SPLITTER]ops!
Good king, great king, and yet not greatly go[SEQ_SPLITTER]od,
An if my word be sterling yet in England,
Let [SEQ_SPLITTER]it command a mirror hither straight,
That it may s[SEQ_SPLITTER]how me what a face I have,
Since it is bankrupt of[SEQ_SPLITTER] his majesty.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Go some of you a[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd fetch a looking-glass.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Read o'[SEQ_SPLITTER]er this paper while the glass doth come.

KING RIC[SEQ_SPLITTER]HARD II:
Fiend, thou torment'st me ere I come to h[SEQ_SPLITTER]ell!

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Urge it no more, my Lord [SEQ_SPLITTER]Northumberland.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
The commons will [SEQ_SPLITTER]not then be satisfied.

KING RICHARD II:
They shal[SEQ_SPLITTER]l be satisfied: I'll read enough,
When I do see th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e very book indeed
Where all my sins are writ, and[SEQ_SPLITTER] that's myself.
Give me the glass, and therein wil[SEQ_SPLITTER]l I read.
No deeper wrinkles yet? hath sorrow stru[SEQ_SPLITTER]ck
So many blows upon this face of mine,
And made [SEQ_SPLITTER]no deeper wounds? O flattering glass,
Like to my f[SEQ_SPLITTER]ollowers in prosperity,
Thou dost beguile me! Was [SEQ_SPLITTER]this face the face
That every day under his househ[SEQ_SPLITTER]old roof
Did keep ten thousand men? was this the f[SEQ_SPLITTER]ace
That, like the sun, did make beholders wink?
W[SEQ_SPLITTER]as this the face that faced so many follies,
And w[SEQ_SPLITTER]as at last out-faced by Bolingbroke?
A brittle glo[SEQ_SPLITTER]ry shineth in this face:
As brittle as the glory i[SEQ_SPLITTER]s the face;
For there it is, crack'd in a hundred [SEQ_SPLITTER]shivers.
Mark, silent king, the moral of this spor[SEQ_SPLITTER]t,
How soon my sorrow hath destroy'd my face.

HEN[SEQ_SPLITTER]RY BOLINGBROKE:
The shadow of your sorrow hath des[SEQ_SPLITTER]troy'd
The shadow or your face.

KING RICHARD II:
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Say that again.
The shadow of my sorrow! ha! let's[SEQ_SPLITTER] see:
'Tis very true, my grief lies all within;
An[SEQ_SPLITTER]d these external manners of laments
Are merely sha[SEQ_SPLITTER]dows to the unseen grief
That swells with silence [SEQ_SPLITTER]in the tortured soul;
There lies the substance: an[SEQ_SPLITTER]d I thank thee, king,
For thy great bounty, that n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ot only givest
Me cause to wail but teachest me th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e way
How to lament the cause. I'll beg one boon,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]And then be gone and trouble you no more.
Shall I [SEQ_SPLITTER]obtain it?

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Name it, fair cousi[SEQ_SPLITTER]n.

KING RICHARD II:
'Fair cousin'? I am greater t[SEQ_SPLITTER]han a king:
For when I was a king, my flatterers
W[SEQ_SPLITTER]ere then but subjects; being now a subject,
I have[SEQ_SPLITTER] a king here to my flatterer.
Being so great, I ha[SEQ_SPLITTER]ve no need to beg.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Yet ask.

K[SEQ_SPLITTER]ING RICHARD II:
And shall I have?

HENRY BOLINGBRO[SEQ_SPLITTER]KE:
You shall.

KING RICHARD II:
Then give me leav[SEQ_SPLITTER]e to go.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Whither?

KING RICHAR[SEQ_SPLITTER]D II:
Whither you will, so I were from your sights[SEQ_SPLITTER].

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Go, some of you convey him t[SEQ_SPLITTER]o the Tower.

KING RICHARD II:
O, good! convey? co[SEQ_SPLITTER]nveyers are you all,
That rise thus nimbly by a tr[SEQ_SPLITTER]ue king's fall.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
On Wednesday n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ext we solemnly set down
Our coronation: lords, pr[SEQ_SPLITTER]epare yourselves.

A woeful pageant have we[SEQ_SPLITTER] here beheld.

BISHOP OF CARLISLE:
The woe's to co[SEQ_SPLITTER]me; the children yet unborn.
Shall feel this day a[SEQ_SPLITTER]s sharp to them as thorn.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
You ho[SEQ_SPLITTER]ly clergymen, is there no plot
To rid the realm of[SEQ_SPLITTER] this pernicious blot?

Abbot:
My lord,
Before I f[SEQ_SPLITTER]reely speak my mind herein,
You shall not only tak[SEQ_SPLITTER]e the sacrament
To bury mine intents, but also to [SEQ_SPLITTER]effect
Whatever I shall happen to devise.
I see yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]ur brows are full of discontent,
Your hearts of so[SEQ_SPLITTER]rrow and your eyes of tears:
Come home with me to [SEQ_SPLITTER]supper; and I'll lay
A plot shall show us all a me[SEQ_SPLITTER]rry day.

QUEEN:
This way the king will come; this[SEQ_SPLITTER] is the way
To Julius Caesar's ill-erected tower,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]To whose flint bosom my condemned lord
Is doom'd a[SEQ_SPLITTER] prisoner by proud Bolingbroke:
Here let us rest, [SEQ_SPLITTER]if this rebellious earth
Have any resting for her [SEQ_SPLITTER]true king's queen.
But soft, but see, or rather do[SEQ_SPLITTER] not see,
My fair rose wither: yet look up, behold[SEQ_SPLITTER],
That you in pity may dissolve to dew,
And wash h[SEQ_SPLITTER]im fresh again with true-love tears.
Ah, thou, the[SEQ_SPLITTER] model where old Troy did stand,
Thou map of honou[SEQ_SPLITTER]r, thou King Richard's tomb,
And not King Richard;[SEQ_SPLITTER] thou most beauteous inn,
Why should hard-favour'd[SEQ_SPLITTER] grief be lodged in thee,
When triumph is become a[SEQ_SPLITTER]n alehouse guest?

KING RICHARD II:
Join not with [SEQ_SPLITTER]grief, fair woman, do not so,
To make my end too s[SEQ_SPLITTER]udden: learn, good soul,
To think our former state[SEQ_SPLITTER] a happy dream;
From which awaked, the truth of wh[SEQ_SPLITTER]at we are
Shows us but this: I am sworn brother, s[SEQ_SPLITTER]weet,
To grim Necessity, and he and I
Will keep a [SEQ_SPLITTER]league till death. Hie thee to France
And cloister[SEQ_SPLITTER] thee in some religious house:
Our holy lives must[SEQ_SPLITTER] win a new world's crown,
Which our profane hours [SEQ_SPLITTER]here have stricken down.

QUEEN:
What, is my Richa[SEQ_SPLITTER]rd both in shape and mind
Transform'd and weaken'd[SEQ_SPLITTER]? hath Bolingbroke deposed
Thine intellect? hath h[SEQ_SPLITTER]e been in thy heart?
The lion dying thrusteth fort[SEQ_SPLITTER]h his paw,
And wounds the earth, if nothing else, [SEQ_SPLITTER]with rage
To be o'erpower'd; and wilt thou, pupil-[SEQ_SPLITTER]like,
Take thy correction mildly, kiss the rod,
An[SEQ_SPLITTER]d fawn on rage with base humility,
Which art a lio[SEQ_SPLITTER]n and a king of beasts?

KING RICHARD II:
A king o[SEQ_SPLITTER]f beasts, indeed; if aught but beasts,
I had been [SEQ_SPLITTER]still a happy king of men.
Good sometime queen, pr[SEQ_SPLITTER]epare thee hence for France:
Think I am dead and t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hat even here thou takest,
As from my death-bed, t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hy last living leave.
In winter's tedious nights s[SEQ_SPLITTER]it by the fire
With good old folks and let them te[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll thee tales
Of woeful ages long ago betid;
And e[SEQ_SPLITTER]re thou bid good night, to quit their griefs,
Tell[SEQ_SPLITTER] thou the lamentable tale of me
And send the heare[SEQ_SPLITTER]rs weeping to their beds:
For why, the senseless b[SEQ_SPLITTER]rands will sympathize
The heavy accent of thy movi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ng tongue
And in compassion weep the fire out;
And[SEQ_SPLITTER] some will mourn in ashes, some coal-black,
For th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e deposing of a rightful king.

KING RICHARD II:
Northumber[SEQ_SPLITTER]land, thou ladder wherewithal

The time shall not be many[SEQ_SPLITTER] hours of age
More than it is ere foul sin gatheri[SEQ_SPLITTER]ng head

Though he divide the realm and give thee half[SEQ_SPLITTER],
It is too little, helping him to all;
And he sha[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll think that thou, which know'st the way
To plant[SEQ_SPLITTER] unrightful kings, wilt know again,
Being ne'er so[SEQ_SPLITTER] little urged, another way
To pluck him headlong f[SEQ_SPLITTER]rom the usurped throne.
The love of wicked men con[SEQ_SPLITTER]verts to fear;
That fear to hate, and hate turns o[SEQ_SPLITTER]ne or both
To worthy danger and deserved death.

N[SEQ_SPLITTER]ORTHUMBERLAND:
My guilt be on my head, and there a[SEQ_SPLITTER]n end.

KING RICHARD II:

Le[SEQ_SPLITTER]t me unkiss the oath 'twixt thee and me;
And yet n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ot so, for with a kiss 'twas made.
Part us, Northu[SEQ_SPLITTER]mberland; I toward the north,
Where shivering cold[SEQ_SPLITTER] and sickness pines the clime;
My wife to France: [SEQ_SPLITTER]from whence, set forth in pomp,
She came adorned h[SEQ_SPLITTER]ither like sweet May,
Sent back like Hallowmas or [SEQ_SPLITTER]short'st of day.

QUEEN:
And must we be divided? m[SEQ_SPLITTER]ust we part?

Ay, hand from hand,[SEQ_SPLITTER] my love, and heart from heart.

QUEEN:
Banish us [SEQ_SPLITTER]both and send the king with me.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
T[SEQ_SPLITTER]hat were some love but little policy.

QUEEN:
Then[SEQ_SPLITTER] whither he goes, thither let me go.

KING RICHARD[SEQ_SPLITTER] II:
So two, together weeping, make one woe.
Weep [SEQ_SPLITTER]thou for me in France, I for thee here;
Better far[SEQ_SPLITTER] off than near, be ne'er the near.
Go, count thy w[SEQ_SPLITTER]ay with sighs; I mine with groans.

QUEEN:
So long[SEQ_SPLITTER]est way shall have the longest moans.

KING RICHAR[SEQ_SPLITTER]D II:
Twice for one step I'll groan, the way being[SEQ_SPLITTER] short,
And piece the way out with a heavy heart.
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Come, come, in wooing sorrow let's be brief,
Since[SEQ_SPLITTER], wedding it, there is such length in grief;
One k[SEQ_SPLITTER]iss shall stop our mouths, and dumbly part;
Thus g[SEQ_SPLITTER]ive I mine, and thus take I thy heart.

QUEEN:
Giv[SEQ_SPLITTER]e me mine own again; 'twere no good part
To take o[SEQ_SPLITTER]n me to keep and kill thy heart.
So, now I have mi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ne own again, be gone,
That I might strive to kill[SEQ_SPLITTER] it with a groan.

Once more, adieu; the r[SEQ_SPLITTER]est let sorrow say.

Then, as I said, the duke, great Bolingbroke,[SEQ_SPLITTER]

Whilst all tongues cried '[SEQ_SPLITTER]God save thee,
Bolingbroke!'
You would have though[SEQ_SPLITTER]t the very windows spake,

And thus still doing, thu[SEQ_SPLITTER]s he pass'd along.

DUCHESS OF YORK:

DUKE OF YORK:
A[SEQ_SPLITTER]s in a theatre, the eyes of men,
After a well-grac[SEQ_SPLITTER]ed actor leaves the stage,
Are idly bent on him th[SEQ_SPLITTER]at enters next,
Thinking his prattle to be tedious[SEQ_SPLITTER];
Even so, or with much more contempt, men's eyes
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Did scowl on gentle Richard; no man cried 'God sav[SEQ_SPLITTER]e him!'
No joyful tongue gave him his welcome home[SEQ_SPLITTER]:
But dust was thrown upon his sacred head:
Which [SEQ_SPLITTER]with such gentle sorrow he shook off,
His face sti[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll combating with tears and smiles,
The badges of [SEQ_SPLITTER]his grief and patience,

And barbarism itself have[SEQ_SPLITTER] pitied him.
But heaven hath a hand in these event[SEQ_SPLITTER]s,
To whose high will we bound our calm contents.

Whose st[SEQ_SPLITTER]ate and honour I for aye allow.

To kill the king at Oxford.

DUCHESS OF YORK[SEQ_SPLITTER]:
He shall be none;
We'll keep him here: then what[SEQ_SPLITTER] is that to him?

DUKE OF YORK:
Away, fond woman! [SEQ_SPLITTER]were he twenty times my son,
I would appeach him.
[SEQ_SPLITTER]
DUCHESS OF YORK:
Hadst thou groan'd for him
As I [SEQ_SPLITTER]have done, thou wouldst be more pitiful.
But now I[SEQ_SPLITTER] know thy mind; thou dost suspect
That I have been[SEQ_SPLITTER] disloyal to thy bed,
And that he is a bastard, no[SEQ_SPLITTER]t thy son:
Sweet York, sweet husband, be not of th[SEQ_SPLITTER]at mind:
He is as like thee as a man may be,
Not l[SEQ_SPLITTER]ike to me, or any of my kin,
And yet I love him.

[SEQ_SPLITTER]DUKE OF YORK:
Make way, unruly woman!

DUCHESS OF [SEQ_SPLITTER]YORK:
After, Aumerle! mount thee upon his horse;
S[SEQ_SPLITTER]pur post, and get before him to the king,
And beg [SEQ_SPLITTER]thy pardon ere he do accuse thee.
I'll not be long[SEQ_SPLITTER] behind; though I be old,
I doubt not but to ride [SEQ_SPLITTER]as fast as York:
And never will I rise up from the[SEQ_SPLITTER] ground
Till Bolingbroke have pardon'd thee. Away,[SEQ_SPLITTER] be gone!

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Can no man tell me o[SEQ_SPLITTER]f my unthrifty son?
'Tis full three months since I[SEQ_SPLITTER] did see him last;
If any plague hang over us, 'ti[SEQ_SPLITTER]s he.
I would to God, my lords, he might be found:[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Inquire at London, 'mongst the taverns there,
For[SEQ_SPLITTER] there, they say, he daily doth frequent,
With unr[SEQ_SPLITTER]estrained loose companions,
Even such, they say, a[SEQ_SPLITTER]s stand in narrow lanes,
And beat our watch, and r[SEQ_SPLITTER]ob our passengers;
Which he, young wanton and effe[SEQ_SPLITTER]minate boy,
Takes on the point of honour to suppor[SEQ_SPLITTER]t
So dissolute a crew.

And told him of [SEQ_SPLITTER]those triumphs held at Oxford.

His answ[SEQ_SPLITTER]er was, he would unto the stews,

And wear it as a fav[SEQ_SPLITTER]our; and with that
He would unhorse the lustiest c[SEQ_SPLITTER]hallenger.

His eyes do drop no tears, his p[SEQ_SPLITTER]rayers are in jest;
His words come from his mouth,[SEQ_SPLITTER] ours from our breast:
He prays but faintly and wo[SEQ_SPLITTER]uld be denied;
We pray with heart and soul and all[SEQ_SPLITTER] beside:
His weary joints would gladly rise, I kno[SEQ_SPLITTER]w;
Our knees shall kneel till to the ground they g[SEQ_SPLITTER]row:

Ours[SEQ_SPLITTER] of true zeal and deep integrity.
Our prayers do o[SEQ_SPLITTER]ut-pray his; then let them have

And if I were thy nurse, thy tongue to[SEQ_SPLITTER] teach,
'Pardon' should be the first word of thy s[SEQ_SPLITTER]peech.
I never long'd to hear a word till now;
Say[SEQ_SPLITTER] 'pardon,' king; let pity teach thee how:
The word[SEQ_SPLITTER] is short, but not so short as sweet;
No word like[SEQ_SPLITTER] 'pardon' for kings' mouths so meet.

DUKE OF YORK[SEQ_SPLITTER]:

[SEQ_SPLITTER]DUCHESS OF YORK:

That set'st the word itself against the word!
Sp[SEQ_SPLITTER]eak 'pardon' as 'tis current in our land;
The chop[SEQ_SPLITTER]ping French we do not understand.
Thine eye begins[SEQ_SPLITTER] to speak; set thy tongue there;
Or in thy piteous[SEQ_SPLITTER] heart plant thou thine ear;
That hearing how our [SEQ_SPLITTER]plaints and prayers do pierce,
Pity may move thee [SEQ_SPLITTER]'pardon' to rehearse.

And speak[SEQ_SPLITTER]ing it, he wistly look'd on me,

That would divorce t[SEQ_SPLITTER]his terror from my heart;'
Meaning the king at Pom[SEQ_SPLITTER]fret. Come, let's go:
I am the king's friend, and [SEQ_SPLITTER]will rid his foe.

KING RICHARD II:
I have been st[SEQ_SPLITTER]udying how I may compare
This prison where I live [SEQ_SPLITTER]unto the world:
And for because the world is popul[SEQ_SPLITTER]ous
And here is not a creature but myself,
I canno[SEQ_SPLITTER]t do it; yet I'll hammer it out.
My brain I'll pro[SEQ_SPLITTER]ve the female to my soul,
My soul the father; and [SEQ_SPLITTER]these two beget
A generation of still-breeding tho[SEQ_SPLITTER]ughts,
And these same thoughts people this little [SEQ_SPLITTER]world,
In humours like the people of this world,
F[SEQ_SPLITTER]or no thought is contented. The better sort,
As th[SEQ_SPLITTER]oughts of things divine, are intermix'd
With scrup[SEQ_SPLITTER]les and do set the word itself
Against the word:
A[SEQ_SPLITTER]s thus, 'Come, little ones,' and then again,
'It i[SEQ_SPLITTER]s as hard to come as for a camel
To thread the pos[SEQ_SPLITTER]tern of a small needle's eye.'
Thoughts tending to[SEQ_SPLITTER] ambition, they do plot
Unlikely wonders; how thes[SEQ_SPLITTER]e vain weak nails
May tear a passage through the f[SEQ_SPLITTER]linty ribs
Of this hard world, my ragged prison wa[SEQ_SPLITTER]lls,
And, for they cannot, die in their own pride.[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Thoughts tending to content flatter themselves
Th[SEQ_SPLITTER]at they are not the first of fortune's slaves,
Nor[SEQ_SPLITTER] shall not be the last; like silly beggars
Who sit[SEQ_SPLITTER]ting in the stocks refuge their shame,
That many h[SEQ_SPLITTER]ave and others must sit there;
And in this thought[SEQ_SPLITTER] they find a kind of ease,
Bearing their own misfo[SEQ_SPLITTER]rtunes on the back
Of such as have before endured [SEQ_SPLITTER]the like.
Thus play I in one person many people,
A[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd none contented: sometimes am I king;
Then treas[SEQ_SPLITTER]ons make me wish myself a beggar,
And so I am: the[SEQ_SPLITTER]n crushing penury
Persuades me I was better when a[SEQ_SPLITTER] king;
Then am I king'd again: and by and by
Think[SEQ_SPLITTER] that I am unking'd by Bolingbroke,
And straight a[SEQ_SPLITTER]m nothing: but whate'er I be,
Nor I nor any man th[SEQ_SPLITTER]at but man is
With nothing shall be pleased, till [SEQ_SPLITTER]he be eased
With being nothing. Music do I hear?
H[SEQ_SPLITTER]a, ha! keep time: how sour sweet music is,
When ti[SEQ_SPLITTER]me is broke and no proportion kept!
So is it in th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e music of men's lives.
And here have I the dainti[SEQ_SPLITTER]ness of ear
To cheque time broke in a disorder'd s[SEQ_SPLITTER]tring;
But for the concord of my state and time
Ha[SEQ_SPLITTER]d not an ear to hear my true time broke.
I wasted [SEQ_SPLITTER]time, and now doth time waste me;
For now hath tim[SEQ_SPLITTER]e made me his numbering clock:
My thoughts are min[SEQ_SPLITTER]utes; and with sighs they jar
Their watches on unt[SEQ_SPLITTER]o mine eyes, the outward watch,
Whereto my finger,[SEQ_SPLITTER] like a dial's point,
Is pointing still, in cleans[SEQ_SPLITTER]ing them from tears.
Now sir, the sound that tells[SEQ_SPLITTER] what hour it is
Are clamorous groans, which strik[SEQ_SPLITTER]e upon my heart,
Which is the bell: so sighs and t[SEQ_SPLITTER]ears and groans
Show minutes, times, and hours: bu[SEQ_SPLITTER]t my time
Runs posting on in Bolingbroke's proud j[SEQ_SPLITTER]oy,
While I stand fooling here, his Jack o' the cl[SEQ_SPLITTER]ock.
This music mads me; let it sound no more;
For[SEQ_SPLITTER] though it have holp madmen to their wits,
In me i[SEQ_SPLITTER]t seems it will make wise men mad.
Yet blessing on[SEQ_SPLITTER] his heart that gives it me!
For 'tis a sign of lo[SEQ_SPLITTER]ve; and love to Richard
Is a strange brooch in thi[SEQ_SPLITTER]s all-hating world.

Groom:
Hail, royal prince!

Thanks, noble peer;
The cheapest o[SEQ_SPLITTER]f us is ten groats too dear.
What art thou? and ho[SEQ_SPLITTER]w comest thou hither,
Where no man never comes but[SEQ_SPLITTER] that sad dog
That brings me food to make misfortu[SEQ_SPLITTER]ne live?

Groom:
I was a poor groom of thy stable,[SEQ_SPLITTER] king,
When thou wert king; who, travelling toward[SEQ_SPLITTER]s York,
With much ado at length have gotten leave
[SEQ_SPLITTER]To look upon my sometimes royal master's face.
O, [SEQ_SPLITTER]how it yearn'd my heart when I beheld
In London st[SEQ_SPLITTER]reets, that coronation-day,
When Bolingbroke rode [SEQ_SPLITTER]on roan Barbary,

KING RIC[SEQ_SPLITTER]HARD II:
So proud that Bolingbroke was on his back[SEQ_SPLITTER]!
That jade hath eat bread from my royal hand;
Thi[SEQ_SPLITTER]s hand hath made him proud with clapping him.
Woul[SEQ_SPLITTER]d he not stumble? would he not fall down,
Since pr[SEQ_SPLITTER]ide must have a fall, and break the neck
Of that p[SEQ_SPLITTER]roud man that did usurp his back?
Forgiveness, hor[SEQ_SPLITTER]se! why do I rail on thee,
Since thou, created to [SEQ_SPLITTER]be awed by man,
Wast born to bear? I was not made [SEQ_SPLITTER]a horse;
And yet I bear a burthen like an ass,
Spu[SEQ_SPLITTER]rr'd, gall'd and tired by jouncing Bolingbroke.

K[SEQ_SPLITTER]eeper:

EXTON:

For now the devil, that told m[SEQ_SPLITTER]e I did well,
Says that this deed is chronicled in[SEQ_SPLITTER] hell.
This dead king to the living king I'll bear[SEQ_SPLITTER]

[SEQ_SPLITTER]HENRY BOLINGBROKE:

Hath yielded up his body to the grave;

Thy kingly doom[SEQ_SPLITTER] and sentence of his pride.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Ca[SEQ_SPLITTER]rlisle, this is your doom:
Choose out some secret [SEQ_SPLITTER]place, some reverend room,
More than thou hast, an[SEQ_SPLITTER]d with it joy thy life;
So as thou livest in peace[SEQ_SPLITTER], die free from strife:
For though mine enemy thou[SEQ_SPLITTER] hast ever been,
High sparks of honour in thee hav[SEQ_SPLITTER]e I seen.

HENRY BOLINGBRO[SEQ_SPLITTER]KE:
They love not poison that do poison need,
Nor [SEQ_SPLITTER]do I thee: though I did wish him dead,
I hate the [SEQ_SPLITTER]murderer, love him murdered.
The guilt of conscien[SEQ_SPLITTER]ce take thou for thy labour,
But neither my good w[SEQ_SPLITTER]ord nor princely favour:
With Cain go wander throu[SEQ_SPLITTER]gh shades of night,
And never show thy head by day[SEQ_SPLITTER] nor light.

That blood should sprinkle me to make me grow:[SEQ_SPLITTER]

And put[SEQ_SPLITTER] on sullen black incontinent:
I'll make a voyage t[SEQ_SPLITTER]o the Holy Land,
To wash this blood off from my gu[SEQ_SPLITTER]ilty hand:
March sadly after; grace my mournings h[SEQ_SPLITTER]ere;
In weeping after this untimely bier.


SAMPSO[SEQ_SPLITTER]N:

GR[SEQ_SPLITTER]EGORY:
No, for then we should be colliers.

SAMPSO[SEQ_SPLITTER]N:
I mean, an we be in choler, we'll draw.

GREGOR[SEQ_SPLITTER]Y:
Ay, while you live, draw your neck out o' the c[SEQ_SPLITTER]ollar.

SAMPSON:
I strike quickly, being moved.

G[SEQ_SPLITTER]REGORY:
But thou art not quickly moved to strike.

SAMPSON:
A dog of the house of Montague moves me.[SEQ_SPLITTER]

GREGORY:
To move is to stir; and to be valiant i[SEQ_SPLITTER]s to stand:
therefore, if thou art moved, thou run[SEQ_SPLITTER]n'st away.

SAMPSON:
A dog of that house shall mov[SEQ_SPLITTER]e me to stand: I will
take the wall of any man or [SEQ_SPLITTER]maid of Montague's.

GREGORY:
That shows thee a we[SEQ_SPLITTER]ak slave; for the weakest goes
to the wall.

SAMPS[SEQ_SPLITTER]ON:

The quarrel is bet[SEQ_SPLITTER]ween our masters and us their men.

SAMPSON:
'Tis [SEQ_SPLITTER]all one, I will show myself a tyrant: when I
have [SEQ_SPLITTER]fought with the men, I will be cruel with the
maid[SEQ_SPLITTER]s, and cut off their heads.

The heads of[SEQ_SPLITTER] the maids?

And hear the sentence [SEQ_SPLITTER]of your moved prince.

By thee, old Capulet, and Montague,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Have thrice disturb'd the quiet of our streets,
An[SEQ_SPLITTER]d made Verona's ancient citizens

That most are busied when[SEQ_SPLITTER] they're most alone,
Pursued my humour not pursuin[SEQ_SPLITTER]g his,
And gladly shunn'd who gladly fled from me.[SEQ_SPLITTER]

For then she could st[SEQ_SPLITTER]and alone; nay, by the rood,
She could have run an[SEQ_SPLITTER]d waddled all about;
For even the day before, she [SEQ_SPLITTER]broke her brow:
And then my husband--God be with h[SEQ_SPLITTER]is soul!
A' was a merry man--took up the child:
'Y[SEQ_SPLITTER]ea,' quoth he, 'dost thou fall upon thy face?
Thou[SEQ_SPLITTER] wilt fall backward when thou hast more wit;
Wilt [SEQ_SPLITTER]thou not, Jule?' and, by my holidame,
The pretty w[SEQ_SPLITTER]retch left crying and said 'Ay.'
To see, now, how [SEQ_SPLITTER]a jest shall come about!
I warrant, an I should li[SEQ_SPLITTER]ve a thousand years,
I never should forget it: 'Wi[SEQ_SPLITTER]lt thou not, Jule?' quoth he;
And, pretty fool, it[SEQ_SPLITTER] stinted and said 'Ay.'

Chorus:
Now old desire doth in hi[SEQ_SPLITTER]s death-bed lie,
And young affection gapes to be h[SEQ_SPLITTER]is heir;
That fair for which love groan'd for and [SEQ_SPLITTER]would die,
With tender Juliet match'd, is now not [SEQ_SPLITTER]fair.
Now Romeo is beloved and loves again,
Alike [SEQ_SPLITTER]betwitched by the charm of looks,
But to his foe s[SEQ_SPLITTER]upposed he must complain,
And she steal love's swe[SEQ_SPLITTER]et bait from fearful hooks:
Being held a foe, he m[SEQ_SPLITTER]ay not have access
To breathe such vows as lovers [SEQ_SPLITTER]use to swear;
And she as much in love, her means m[SEQ_SPLITTER]uch less
To meet her new-beloved any where:
But pa[SEQ_SPLITTER]ssion lends them power, time means, to meet
Temper[SEQ_SPLITTER]ing extremities with extreme sweet.

ROMEO:
Can I [SEQ_SPLITTER]go forward when my heart is here?
Turn back, dull [SEQ_SPLITTER]earth, and find thy centre out.

BENVOLIO:

MERCUTIO:
He is wise;
And, on my[SEQ_SPLITTER] lie, hath stol'n him home to bed.

BENVOLIO:
He r[SEQ_SPLITTER]an this way, and leap'd this orchard wall:
Call, g[SEQ_SPLITTER]ood Mercutio.

MERCUTIO:

Ro[SEQ_SPLITTER]meo! humours! madman! passion! lover!
Appear thou [SEQ_SPLITTER]in the likeness of a sigh:
Speak but one rhyme, an[SEQ_SPLITTER]d I am satisfied;
Cry but 'Ay me!' pronounce but '[SEQ_SPLITTER]love' and 'dove;'
Speak to my gossip Venus one fai[SEQ_SPLITTER]r word,
One nick-name for her purblind son and hei[SEQ_SPLITTER]r,
Young Adam Cupid, he that shot so trim,
When Ki[SEQ_SPLITTER]ng Cophetua loved the beggar-maid!
He heareth not,[SEQ_SPLITTER] he stirreth not, he moveth not;
The ape is dead, [SEQ_SPLITTER]and I must conjure him.
I conjure thee by Rosaline[SEQ_SPLITTER]'s bright eyes,
By her high forehead and her scarl[SEQ_SPLITTER]et lip,
By her fine foot, straight leg and quiveri[SEQ_SPLITTER]ng thigh
And the demesnes that there adjacent lie,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
That in thy likeness thou appear to us!

BENVOLIO[SEQ_SPLITTER]:
And if he hear thee, thou wilt anger him.

MERCU[SEQ_SPLITTER]TIO:
This cannot anger him: 'twould anger him
To r[SEQ_SPLITTER]aise a spirit in his mistress' circle
Of some stra[SEQ_SPLITTER]nge nature, letting it there stand
Till she had la[SEQ_SPLITTER]id it and conjured it down;
That were some spite: [SEQ_SPLITTER]my invocation
Is fair and honest, and in his mistr[SEQ_SPLITTER]ess' name
I conjure only but to raise up him.

BEN[SEQ_SPLITTER]VOLIO:
Come, he hath hid himself among these trees[SEQ_SPLITTER],
To be consorted with the humorous night:
Blind i[SEQ_SPLITTER]s his love and best befits the dark.

MERCUTIO:
If[SEQ_SPLITTER] love be blind, love cannot hit the mark.
Now will[SEQ_SPLITTER] he sit under a medlar tree,
And wish his mistress[SEQ_SPLITTER] were that kind of fruit
As maids call medlars, wh[SEQ_SPLITTER]en they laugh alone.
Romeo, that she were, O, that[SEQ_SPLITTER] she were
An open et caetera, thou a poperin pear![SEQ_SPLITTER]
Romeo, good night: I'll to my truckle-bed;
This f[SEQ_SPLITTER]ield-bed is too cold for me to sleep:
Come, shall [SEQ_SPLITTER]we go?

BENVOLIO:
Go, then; for 'tis in vain
To se[SEQ_SPLITTER]ek him here that means not to be found.

ROMEO:
He[SEQ_SPLITTER] jests at scars that never felt a wound.
But, soft[SEQ_SPLITTER]! what light through yonder window breaks?
It is t[SEQ_SPLITTER]he east, and Juliet is the sun.
Arise, fair sun, a[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd kill the envious moon,
Who is already sick and [SEQ_SPLITTER]pale with grief,
That thou her maid art far more f[SEQ_SPLITTER]air than she:
Be not her maid, since she is enviou[SEQ_SPLITTER]s;
Her vestal livery is but sick and green
And non[SEQ_SPLITTER]e but fools do wear it; cast it off.
It is my lady[SEQ_SPLITTER], O, it is my love!
O, that she knew she were!
She[SEQ_SPLITTER] speaks yet she says nothing: what of that?
Her ey[SEQ_SPLITTER]e discourses; I will answer it.
I am too bold, 'ti[SEQ_SPLITTER]s not to me she speaks:
Two of the fairest stars i[SEQ_SPLITTER]n all the heaven,
Having some business, do entreat[SEQ_SPLITTER] her eyes
To twinkle in their spheres till they re[SEQ_SPLITTER]turn.
What if her eyes were there, they in her hea[SEQ_SPLITTER]d?
The brightness of her cheek would shame those s[SEQ_SPLITTER]tars,
As daylight doth a lamp; her eyes in heaven
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Would through the airy region stream so bright
Tha[SEQ_SPLITTER]t birds would sing and think it were not night.
Se[SEQ_SPLITTER]e, how she leans her cheek upon her hand!
O, that [SEQ_SPLITTER]I were a glove upon that hand,
That I might touch [SEQ_SPLITTER]that cheek!

JULIET:
Ay me!

ROMEO:
She speaks:
O,[SEQ_SPLITTER] speak again, bright angel! for thou art
As glorio[SEQ_SPLITTER]us to this night, being o'er my head
As is a winge[SEQ_SPLITTER]d messenger of heaven
Unto the white-upturned wond[SEQ_SPLITTER]ering eyes
Of mortals that fall back to gaze on hi[SEQ_SPLITTER]m
When he bestrides the lazy-pacing clouds
And sai[SEQ_SPLITTER]ls upon the bosom of the air.

JULIET:

Deny thy father and[SEQ_SPLITTER] refuse thy name;
Or, if thou wilt not, be but swo[SEQ_SPLITTER]rn my love,
And I'll no longer be a Capulet.

ROME[SEQ_SPLITTER]O:

JULIET:
'Tis but thy name that is my enemy;
Th[SEQ_SPLITTER]ou art thyself, though not a Montague.
What's Mont[SEQ_SPLITTER]ague? it is nor hand, nor foot,
Nor arm, nor face,[SEQ_SPLITTER] nor any other part
Belonging to a man. O, be some[SEQ_SPLITTER] other name!
What's in a name? that which we call [SEQ_SPLITTER]a rose
By any other name would smell as sweet;
So [SEQ_SPLITTER]Romeo would, were he not Romeo call'd,
Retain that[SEQ_SPLITTER] dear perfection which he owes
Without that title.[SEQ_SPLITTER] Romeo, doff thy name,
And for that name which is [SEQ_SPLITTER]no part of thee
Take all myself.

ROMEO:

Call me but love, and I'll be new [SEQ_SPLITTER]baptized;
Henceforth I never will be Romeo.

JULIE[SEQ_SPLITTER]T:

By a name

Because it is an enemy[SEQ_SPLITTER] to thee;
Had I it written, I would tear the word.[SEQ_SPLITTER]

ROMEO:

And what love can do [SEQ_SPLITTER]that dares love attempt;
Therefore thy kinsmen are[SEQ_SPLITTER] no let to me.

JULIET:

FRIAR LAU[SEQ_SPLITTER]RENCE:
The grey-eyed morn smiles on the frowning n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ight,
Chequering the eastern clouds with streaks o[SEQ_SPLITTER]f light,
And flecked darkness like a drunkard reel[SEQ_SPLITTER]s
From forth day's path and Titan's fiery wheels:
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Now, ere the sun advance his burning eye,
The day [SEQ_SPLITTER]to cheer and night's dank dew to dry,
I must up-fi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll this osier cage of ours
With baleful weeds and [SEQ_SPLITTER]precious-juiced flowers.
The earth that's nature's[SEQ_SPLITTER] mother is her tomb;
What is her burying grave tha[SEQ_SPLITTER]t is her womb,
And from her womb children of diver[SEQ_SPLITTER]s kind
We sucking on her natural bosom find,
Many [SEQ_SPLITTER]for many virtues excellent,
None but for some and [SEQ_SPLITTER]yet all different.
O, mickle is the powerful grace[SEQ_SPLITTER] that lies
In herbs, plants, stones, and their tru[SEQ_SPLITTER]e qualities:
For nought so vile that on the earth [SEQ_SPLITTER]doth live
But to the earth some special good doth [SEQ_SPLITTER]give,
Nor aught so good but strain'd from that fai[SEQ_SPLITTER]r use
Revolts from true birth, stumbling on abuse:[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied;
And v[SEQ_SPLITTER]ice sometimes by action dignified.
Within the infa[SEQ_SPLITTER]nt rind of this small flower
Poison hath residence[SEQ_SPLITTER] and medicine power:
For this, being smelt, with t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hat part cheers each part;
Being tasted, slays all[SEQ_SPLITTER] senses with the heart.
Two such opposed kings enc[SEQ_SPLITTER]amp them still
In man as well as herbs, grace and [SEQ_SPLITTER]rude will;
And where the worser is predominant,
Fu[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll soon the canker death eats up that plant.

ROME[SEQ_SPLITTER]O:
Good morrow, father.

FRIAR LAURENCE:
Benedicit[SEQ_SPLITTER]e!
What early tongue so sweet saluteth me?
Young s[SEQ_SPLITTER]on, it argues a distemper'd head
So soon to bid go[SEQ_SPLITTER]od morrow to thy bed:
Care keeps his watch in ever[SEQ_SPLITTER]y old man's eye,
And where care lodges, sleep will[SEQ_SPLITTER] never lie;
But where unbruised youth with unstuff[SEQ_SPLITTER]'d brain
Doth couch his limbs, there golden sleep [SEQ_SPLITTER]doth reign:
Therefore thy earliness doth me assure[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Thou art up-roused by some distemperature;
Or if [SEQ_SPLITTER]not so, then here I hit it right,
Our Romeo hath n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ot been in bed to-night.

R[SEQ_SPLITTER]OMEO:

Where on a sud[SEQ_SPLITTER]den one hath wounded me,

My inte[SEQ_SPLITTER]rcession likewise steads my foe.

FRIAR LAURENCE:

Riddl[SEQ_SPLITTER]ing confession finds but riddling shrift.

T[SEQ_SPLITTER]hat thou consent to marry us to-day.

FRIAR LAUREN[SEQ_SPLITTER]CE:

How much salt water thrown away in waste,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]To season love, that of it doth not taste!

Women may fall, when there's no streng[SEQ_SPLITTER]th in men.

M[SEQ_SPLITTER]ERCUTIO:

JULIET:
The clock struck nine when I did send[SEQ_SPLITTER] the nurse;
In half an hour she promised to return[SEQ_SPLITTER].
Perchance she cannot meet him: that's not so.
O,[SEQ_SPLITTER] she is lame! love's heralds should be thoughts,
W[SEQ_SPLITTER]hich ten times faster glide than the sun's beams,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Driving back shadows over louring hills:
Therefore[SEQ_SPLITTER] do nimble-pinion'd doves draw love,
And therefore[SEQ_SPLITTER] hath the wind-swift Cupid wings.

FRIAR LAURENCE:
Romeo, come forth; co[SEQ_SPLITTER]me forth, thou fearful man:
Affliction is enamour'[SEQ_SPLITTER]d of thy parts,
And thou art wedded to calamity.

Tha[SEQ_SPLITTER]t I yet know not?

Too familiar

I bring thee [SEQ_SPLITTER]tidings of the prince's doom.

What less th[SEQ_SPLITTER]an dooms-day is the prince's doom?

A gentler judgment vanish'd from his lips,
Not b[SEQ_SPLITTER]ody's death, but body's banishment.

ROMEO:
Ha, ba[SEQ_SPLITTER]nishment! be merciful, say 'death;'
For exile hath[SEQ_SPLITTER] more terror in his look,
Much more than death: do[SEQ_SPLITTER] not say 'banishment.'

FRIAR LAURENCE:
Hence from[SEQ_SPLITTER] Verona art thou banished:
Be patient, for the wor[SEQ_SPLITTER]ld is broad and wide.

There is no world wi[SEQ_SPLITTER]thout Verona walls,
But purgatory, torture, hell i[SEQ_SPLITTER]tself.
Hence-banished is banish'd from the world,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]And world's exile is death: then banished,
Is deat[SEQ_SPLITTER]h mis-term'd: calling death banishment,
Thou cutt'[SEQ_SPLITTER]st my head off with a golden axe,
And smilest upon[SEQ_SPLITTER] the stroke that murders me.

FRIAR LAURENCE:
O de[SEQ_SPLITTER]adly sin! O rude unthankfulness!
Thy fault our law[SEQ_SPLITTER] calls death; but the kind prince,
Taking thy part[SEQ_SPLITTER], hath rush'd aside the law,
And turn'd that black[SEQ_SPLITTER] word death to banishment:
This is dear mercy, and[SEQ_SPLITTER] thou seest it not.

ROMEO:
'Tis torture, and not [SEQ_SPLITTER]mercy: heaven is here,
Where Juliet lives; and eve[SEQ_SPLITTER]ry cat and dog
And little mouse, every unworthy th[SEQ_SPLITTER]ing,
Live here in heaven and may look on her;
But [SEQ_SPLITTER]Romeo may not: more validity,
More honourable stat[SEQ_SPLITTER]e, more courtship lives
In carrion-flies than Rome[SEQ_SPLITTER]o: they my seize
On the white wonder of dear Julie[SEQ_SPLITTER]t's hand
And steal immortal blessing from her lips[SEQ_SPLITTER],
Who even in pure and vestal modesty,
Still blush[SEQ_SPLITTER], as thinking their own kisses sin;
But Romeo may [SEQ_SPLITTER]not; he is banished:
Flies may do this, but I from[SEQ_SPLITTER] this must fly:
They are free men, but I am banish[SEQ_SPLITTER]ed.
And say'st thou yet that exile is not death?
H[SEQ_SPLITTER]adst thou no poison mix'd, no sharp-ground knife,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]No sudden mean of death, though ne'er so mean,
But[SEQ_SPLITTER] 'banished' to kill me?--'banished'?
O friar, the [SEQ_SPLITTER]damned use that word in hell;
Howlings attend it: [SEQ_SPLITTER]how hast thou the heart,
Being a divine, a ghostly[SEQ_SPLITTER] confessor,
A sin-absolver, and my friend profess'[SEQ_SPLITTER]d,
To mangle me with that word 'banished'?

FRIAR [SEQ_SPLITTER]LAURENCE:
Thou fond mad man, hear me but speak a w[SEQ_SPLITTER]ord.

It helps not, it prevails not: ta[SEQ_SPLITTER]lk no more.

Piteous predicament! Eve[SEQ_SPLITTER]n so lies she,
Blubbering and weeping, weeping and[SEQ_SPLITTER] blubbering.

For Juliet's sake, for her sake, rise and [SEQ_SPLITTER]stand;

And then down falls again[SEQ_SPLITTER].

FRIAR LAURENCE:

A[SEQ_SPLITTER]rt thou a man? thy form cries out thou art:
Thy te[SEQ_SPLITTER]ars are womanish; thy wild acts denote
The unreaso[SEQ_SPLITTER]nable fury of a beast:
Unseemly woman in a seeming[SEQ_SPLITTER] man!
Or ill-beseeming beast in seeming both!
Thou[SEQ_SPLITTER] hast amazed me: by my holy order,
I thought thy d[SEQ_SPLITTER]isposition better temper'd.
Hast thou slain Tybalt[SEQ_SPLITTER]? wilt thou slay thyself?
And stay thy lady too th[SEQ_SPLITTER]at lives in thee,
By doing damned hate upon thysel[SEQ_SPLITTER]f?

Since birth, and heaven, and earth, all thr[SEQ_SPLITTER]ee do meet

Which, like a usurer, abound'st in a[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll,

Thy nob[SEQ_SPLITTER]le shape is but a form of wax,
Digressing from the[SEQ_SPLITTER] valour of a man;
Thy dear love sworn but hollow p[SEQ_SPLITTER]erjury,
Killing that love which thou hast vow'd to[SEQ_SPLITTER] cherish;
Thy wit, that ornament to shape and love[SEQ_SPLITTER],
Misshapen in the conduct of them both,
Like powd[SEQ_SPLITTER]er in a skitless soldier's flask,
Is set afire by [SEQ_SPLITTER]thine own ignorance,

Our solemn hymns to sulle[SEQ_SPLITTER]n dirges change,
Our bridal flowers serve for a bu[SEQ_SPLITTER]ried corse,
And all things change them to the cont[SEQ_SPLITTER]rary.

FRIAR LAURENCE:
Sir, go you in; and, madam,[SEQ_SPLITTER] go with him;
And go, Sir Paris; every one prepare[SEQ_SPLITTER]
To follow this fair corse unto her grave:
The hea[SEQ_SPLITTER]vens do lour upon you for some ill;
Move them no m[SEQ_SPLITTER]ore by crossing their high will.

First Musician:
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Faith, we may put up our pipes, and be gone.

Nurs[SEQ_SPLITTER]e:
Honest goodfellows, ah, put up, put up;
For, we[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll you know, this is a pitiful case.

First Musici[SEQ_SPLITTER]an:
Ay, by my troth, the case may be amended.

PET[SEQ_SPLITTER]ER:
Musicians, O, musicians, 'Heart's ease, Heart'[SEQ_SPLITTER]s
ease:' O, an you will have me live, play 'Heart'[SEQ_SPLITTER]s ease.'

First Musician:
Why 'Heart's ease?'

PET[SEQ_SPLITTER]ER:

heart is full of woe:' O, play me some merry dum[SEQ_SPLITTER]p,
to comfort me.

First Musician:
Not a dump we; [SEQ_SPLITTER]'tis no time to play now.

PETER:
You will not, th[SEQ_SPLITTER]en?

First Musician:
No.

PETER:
I will then give [SEQ_SPLITTER]it you soundly.

First Musician:
What will you giv[SEQ_SPLITTER]e us?

PETER:

I will give you the minstrel.

First Musician:
T[SEQ_SPLITTER]hen I will give you the serving-creature.

PETER:

y[SEQ_SPLITTER]our pate. I will carry no crotchets: I'll re you,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]I'll fa you; do you note me?

First Musician:
An y[SEQ_SPLITTER]ou re us and fa us, you note us.

Second Musician:[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Pray you, put up your dagger, and put out your wi[SEQ_SPLITTER]t.

'When griping grief the [SEQ_SPLITTER]heart doth wound,
And doleful dumps the mind oppre[SEQ_SPLITTER]ss,
Then music with her silver sound'--
why 'silve[SEQ_SPLITTER]r sound'? why 'music with her silver
sound'? What [SEQ_SPLITTER]say you, Simon Catling?

Musician:
Marry, sir, bec[SEQ_SPLITTER]ause silver hath a sweet sound.

PETER:

Second Musician:
I say '[SEQ_SPLITTER]silver sound,' because musicians sound for silver.[SEQ_SPLITTER]

PETER:

Third Musician:
Faith, I know not what to say.

because musicians have no gold for sounding:

With speedy help[SEQ_SPLITTER] doth lend redress.'

What a pesti[SEQ_SPLITTER]lent knave is this same!

ROMEO:
If I may trust the fl[SEQ_SPLITTER]attering truth of sleep,
My dreams presage some jo[SEQ_SPLITTER]yful news at hand:
My bosom's lord sits lightly in[SEQ_SPLITTER] his throne;
And all this day an unaccustom'd spir[SEQ_SPLITTER]it
Lifts me above the ground with cheerful thought[SEQ_SPLITTER]s.
I dreamt my lady came and found me dead--
Stran[SEQ_SPLITTER]ge dream, that gives a dead man leave
to think!--
[SEQ_SPLITTER]And breathed such life with kisses in my lips,
Tha[SEQ_SPLITTER]t I revived, and was an emperor.
Ah me! how sweet [SEQ_SPLITTER]is love itself possess'd,
When but love's shadows [SEQ_SPLITTER]are so rich in joy!
News from Verona!--How now, Ba[SEQ_SPLITTER]lthasar!
Dost thou not bring me letters from the f[SEQ_SPLITTER]riar?
How doth my lady? Is my father well?
How far[SEQ_SPLITTER]es my Juliet? that I ask again;
For nothing can be[SEQ_SPLITTER] ill, if she be well.

BALTHASAR:
Then she is well[SEQ_SPLITTER], and nothing can be ill:
Her body sleeps in Capel[SEQ_SPLITTER]'s monument,
And her immortal part with angels liv[SEQ_SPLITTER]es.
I saw her laid low in her kindred's vault,
And[SEQ_SPLITTER] presently took post to tell it you:
O, pardon me [SEQ_SPLITTER]for bringing these ill news,
Since you did leave i[SEQ_SPLITTER]t for my office, sir.

ROMEO:

Thou know'st my lodging: get me[SEQ_SPLITTER] ink and paper,
And hire post-horses; I will hence[SEQ_SPLITTER] to-night.

BALTHASAR:

Your looks are pale and wild, and do im[SEQ_SPLITTER]port

No, my good lord.

Let's see for means: O mischief, thou art swift
[SEQ_SPLITTER]To enter in the thoughts of desperate men!
I do re[SEQ_SPLITTER]member an apothecary,--
And hereabouts he dwells,-[SEQ_SPLITTER]-which late I noted
In tatter'd weeds, with overwh[SEQ_SPLITTER]elming brows,
Culling of simples; meagre were his [SEQ_SPLITTER]looks,
Sharp misery had worn him to the bones:
And[SEQ_SPLITTER] in his needy shop a tortoise hung,
An alligator s[SEQ_SPLITTER]tuff'd, and other skins
Of ill-shaped fishes; and [SEQ_SPLITTER]about his shelves
A beggarly account of empty boxe[SEQ_SPLITTER]s,
Green earthen pots, bladders and musty seeds,
R[SEQ_SPLITTER]emnants of packthread and old cakes of roses,
Were[SEQ_SPLITTER] thinly scatter'd, to make up a show.
Noting this [SEQ_SPLITTER]penury, to myself I said
'An if a man did need a p[SEQ_SPLITTER]oison now,
Whose sale is present death in Mantua,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Here lives a caitiff wretch would sell it him.'
O,[SEQ_SPLITTER] this same thought did but forerun my need;
And th[SEQ_SPLITTER]is same needy man must sell it me.
As I remember, [SEQ_SPLITTER]this should be the house.
Being holiday, the begga[SEQ_SPLITTER]r's shop is shut.
What, ho! apothecary!

Apothecar[SEQ_SPLITTER]y:
Who calls so loud?

ROMEO:

A dram of poison, such soon-speedin[SEQ_SPLITTER]g gear
As will disperse itself through all the vei[SEQ_SPLITTER]ns
That the life-weary taker may fall dead
And tha[SEQ_SPLITTER]t the trunk may be discharged of breath
As violent[SEQ_SPLITTER]ly as hasty powder fired
Doth hurry from the fatal[SEQ_SPLITTER] cannon's womb.

Apothecary:
Such mortal drugs I h[SEQ_SPLITTER]ave; but Mantua's law
Is death to any he that utte[SEQ_SPLITTER]rs them.

ROMEO:

And fear'st to die? famine is in thy che[SEQ_SPLITTER]eks,
Need and oppression starveth in thine eyes,
C[SEQ_SPLITTER]ontempt and beggary hangs upon thy back;
The world[SEQ_SPLITTER] is not thy friend nor the world's law;
The world [SEQ_SPLITTER]affords no law to make thee rich;
Then be not poor[SEQ_SPLITTER], but break it, and take this.

Apothecary:
My pov[SEQ_SPLITTER]erty, but not my will, consents.

ROMEO:
I pay thy[SEQ_SPLITTER] poverty, and not thy will.

Apothecary:

And drink it off; an[SEQ_SPLITTER]d, if you had the strength
Of twenty men, it would[SEQ_SPLITTER] dispatch you straight.

ROMEO:

Doing more murders i[SEQ_SPLITTER]n this loathsome world,

FR[SEQ_SPLITTER]IAR JOHN:
Going to find a bare-foot brother out

Here in this city[SEQ_SPLITTER] visiting the sick,
And finding him, the searchers[SEQ_SPLITTER] of the town,
Suspecting that we both were in a ho[SEQ_SPLITTER]use
Where the infectious pestilence did reign,
Sea[SEQ_SPLITTER]l'd up the doors, and would not let us forth;
So t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hat my speed to Mantua there was stay'd.

With [SEQ_SPLITTER]instruments upon them, fit to open
These dead men'[SEQ_SPLITTER]s tombs.

This dagger hath mista'en--for, [SEQ_SPLITTER]lo, his house
Is empty on the back of Montague,--
[SEQ_SPLITTER]And it mis-sheathed in my daughter's bosom!

T[SEQ_SPLITTER]hat warns my old age to a sepulchre.

FRIAR LAURENCE:
I am the greatest, able t[SEQ_SPLITTER]o do least,
Yet most suspected, as the time and pl[SEQ_SPLITTER]ace
Doth make against me of this direful murder;
A[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd here I stand, both to impeach and purge
Myself [SEQ_SPLITTER]condemned and myself excused.

PRINCE:
Then say at[SEQ_SPLITTER] once what thou dost know in this.

FRIAR LAURENCE[SEQ_SPLITTER]:
I will be brief, for my short date of breath
Is [SEQ_SPLITTER]not so long as is a tedious tale.
Romeo, there dea[SEQ_SPLITTER]d, was husband to that Juliet;
And she, there dead[SEQ_SPLITTER], that Romeo's faithful wife:
I married them; and [SEQ_SPLITTER]their stol'n marriage-day
Was Tybalt's dooms-day, [SEQ_SPLITTER]whose untimely death
Banish'd the new-made bridegr[SEQ_SPLITTER]oom from the city,
For whom, and not for Tybalt, J[SEQ_SPLITTER]uliet pined.
You, to remove that siege of grief fr[SEQ_SPLITTER]om her,
Betroth'd and would have married her perfo[SEQ_SPLITTER]rce
To County Paris: then comes she to me,
And, wi[SEQ_SPLITTER]th wild looks, bid me devise some mean
To rid her [SEQ_SPLITTER]from this second marriage,
Or in my cell there wou[SEQ_SPLITTER]ld she kill herself.
Then gave I her, so tutor'd b[SEQ_SPLITTER]y my art,
A sleeping potion; which so took effect
[SEQ_SPLITTER]As I intended, for it wrought on her
The form of d[SEQ_SPLITTER]eath: meantime I writ to Romeo,
That he should hit[SEQ_SPLITTER]her come as this dire night,
To help to take her f[SEQ_SPLITTER]rom her borrow'd grave,
Being the time the potion'[SEQ_SPLITTER]s force should cease.
But he which bore my letter,[SEQ_SPLITTER] Friar John,
Was stay'd by accident, and yesternig[SEQ_SPLITTER]ht
Return'd my letter back. Then all alone
At the [SEQ_SPLITTER]prefixed hour of her waking,
Came I to take her fr[SEQ_SPLITTER]om her kindred's vault;
Meaning to keep her closel[SEQ_SPLITTER]y at my cell,
Till I conveniently could send to Ro[SEQ_SPLITTER]meo:
But when I came, some minute ere the time
Of [SEQ_SPLITTER]her awaking, here untimely lay
The noble Paris and[SEQ_SPLITTER] true Romeo dead.
She wakes; and I entreated her c[SEQ_SPLITTER]ome forth,
And bear this work of heaven with patie[SEQ_SPLITTER]nce:
But then a noise did scare me from the tomb;
[SEQ_SPLITTER]And she, too desperate, would not go with me,
But,[SEQ_SPLITTER] as it seems, did violence on herself.
All this I [SEQ_SPLITTER]know; and to the marriage
Her nurse is privy: and,[SEQ_SPLITTER] if aught in this
Miscarried by my fault, let my o[SEQ_SPLITTER]ld life
Be sacrificed, some hour before his time,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Unto the rigour of severest law.

What is it, but to make thy se[SEQ_SPLITTER]pulchre
And creep into it far before thy time?
War[SEQ_SPLITTER]wick is chancellor and the lord of Calais;
Stern F[SEQ_SPLITTER]alconbridge commands the narrow seas;
The duke is [SEQ_SPLITTER]made protector of the realm;
And yet shalt thou be[SEQ_SPLITTER] safe? such safety finds
The trembling lamb enviro[SEQ_SPLITTER]ned with wolves.
Had I been there, which am a sill[SEQ_SPLITTER]y woman,
The soldiers should have toss'd me on the[SEQ_SPLITTER]ir pikes
Before I would have granted to that act.
[SEQ_SPLITTER]But thou preferr'st thy life before thine honour:
[SEQ_SPLITTER]And seeing thou dost, I here divorce myself
Both f[SEQ_SPLITTER]rom thy table, Henry, and thy bed,
Until that act [SEQ_SPLITTER]of parliament be repeal'd
Whereby my son is disinh[SEQ_SPLITTER]erited.
The northern lords that have forsworn thy [SEQ_SPLITTER]colours
Will follow mine, if once they see them sp[SEQ_SPLITTER]read;
And spread they shall be, to thy foul disgra[SEQ_SPLITTER]ce
And utter ruin of the house of York.
Thus do I [SEQ_SPLITTER]leave thee. Come, son, let's away;
Our army is rea[SEQ_SPLITTER]dy; come, we'll after them.

KING HENRY VI:
Stay, [SEQ_SPLITTER]gentle Margaret, and hear me speak.

QUEEN MARGARE[SEQ_SPLITTER]T:
Thou hast spoke too much already: get thee gone[SEQ_SPLITTER].

KING HENRY VI:
Gentle son Edward, thou wilt sta[SEQ_SPLITTER]y with me?

QUEEN MARGARET:
Ay, to be murder'd by [SEQ_SPLITTER]his enemies.

PRINCE EDWARD:
When I return with vi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ctory from the field
I'll see your grace: till the[SEQ_SPLITTER]n I'll follow her.

QUEEN MARGARET:
Come, son, awa[SEQ_SPLITTER]y; we may not linger thus.

KING HENRY VI:
Poor qu[SEQ_SPLITTER]een! how love to me and to her son
Hath made her b[SEQ_SPLITTER]reak out into terms of rage!
Revenged may she be o[SEQ_SPLITTER]n that hateful duke,
Whose haughty spirit, winged [SEQ_SPLITTER]with desire,
Will cost my crown, and like an empty[SEQ_SPLITTER] eagle
Tire on the flesh of me and of my son!
The [SEQ_SPLITTER]loss of those three lords torments my heart:
I'll [SEQ_SPLITTER]write unto them and entreat them fair.
Come, cousi[SEQ_SPLITTER]n you shall be the messenger.

EXETER:
And I, I ho[SEQ_SPLITTER]pe, shall reconcile them all.
3 KING HENRY VI

RIC[SEQ_SPLITTER]HARD:

But I have reasons strong and forcible.

YORK:

RICHARD:
