EDWARD:
Now you are heir, therefore enjoy [SEQ_SPLITTER]it now:
By giving the house of Lancaster leave to [SEQ_SPLITTER]breathe,
It will outrun you, father, in the end.

I took an oath that he should quietly reign.[SEQ_SPLITTER]

EDWARD:
But for a kingdom any oath may be broken[SEQ_SPLITTER]:
I would break a thousand oaths to reign one year[SEQ_SPLITTER].

RICHARD:
No; God forbid your grace should be fo[SEQ_SPLITTER]rsworn.

YORK:
I shall be, if I claim by open war.[SEQ_SPLITTER]

RICHARD:
I'll prove the contrary, if you'll hear[SEQ_SPLITTER] me speak.

YORK:

RICHARD:
An oath is of no moment, being no[SEQ_SPLITTER]t took
Before a true and lawful magistrate,
That h[SEQ_SPLITTER]ath authority over him that swears:
Henry had none[SEQ_SPLITTER], but did usurp the place;
Then, seeing 'twas he t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hat made you to depose,
Your oath, my lord, is vai[SEQ_SPLITTER]n and frivolous.
Therefore, to arms! And, father, [SEQ_SPLITTER]do but think
How sweet a thing it is to wear a cro[SEQ_SPLITTER]wn;
Within whose circuit is Elysium
And all that p[SEQ_SPLITTER]oets feign of bliss and joy.
Why do we finger thus[SEQ_SPLITTER]? I cannot rest
Until the white rose that I wear b[SEQ_SPLITTER]e dyed
Even in the lukewarm blood of Henry's heart[SEQ_SPLITTER].

And whet [SEQ_SPLITTER]on Warwick to this enterprise.

And tell him privily of [SEQ_SPLITTER]our intent.

With whom the Kentishmen will willingly rise:
In [SEQ_SPLITTER]them I trust; for they are soldiers,
Witty, courte[SEQ_SPLITTER]ous, liberal, full of spirit.
While you are thus e[SEQ_SPLITTER]mploy'd, what resteth more,
But that I seek occasi[SEQ_SPLITTER]on how to rise,
And yet the king not privy to my d[SEQ_SPLITTER]rift,
Nor any of the house of Lancaster?
But, stay[SEQ_SPLITTER]: what news? Why comest thou in such post?

Messen[SEQ_SPLITTER]ger:

Intend here to besiege you in your castle:
She [SEQ_SPLITTER]is hard by with twenty thousand men;

Sir Jo[SEQ_SPLITTER]hn and Sir Hugh Mortimer, mine uncles,

The army of the queen[SEQ_SPLITTER] mean to besiege us.

She shall not[SEQ_SPLITTER] need; we'll meet her in the field.

RICHARD:

A woman's general; what [SEQ_SPLITTER]should we fear?

EDWARD:

And issue forth and bid the[SEQ_SPLITTER]m battle straight.

YORK:

I doubt not, uncle, of our v[SEQ_SPLITTER]ictory.

When a[SEQ_SPLITTER]s the enemy hath been ten to one:
Why should I not[SEQ_SPLITTER] now have the like success?
3 KING HENRY VI

RUTLA[SEQ_SPLITTER]ND:

An[SEQ_SPLITTER]d so he comes, to rend his limbs asunder.

The[SEQ_SPLITTER]refore--

CLIFFORD:

YORK:
The army of the queen hath [SEQ_SPLITTER]got the field:
My uncles both are slain in rescuin[SEQ_SPLITTER]g me;
And all my followers to the eager foe

But this I know, they [SEQ_SPLITTER]have demean'd themselves
Like men born to renown b[SEQ_SPLITTER]y life or death.
Three times did Richard make a la[SEQ_SPLITTER]ne to me.
And thrice cried 'Courage, father! fight[SEQ_SPLITTER] it out!'
And full as oft came Edward to my side,

In blood[SEQ_SPLITTER] of those that had encounter'd him:

And cried 'A crown,[SEQ_SPLITTER] or else a glorious tomb!
A sceptre, or an earthly[SEQ_SPLITTER] sepulchre!'
With this, we charged again: but, out[SEQ_SPLITTER], alas!
We bodged again; as I have seen a swan
Wit[SEQ_SPLITTER]h bootless labour swim against the tide
And spend [SEQ_SPLITTER]her strength with over-matching waves.
Ah, hark! t[SEQ_SPLITTER]he fatal followers do pursue;
And I am faint and c[SEQ_SPLITTER]annot fly their fury:
And were I strong, I would n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ot shun their fury:
The sands are number'd that ma[SEQ_SPLITTER]ke up my life;
Here must I stay, and here my life [SEQ_SPLITTER]must end.

Whose tong[SEQ_SPLITTER]ue more poisons than the adder's tooth!
How ill-be[SEQ_SPLITTER]seeming is it in thy sex

Upon their woes whom fortune captivate[SEQ_SPLITTER]s!
But that thy face is, vizard-like, unchanging,

Were shame eno[SEQ_SPLITTER]ugh to shame thee, wert thou not shameless.

Of both the[SEQ_SPLITTER] Sicils and Jerusalem,

'Tis bea[SEQ_SPLITTER]uty that doth oft make women proud;
But, God he kn[SEQ_SPLITTER]ows, thy share thereof is small:
'Tis virtue that [SEQ_SPLITTER]doth make them most admired;
The contrary doth mak[SEQ_SPLITTER]e thee wonder'd at:
'Tis government that makes the[SEQ_SPLITTER]m seem divine;
The want thereof makes thee abomina[SEQ_SPLITTER]ble:
Thou art as opposite to every good
As the Ant[SEQ_SPLITTER]ipodes are unto us,
Or as the south to the septent[SEQ_SPLITTER]rion.
O tiger's heart wrapt in a woman's hide!
How[SEQ_SPLITTER] couldst thou drain the life-blood of the child,
T[SEQ_SPLITTER]o bid the father wipe his eyes withal,
And yet be [SEQ_SPLITTER]seen to bear a woman's face?
Women are soft, mild,[SEQ_SPLITTER] pitiful and flexible;
Thou stern, obdurate, flint[SEQ_SPLITTER]y, rough, remorseless.
Bids't thou me rage? why, n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ow thou hast thy wish:
Wouldst have me weep? why, [SEQ_SPLITTER]now thou hast thy will:
For raging wind blows up i[SEQ_SPLITTER]ncessant showers,
And when the rage allays, the ra[SEQ_SPLITTER]in begins.
These tears are my sweet Rutland's obse[SEQ_SPLITTER]quies:
And every drop cries vengeance for his deat[SEQ_SPLITTER]h,

Fr[SEQ_SPLITTER]enchwoman.

Upon my soul, the hea[SEQ_SPLITTER]rers will shed tears;

And in thy need such comfort come to t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hee

My soul to h[SEQ_SPLITTER]eaven, my blood upon your heads!

I should [SEQ_SPLITTER]not for my life but weep with him.

So York may overlook the town of York.
3 KING [SEQ_SPLITTER]HENRY VI

EDWARD:
I wonder how our princely father[SEQ_SPLITTER] 'scaped,
Or whether he be 'scaped away or no
From[SEQ_SPLITTER] Clifford's and Northumberland's pursuit:
Had he b[SEQ_SPLITTER]een ta'en, we should have heard the news;
Had he b[SEQ_SPLITTER]een slain, we should have heard the news;
Or had h[SEQ_SPLITTER]e 'scaped, methinks we should have heard
The happy[SEQ_SPLITTER] tidings of his good escape.
How fares my brother?[SEQ_SPLITTER] why is he so sad?

RICHARD:
I cannot joy, until I[SEQ_SPLITTER] be resolved
Where our right valiant father is bec[SEQ_SPLITTER]ome.
I saw him in the battle range about;
And watc[SEQ_SPLITTER]h'd him how he singled Clifford forth.
Methought h[SEQ_SPLITTER]e bore him in the thickest troop
As doth a lion in[SEQ_SPLITTER] a herd of neat;
Or as a bear, encompass'd round w[SEQ_SPLITTER]ith dogs,
Who having pinch'd a few and made them c[SEQ_SPLITTER]ry,
The rest stand all aloof, and bark at him.
So [SEQ_SPLITTER]fared our father with his enemies;
So fled his ene[SEQ_SPLITTER]mies my warlike father:
Methinks, 'tis prize enoug[SEQ_SPLITTER]h to be his son.
See how the morning opes her gold[SEQ_SPLITTER]en gates,
And takes her farewell of the glorious s[SEQ_SPLITTER]un!
How well resembles it the prime of youth,
Trim[SEQ_SPLITTER]m'd like a younker prancing to his love!

EDWARD:
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Dazzle mine eyes, or do I see three suns?

RICHARD[SEQ_SPLITTER]:
Three glorious suns, each one a perfect sun;
Not[SEQ_SPLITTER] separated with the racking clouds,
But sever'd in[SEQ_SPLITTER] a pale clear-shining sky.
See, see! they join, em[SEQ_SPLITTER]brace, and seem to kiss,
As if they vow'd some lea[SEQ_SPLITTER]gue inviolable:
Now are they but one lamp, one lig[SEQ_SPLITTER]ht, one sun.
In this the heaven figures some event[SEQ_SPLITTER].

EDWARD:
'Tis wondrous strange, the like yet nev[SEQ_SPLITTER]er heard of.
I think it cites us, brother, to the [SEQ_SPLITTER]field,
That we, the sons of brave Plantagenet,
Eac[SEQ_SPLITTER]h one already blazing by our meeds,
Should notwith[SEQ_SPLITTER]standing join our lights together
And over-shine t[SEQ_SPLITTER]he earth as this the world.
Whate'er it bodes, hen[SEQ_SPLITTER]ceforward will I bear
Upon my target three fair-sh[SEQ_SPLITTER]ining suns.

RICHARD:
Nay, bear three daughters: b[SEQ_SPLITTER]y your leave I speak it,
You love the breeder bett[SEQ_SPLITTER]er than the male.
But what art thou, whose heavy l[SEQ_SPLITTER]ooks foretell
Some dreadful story hanging on thy t[SEQ_SPLITTER]ongue?

Messenger:
Ah, one that was a woful looker[SEQ_SPLITTER]-on
When as the noble Duke of York was slain,
Your[SEQ_SPLITTER] princely father and my loving lord!

EDWARD:
O, s[SEQ_SPLITTER]peak no more, for I have heard too much.

RICHARD:[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Say how he died, for I will hear it all.

Messeng[SEQ_SPLITTER]er:
Environed he was with many foes,
And stood aga[SEQ_SPLITTER]inst them, as the hope of Troy
Against the Greeks [SEQ_SPLITTER]that would have enter'd Troy.
But Hercules himself[SEQ_SPLITTER] must yield to odds;
And many strokes, though with[SEQ_SPLITTER] a little axe,
Hew down and fell the hardest-timbe[SEQ_SPLITTER]r'd oak.
By many hands your father was subdued;
Bu[SEQ_SPLITTER]t only slaughter'd by the ireful arm
Of unrelentin[SEQ_SPLITTER]g Clifford and the queen,
Who crown'd the gracious[SEQ_SPLITTER] duke in high despite,
Laugh'd in his face; and wh[SEQ_SPLITTER]en with grief he wept,
The ruthless queen gave him[SEQ_SPLITTER] to dry his cheeks
A napkin steeped in the harmles[SEQ_SPLITTER]s blood
Of sweet young Rutland, by rough Clifford [SEQ_SPLITTER]slain:
And after many scorns, many foul taunts,
Th[SEQ_SPLITTER]ey took his head, and on the gates of York
They se[SEQ_SPLITTER]t the same; and there it doth remain,
The saddest [SEQ_SPLITTER]spectacle that e'er I view'd.

EDWARD:
Sweet Duke [SEQ_SPLITTER]of York, our prop to lean upon,
Now thou art gone,[SEQ_SPLITTER] we have no staff, no stay.
O Clifford, boisterous[SEQ_SPLITTER] Clifford! thou hast slain
The flower of Europe fo[SEQ_SPLITTER]r his chivalry;
And treacherously hast thou vanqui[SEQ_SPLITTER]sh'd him,
For hand to hand he would have vanquish'[SEQ_SPLITTER]d thee.
Now my soul's palace is become a prison:
A[SEQ_SPLITTER]h, would she break from hence, that this my body
M[SEQ_SPLITTER]ight in the ground be closed up in rest!
For never[SEQ_SPLITTER] henceforth shall I joy again,
Never, O never shal[SEQ_SPLITTER]l I see more joy!

RICHARD:
I cannot weep; for all[SEQ_SPLITTER] my body's moisture
Scarce serves to quench my fur[SEQ_SPLITTER]nace-burning heart:
Nor can my tongue unload my he[SEQ_SPLITTER]art's great burthen;
For selfsame wind that I shou[SEQ_SPLITTER]ld speak withal
Is kindling coals that fires all m[SEQ_SPLITTER]y breast,
And burns me up with flames that tears w[SEQ_SPLITTER]ould quench.
To weep is to make less the depth of [SEQ_SPLITTER]grief:
Tears then for babes; blows and revenge for[SEQ_SPLITTER] me
Richard, I bear thy name; I'll venge thy death[SEQ_SPLITTER],
Or die renowned by attempting it.

EDWARD:
His n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ame that valiant duke hath left with thee;
His duk[SEQ_SPLITTER]edom and his chair with me is left.

RICHARD:

Show thy d[SEQ_SPLITTER]escent by gazing 'gainst the sun:
For chair and du[SEQ_SPLITTER]kedom, throne and kingdom say;
Either that is thin[SEQ_SPLITTER]e, or else thou wert not his.

WARWICK:

RICHARD:

Our ba[SEQ_SPLITTER]leful news, and at each word's deliverance
Stab po[SEQ_SPLITTER]niards in our flesh till all were told,
The words [SEQ_SPLITTER]would add more anguish than the wounds.
O valiant [SEQ_SPLITTER]lord, the Duke of York is slain!

EDWARD:

Which held three dea[SEQ_SPLITTER]rly as his soul's redemption,
Is by the stern Lord[SEQ_SPLITTER] Clifford done to death.

WARWICK:
Ten days ago I [SEQ_SPLITTER]drown'd these news in tears;
And now, to add more [SEQ_SPLITTER]measure to your woes,
I come to tell you things si[SEQ_SPLITTER]th then befall'n.
After the bloody fray at Wakefie[SEQ_SPLITTER]ld fought,
Where your brave father breathed his la[SEQ_SPLITTER]test gasp,
Tidings, as swiftly as the posts could [SEQ_SPLITTER]run,
Were brought me of your loss and his depart.
[SEQ_SPLITTER]I, then in London keeper of the king,
Muster'd my [SEQ_SPLITTER]soldiers, gather'd flocks of friends,
And very wel[SEQ_SPLITTER]l appointed, as I thought,
March'd toward Saint Al[SEQ_SPLITTER]ban's to intercept the queen,
Bearing the king in [SEQ_SPLITTER]my behalf along;
For by my scouts I was advertised[SEQ_SPLITTER]
That she was coming with a full intent
To dash ou[SEQ_SPLITTER]r late decree in parliament
Touching King Henry's [SEQ_SPLITTER]oath and your succession.
Short tale to make, we a[SEQ_SPLITTER]t Saint Alban's met
Our battles join'd, and both s[SEQ_SPLITTER]ides fiercely fought:
But whether 'twas the coldne[SEQ_SPLITTER]ss of the king,
Who look'd full gently on his warl[SEQ_SPLITTER]ike queen,

Or whether 'twas report of her success;
O[SEQ_SPLITTER]r more than common fear of Clifford's rigour,
Who [SEQ_SPLITTER]thunders to his captives blood and death,
I cannot[SEQ_SPLITTER] judge: but to conclude with truth,
Their weapons [SEQ_SPLITTER]like to lightning came and went;
Our soldiers', li[SEQ_SPLITTER]ke the night-owl's lazy flight,
Or like an idle th[SEQ_SPLITTER]resher with a flail,
Fell gently down, as if they [SEQ_SPLITTER]struck their friends.

But all in vain; they had no heart to f[SEQ_SPLITTER]ight,
And we in them no hope to win the day;

In haste, post-ha[SEQ_SPLITTER]ste, are come to join with you:
For in the marches[SEQ_SPLITTER] here we heard you were,
Making another head to fi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ght again.

Where is the Duke of Norfolk, [SEQ_SPLITTER]gentle Warwick?
And when came George from Burgundy[SEQ_SPLITTER] to England?

But [SEQ_SPLITTER]ne'er till now his scandal of retire.

WARWICK:

As he is famed for mildness, p[SEQ_SPLITTER]eace, and prayer.

RICHARD:

'Tis love I bear thy glories[SEQ_SPLITTER] makes me speak.

WARWICK:

And therefore comes my brother [SEQ_SPLITTER]Montague.

And now to London all the crew are go[SEQ_SPLITTER]ne,

May[SEQ_SPLITTER] make against the house of Lancaster.
Their power,[SEQ_SPLITTER] I think, is thirty thousand strong:
Now, if the h[SEQ_SPLITTER]elp of Norfolk and myself,

But [SEQ_SPLITTER]never once again turn back and fly.

RICHARD:

3 KING[SEQ_SPLITTER] HENRY VI

QUEEN MARGARET:
Welcome, my lord, to th[SEQ_SPLITTER]is brave town of York.
Yonder's the head of that a[SEQ_SPLITTER]rch-enemy
That sought to be encompass'd with your [SEQ_SPLITTER]crown:
Doth not the object cheer your heart, my lo[SEQ_SPLITTER]rd?

KING HENRY VI:
Ay, as the rocks cheer them th[SEQ_SPLITTER]at fear their wreck:
To see this sight, it irks my[SEQ_SPLITTER] very soul.
Withhold revenge, dear God! 'tis not m[SEQ_SPLITTER]y fault,
Nor wittingly have I infringed my vow.

C[SEQ_SPLITTER]LIFFORD:
My gracious liege, this too much lenity
A[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd harmful pity must be laid aside.
To whom do lio[SEQ_SPLITTER]ns cast their gentle looks?
Not to the beast that [SEQ_SPLITTER]would usurp their den.
Whose hand is that the fore[SEQ_SPLITTER]st bear doth lick?
Not his that spoils her young b[SEQ_SPLITTER]efore her face.
Who 'scapes the lurking serpent's [SEQ_SPLITTER]mortal sting?
Not he that sets his foot upon her b[SEQ_SPLITTER]ack.
The smallest worm will turn being trodden on,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
And doves will peck in safeguard of their brood.
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Ambitious York doth level at thy crown,
Thou smili[SEQ_SPLITTER]ng while he knit his angry brows:
He, but a duke, [SEQ_SPLITTER]would have his son a king,
And raise his issue, li[SEQ_SPLITTER]ke a loving sire;
Thou, being a king, blest with a[SEQ_SPLITTER] goodly son,
Didst yield consent to disinherit him[SEQ_SPLITTER],
Which argued thee a most unloving father.
Unreas[SEQ_SPLITTER]onable creatures feed their young;
And though man'[SEQ_SPLITTER]s face be fearful to their eyes,
Yet, in protectio[SEQ_SPLITTER]n of their tender ones,
Who hath not seen them, ev[SEQ_SPLITTER]en with those wings
Which sometime they have used [SEQ_SPLITTER]with fearful flight,
Make war with him that climb'[SEQ_SPLITTER]d unto their nest,
Offer their own lives in their [SEQ_SPLITTER]young's defence?
For shame, my liege, make them yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]ur precedent!
Were it not pity that this goodly bo[SEQ_SPLITTER]y
Should lose his birthright by his father's fault[SEQ_SPLITTER],
And long hereafter say unto his child,
'What my [SEQ_SPLITTER]great-grandfather and his grandsire got
My careles[SEQ_SPLITTER]s father fondly gave away'?
Ah, what a shame were [SEQ_SPLITTER]this! Look on the boy;
And let his manly face, whi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ch promiseth
Successful fortune, steel thy melting[SEQ_SPLITTER] heart
To hold thine own and leave thine own with [SEQ_SPLITTER]him.

KING HENRY VI:
Full well hath Clifford play'[SEQ_SPLITTER]d the orator,
Inferring arguments of mighty force.[SEQ_SPLITTER]
But, Clifford, tell me, didst thou never hear
Tha[SEQ_SPLITTER]t things ill-got had ever bad success?
And happy a[SEQ_SPLITTER]lways was it for that son
Whose father for his hoa[SEQ_SPLITTER]rding went to hell?
I'll leave my son my virtuous [SEQ_SPLITTER]deeds behind;
And would my father had left me no m[SEQ_SPLITTER]ore!
For all the rest is held at such a rate
As br[SEQ_SPLITTER]ings a thousand-fold more care to keep
Than in pos[SEQ_SPLITTER]session and jot of pleasure.
Ah, cousin York! woul[SEQ_SPLITTER]d thy best friends did know
How it doth grieve me [SEQ_SPLITTER]that thy head is here!

QUEEN MARGARET:
My lord, c[SEQ_SPLITTER]heer up your spirits: our foes are nigh,
And this [SEQ_SPLITTER]soft courage makes your followers faint.
You promi[SEQ_SPLITTER]sed knighthood to our forward son:
Unsheathe your [SEQ_SPLITTER]sword, and dub him presently.
Edward, kneel down.

And learn this lesson, draw thy sword in right.

Th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e queen hath best success when you are absent.

Have [SEQ_SPLITTER]caused him, by new act of parliament,

Who should succeed the father but the son?

By him that made us all[SEQ_SPLITTER], I am resolved

There is no wrong, but every thing is[SEQ_SPLITTER] right.

RICHARD:

For, well I wot, thou hast thy mother's[SEQ_SPLITTER] tongue.

QUEEN MARGARET:
But thou art neither lik[SEQ_SPLITTER]e thy sire nor dam;
But like a foul mis-shapen sti[SEQ_SPLITTER]gmatic,
Mark'd by the destinies to be avoided,
As [SEQ_SPLITTER]venom toads, or lizards' dreadful stings.

RICHARD[SEQ_SPLITTER]:
Iron of Naples hid with English gilt,
Whose fath[SEQ_SPLITTER]er bears the title of a king,--
As if a channel sh[SEQ_SPLITTER]ould be call'd the sea,--
Shamest thou not, knowin[SEQ_SPLITTER]g whence thou art extraught,
To let thy tongue det[SEQ_SPLITTER]ect thy base-born heart?

EDWARD:
A wisp of straw [SEQ_SPLITTER]were worth a thousand crowns,
To make this shamele[SEQ_SPLITTER]ss callet know herself.
Helen of Greece was fairer[SEQ_SPLITTER] far than thou,
Although thy husband may be Menela[SEQ_SPLITTER]us;
And ne'er was Agamemnon's brother wrong'd
By t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hat false woman, as this king by thee.
His father [SEQ_SPLITTER]revell'd in the heart of France,
And tamed the kin[SEQ_SPLITTER]g, and made the dauphin stoop;
And had he match'd [SEQ_SPLITTER]according to his state,
He might have kept that gl[SEQ_SPLITTER]ory to this day;
But when he took a beggar to his [SEQ_SPLITTER]bed,
And graced thy poor sire with his bridal-day,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Even then that sunshine brew'd a shower for him,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]That wash'd his father's fortunes forth of France,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
And heap'd sedition on his crown at home.
For wha[SEQ_SPLITTER]t hath broach'd this tumult but thy pride?
Hadst t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hou been meek, our title still had slept;
And we, [SEQ_SPLITTER]in pity of the gentle king,
Had slipp'd our claim [SEQ_SPLITTER]until another age.

GEORGE:
But when we saw our su[SEQ_SPLITTER]nshine made thy spring,
And that thy summer bred u[SEQ_SPLITTER]s no increase,
We set the axe to thy usurping root[SEQ_SPLITTER];
And though the edge hath something hit ourselves[SEQ_SPLITTER],
Yet, know thou, since we have begun to strike,
W[SEQ_SPLITTER]e'll never leave till we have hewn thee down,
Or b[SEQ_SPLITTER]athed thy growing with our heated bloods.

EDWARD:[SEQ_SPLITTER]
And, in this resolution, I defy thee;
Not willing[SEQ_SPLITTER] any longer conference,
Since thou deniest the gen[SEQ_SPLITTER]tle king to speak.
Sound trumpets! let our bloody [SEQ_SPLITTER]colours wave!
And either victory, or else a grave.[SEQ_SPLITTER]

QUEEN MARGARET:
Stay, Edward.

EDWARD:
No, wrang[SEQ_SPLITTER]ling woman, we'll no longer stay:
These words will[SEQ_SPLITTER] cost ten thousand lives this day.
3 KING HENRY VI[SEQ_SPLITTER]

WARWICK:
Forspent with toil, as runners with a r[SEQ_SPLITTER]ace,
I lay me down a little while to breathe;
For [SEQ_SPLITTER]strokes received, and many blows repaid,
Have robb[SEQ_SPLITTER]'d my strong-knit sinews of their strength,
And sp[SEQ_SPLITTER]ite of spite needs must I rest awhile.

EDWARD:
Sm[SEQ_SPLITTER]ile, gentle heaven! or strike, ungentle death!
For[SEQ_SPLITTER] this world frowns, and Edward's sun is clouded.

[SEQ_SPLITTER]WARWICK:

Our ranks are broke, and ruin follows us:
[SEQ_SPLITTER]What counsel give you? whither shall we fly?

EDWA[SEQ_SPLITTER]RD:
Bootless is flight, they follow us with wings;[SEQ_SPLITTER]
And weak we are and cannot shun pursuit.

RICHARD[SEQ_SPLITTER]:

Th[SEQ_SPLITTER]y brother's blood the thirsty earth hath drunk,
Br[SEQ_SPLITTER]oach'd with the steely point of Clifford's lance;
[SEQ_SPLITTER]And in the very pangs of death he cried,

So, underneath the b[SEQ_SPLITTER]elly of their steeds,
That stain'd their fetlocks [SEQ_SPLITTER]in his smoking blood,
The noble gentleman gave up [SEQ_SPLITTER]the ghost.

WARWICK:

I'll kill my horse, because I wil[SEQ_SPLITTER]l not fly.
Why stand we like soft-hearted women he[SEQ_SPLITTER]re,
Wailing our losses, whiles the foe doth rage;
[SEQ_SPLITTER]And look upon, as if the tragedy
Were play'd in je[SEQ_SPLITTER]st by counterfeiting actors?
Here on my knee I vow[SEQ_SPLITTER] to God above,
I'll never pause again, never stand[SEQ_SPLITTER] still,
Till either death hath closed these eyes o[SEQ_SPLITTER]f mine

ED[SEQ_SPLITTER]WARD:

And[SEQ_SPLITTER] in this vow do chain my soul to thine!
And, ere m[SEQ_SPLITTER]y knee rise from the earth's cold face,

And give sweet passage to my sinful soul![SEQ_SPLITTER]

Where[SEQ_SPLITTER]'er it be, in heaven or in earth.

RICHARD:

Let me e[SEQ_SPLITTER]mbrace thee in my weary arms:
I, that did never we[SEQ_SPLITTER]ep, now melt with woe
That winter should cut off o[SEQ_SPLITTER]ur spring-time so.

WARWICK:

And call them pillars that will[SEQ_SPLITTER] stand to us;
And, if we thrive, promise them such[SEQ_SPLITTER] rewards
As victors wear at the Olympian games:
Th[SEQ_SPLITTER]is may plant courage in their quailing breasts;
Fo[SEQ_SPLITTER]r yet is hope of life and victory.
Forslow no long[SEQ_SPLITTER]er, make we hence amain.
3 KING HENRY VI

RICHARD:[SEQ_SPLITTER]

Suppose[SEQ_SPLITTER] this arm is for the Duke of York,
And this for Ru[SEQ_SPLITTER]tland; both bound to revenge,
Wert thou environ'd [SEQ_SPLITTER]with a brazen wall.

CLIFFORD:

This is the hand that stabb'[SEQ_SPLITTER]d thy father York;
And this the hand that slew thy[SEQ_SPLITTER] brother Rutland;
And here's the heart that triump[SEQ_SPLITTER]hs in their death
And cheers these hands that slew[SEQ_SPLITTER] thy sire and brother
To execute the like upon thy[SEQ_SPLITTER]self;
And so, have at thee!

RICHARD:

For I myself will hu[SEQ_SPLITTER]nt this wolf to death.
3 KING HENRY VI

KING HENRY[SEQ_SPLITTER] VI:
This battle fares like to the morning's war,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]When dying clouds contend with growing light,
What[SEQ_SPLITTER] time the shepherd, blowing of his nails,
Can neit[SEQ_SPLITTER]her call it perfect day nor night.
Now sways it th[SEQ_SPLITTER]is way, like a mighty sea
Forced by the tide to co[SEQ_SPLITTER]mbat with the wind;
Now sways it that way, like th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e selfsame sea
Forced to retire by fury of the win[SEQ_SPLITTER]d:
Sometime the flood prevails, and then the wind;[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Now one the better, then another best;
Both tuggi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ng to be victors, breast to breast,
Yet neither co[SEQ_SPLITTER]nqueror nor conquered:
So is the equal of this fel[SEQ_SPLITTER]l war.
Here on this molehill will I sit me down.
T[SEQ_SPLITTER]o whom God will, there be the victory!
For Margare[SEQ_SPLITTER]t my queen, and Clifford too,
Have chid me from th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e battle; swearing both
They prosper best of all w[SEQ_SPLITTER]hen I am thence.
Would I were dead! if God's good [SEQ_SPLITTER]will were so;
For what is in this world but grief [SEQ_SPLITTER]and woe?
O God! methinks it were a happy life,
To [SEQ_SPLITTER]be no better than a homely swain;
To sit upon a hi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll, as I do now,
To carve out dials quaintly, poin[SEQ_SPLITTER]t by point,
Thereby to see the minutes how they ru[SEQ_SPLITTER]n,
How many make the hour full complete;
How many [SEQ_SPLITTER]hours bring about the day;
How many days will fini[SEQ_SPLITTER]sh up the year;
How many years a mortal man may li[SEQ_SPLITTER]ve.
When this is known, then to divide the times:
[SEQ_SPLITTER]So many hours must I tend my flock;
So many hours [SEQ_SPLITTER]must I take my rest;
So many hours must I contempl[SEQ_SPLITTER]ate;
So many hours must I sport myself;
So many da[SEQ_SPLITTER]ys my ewes have been with young;
So many weeks ere[SEQ_SPLITTER] the poor fools will ean:
So many years ere I shal[SEQ_SPLITTER]l shear the fleece:
So minutes, hours, days, month[SEQ_SPLITTER]s, and years,
Pass'd over to the end they were cre[SEQ_SPLITTER]ated,
Would bring white hairs unto a quiet grave.
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Ah, what a life were this! how sweet! how lovely!
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Gives not the hawthorn-bush a sweeter shade
To she[SEQ_SPLITTER]pherds looking on their silly sheep,
Than doth a r[SEQ_SPLITTER]ich embroider'd canopy
To kings that fear their su[SEQ_SPLITTER]bjects' treachery?
O, yes, it doth; a thousand-fol[SEQ_SPLITTER]d it doth.
And to conclude, the shepherd's homely [SEQ_SPLITTER]curds,
His cold thin drink out of his leather bott[SEQ_SPLITTER]le.
His wonted sleep under a fresh tree's shade,
A[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll which secure and sweetly he enjoys,
Is far beyo[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd a prince's delicates,
His viands sparkling in a[SEQ_SPLITTER] golden cup,
His body couched in a curious bed,
Wh[SEQ_SPLITTER]en care, mistrust, and treason waits on him.

Son:[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Ill blows the wind that profits nobody.
This man,[SEQ_SPLITTER] whom hand to hand I slew in fight,
May be possess[SEQ_SPLITTER]ed with some store of crowns;
And I, that haply ta[SEQ_SPLITTER]ke them from him now,
May yet ere night yield both[SEQ_SPLITTER] my life and them
To some man else, as this dead m[SEQ_SPLITTER]an doth me.
Who's this? O God! it is my father's f[SEQ_SPLITTER]ace,
Whom in this conflict I unwares have kill'd.
[SEQ_SPLITTER]O heavy times, begetting such events!
From London [SEQ_SPLITTER]by the king was I press'd forth;
My father, being [SEQ_SPLITTER]the Earl of Warwick's man,
Came on the part of Yor[SEQ_SPLITTER]k, press'd by his master;
And I, who at his hands [SEQ_SPLITTER]received my life, him
Have by my hands of life ber[SEQ_SPLITTER]eaved him.
Pardon me, God, I knew not what I did!
[SEQ_SPLITTER]And pardon, father, for I knew not thee!
My tears [SEQ_SPLITTER]shall wipe away these bloody marks;
And no more wo[SEQ_SPLITTER]rds till they have flow'd their fill.

KING HENRY [SEQ_SPLITTER]VI:
O piteous spectacle! O bloody times!
Whiles li[SEQ_SPLITTER]ons war and battle for their dens,
Poor harmless l[SEQ_SPLITTER]ambs abide their enmity.
Weep, wretched man, I'll [SEQ_SPLITTER]aid thee tear for tear;
And let our hearts and eye[SEQ_SPLITTER]s, like civil war,
Be blind with tears, and break [SEQ_SPLITTER]o'ercharged with grief.

Father:

Give me thy gold, if thou ha[SEQ_SPLITTER]st any gold:
For I have bought it with an hundred [SEQ_SPLITTER]blows.
But let me see: is this our foeman's face?
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Ah, no, no, no, it is mine only son!
Ah, boy, if a[SEQ_SPLITTER]ny life be left in thee,
Throw up thine eye! see, [SEQ_SPLITTER]see what showers arise,
Blown with the windy tempe[SEQ_SPLITTER]st of my heart,
Upon thy words, that kill mine eye[SEQ_SPLITTER] and heart!

What[SEQ_SPLITTER] stratagems, how fell, how butcherly,
Erroneous, m[SEQ_SPLITTER]utinous and unnatural,
This deadly quarrel daily d[SEQ_SPLITTER]oth beget!
O boy, thy father gave thee life too so[SEQ_SPLITTER]on,
And hath bereft thee of thy life too late!

KI[SEQ_SPLITTER]NG HENRY VI:

The one his purple bloo[SEQ_SPLITTER]d right well resembles;
The other his pale cheeks,[SEQ_SPLITTER] methinks, presenteth:
Wither one rose, and let th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e other flourish;
If you contend, a thousand lives[SEQ_SPLITTER] must wither.

KING HENRY VI:

3 KING HENRY VI

CLIFFORD:
Here burns my c[SEQ_SPLITTER]andle out; ay, here it dies,
Which, whiles it last[SEQ_SPLITTER]ed, gave King Henry light.
O Lancaster, I fear thy[SEQ_SPLITTER] overthrow
More than my body's parting with my sou[SEQ_SPLITTER]l!
My love and fear glued many friends to thee;
An[SEQ_SPLITTER]d, now I fall, thy tough commixture melts.
Impairi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ng Henry, strengthening misproud York,
The common [SEQ_SPLITTER]people swarm like summer flies;
And whither fly th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e gnats but to the sun?
And who shines now but Hen[SEQ_SPLITTER]ry's enemies?
O Phoebus, hadst thou never given co[SEQ_SPLITTER]nsent
That Phaethon should cheque thy fiery steeds[SEQ_SPLITTER],
Thy burning car never had scorch'd the earth!
An[SEQ_SPLITTER]d, Henry, hadst thou sway'd as kings should do,
Or[SEQ_SPLITTER] as thy father and his father did,
Giving no groun[SEQ_SPLITTER]d unto the house of York,
They never then had spru[SEQ_SPLITTER]ng like summer flies;
I and ten thousand in this l[SEQ_SPLITTER]uckless realm
Had left no mourning widows for our [SEQ_SPLITTER]death;
And thou this day hadst kept thy chair in p[SEQ_SPLITTER]eace.
For what doth cherish weeds but gentle air?
[SEQ_SPLITTER]And what makes robbers bold but too much lenity?
B[SEQ_SPLITTER]ootless are plaints, and cureless are my wounds;
N[SEQ_SPLITTER]o way to fly, nor strength to hold out flight:
The[SEQ_SPLITTER] foe is merciless, and will not pity;
For at their[SEQ_SPLITTER] hands I have deserved no pity.
The air hath got i[SEQ_SPLITTER]nto my deadly wounds,
And much effuse of blood dot[SEQ_SPLITTER]h make me faint.
Come, York and Richard, Warwick a[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd the rest;
I stabb'd your fathers' bosoms, split[SEQ_SPLITTER] my breast.

And smooth the frowns of war[SEQ_SPLITTER] with peaceful looks.
Some troops pursue the blood[SEQ_SPLITTER]y-minded queen,

And wheresoe'er[SEQ_SPLITTER] he is, he's surely dead.

3[SEQ_SPLITTER] KING HENRY VI

First Keeper:
Under this thick-gro[SEQ_SPLITTER]wn brake we'll shroud ourselves;
For through this [SEQ_SPLITTER]laund anon the deer will come;
And in this covert [SEQ_SPLITTER]will we make our stand,
Culling the principal of a[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll the deer.

Second Keeper:
I'll stay above the h[SEQ_SPLITTER]ill, so both may shoot.

First Keeper:

Will scare the her[SEQ_SPLITTER]d, and so my shoot is lost.
Here stand we both, an[SEQ_SPLITTER]d aim we at the best:
And, for the time shall not [SEQ_SPLITTER]seem tedious,
I'll tell thee what befell me on a d[SEQ_SPLITTER]ay
In this self-place where now we mean to stand.
[SEQ_SPLITTER]

Here comes a man; let's stay till [SEQ_SPLITTER]he be past.

To greet mine own land wit[SEQ_SPLITTER]h my wishful sight.

Thy place is fill'd, thy sceptre wrung [SEQ_SPLITTER]from thee,
Thy balm wash'd off wherewith thou wast[SEQ_SPLITTER] anointed:
No bending knee will call thee Caesar n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ow,
No humble suitors press to speak for right,
No[SEQ_SPLITTER], not a man comes for redress of thee;
For how can[SEQ_SPLITTER] I help them, and not myself?

First Keeper:
Ay, h[SEQ_SPLITTER]ere's a deer whose skin's a keeper's fee:
This is [SEQ_SPLITTER]the quondam king; let's seize upon him.

KING HENRY VI:

And, as I hear, the great commanding Wa[SEQ_SPLITTER]rwick

To wife for Edward: if this news be true,

For Wa[SEQ_SPLITTER]rwick is a subtle orator,
And Lewis a prince soon [SEQ_SPLITTER]won with moving words.
By this account then Margar[SEQ_SPLITTER]et may win him;
For she's a woman to be pitied muc[SEQ_SPLITTER]h:
Her sighs will make a battery in his breast;
He[SEQ_SPLITTER]r tears will pierce into a marble heart;
The tiger[SEQ_SPLITTER] will be mild whiles she doth mourn;
And Nero will[SEQ_SPLITTER] be tainted with remorse,
To hear and see her plai[SEQ_SPLITTER]nts, her brinish tears.

She, on his left side, craving a[SEQ_SPLITTER]id for Henry,
He, on his right, asking a wife for [SEQ_SPLITTER]Edward.
She weeps, and says her Henry is deposed;

That [SEQ_SPLITTER]she, poor wretch, for grief can speak no more;
Whi[SEQ_SPLITTER]les Warwick tells his title, smooths the wrong,
In[SEQ_SPLITTER]ferreth arguments of mighty strength,
And in concl[SEQ_SPLITTER]usion wins the king from her,
With promise of his [SEQ_SPLITTER]sister, and what else,
To strengthen and support K[SEQ_SPLITTER]ing Edward's place.
O Margaret, thus 'twill be; an[SEQ_SPLITTER]d thou, poor soul,
Art then forsaken, as thou went[SEQ_SPLITTER]'st forlorn!

Second Keeper:
Say, what art thou th[SEQ_SPLITTER]at talk'st of kings and queens?

KING HENRY VI:
Mo[SEQ_SPLITTER]re than I seem, and less than I was born to:
A man[SEQ_SPLITTER] at least, for less I should not be;
And men may t[SEQ_SPLITTER]alk of kings, and why not I?

Second Keeper:
Ay, b[SEQ_SPLITTER]ut thou talk'st as if thou wert a king.

KING HENR[SEQ_SPLITTER]Y VI:
Why, so I am, in mind; and that's enough.

S[SEQ_SPLITTER]econd Keeper:
But, if thou be a king, where is thy[SEQ_SPLITTER] crown?

KING HENRY VI:
My crown is in my heart, n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ot on my head;
Not decked with diamonds and Indian[SEQ_SPLITTER] stones,
Nor to be seen: my crown is called conten[SEQ_SPLITTER]t:
A crown it is that seldom kings enjoy.

Second [SEQ_SPLITTER]Keeper:
Well, if you be a king crown'd with conten[SEQ_SPLITTER]t,
Your crown content and you must be contented
To[SEQ_SPLITTER] go along with us; for as we think,
You are the ki[SEQ_SPLITTER]ng King Edward hath deposed;
And we his subjects s[SEQ_SPLITTER]worn in all allegiance
Will apprehend you as his e[SEQ_SPLITTER]nemy.

KING HENRY VI:
But did you never swear, and[SEQ_SPLITTER] break an oath?

Second Keeper:
No, never such an [SEQ_SPLITTER]oath; nor will not now.

KING HENRY VI:
Where did [SEQ_SPLITTER]you dwell when I was King of England?

Second Keep[SEQ_SPLITTER]er:
Here in this country, where we now remain.

KI[SEQ_SPLITTER]NG HENRY VI:
I was anointed king at nine months ol[SEQ_SPLITTER]d;
My father and my grandfather were kings,
And yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]u were sworn true subjects unto me:
And tell me, t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hen, have you not broke your oaths?

First Keeper:[SEQ_SPLITTER]
No;
For we were subjects but while you were king.[SEQ_SPLITTER]

KING HENRY VI:
Why, am I dead? do I not breathe [SEQ_SPLITTER]a man?
Ah, simple men, you know not what you swear[SEQ_SPLITTER]!
Look, as I blow this feather from my face,
And a[SEQ_SPLITTER]s the air blows it to me again,
Obeying with my wi[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd when I do blow,
And yielding to another when it[SEQ_SPLITTER] blows,
Commanded always by the greater gust;
Such[SEQ_SPLITTER] is the lightness of you common men.
But do not br[SEQ_SPLITTER]eak your oaths; for of that sin
My mild entreaty s[SEQ_SPLITTER]hall not make you guilty.
Go where you will, the k[SEQ_SPLITTER]ing shall be commanded;
And be you kings, command,[SEQ_SPLITTER] and I'll obey.

First Keeper:
We are true subject[SEQ_SPLITTER]s to the king, King Edward.

KING HENRY VI:
So wou[SEQ_SPLITTER]ld you be again to Henry,
If he were seated as Kin[SEQ_SPLITTER]g Edward is.

First Keeper:
We charge you, in God'[SEQ_SPLITTER]s name, and the king's,
To go with us unto the off[SEQ_SPLITTER]icers.

KING HENRY VI:
In God's name, lead; your k[SEQ_SPLITTER]ing's name be obey'd:
And what God will, that let [SEQ_SPLITTER]your king perform;
And what he will, I humbly yiel[SEQ_SPLITTER]d unto.
3 KING HENRY VI

KING EDWARD IV:
Brother o[SEQ_SPLITTER]f Gloucester, at Saint Alban's field
This lady's h[SEQ_SPLITTER]usband, Sir Richard Grey, was slain,
His lands the[SEQ_SPLITTER]n seized on by the conqueror:
Her suit is now to r[SEQ_SPLITTER]epossess those lands;
Which we in justice cannot w[SEQ_SPLITTER]ell deny,
Because in quarrel of the house of York
[SEQ_SPLITTER]The worthy gentleman did lose his life.

GLOUCESTE[SEQ_SPLITTER]R:
Your highness shall do well to grant her suit;
[SEQ_SPLITTER]It were dishonour to deny it her.

KING EDWARD IV:[SEQ_SPLITTER]

No if th[SEQ_SPLITTER]ou dost say 'no' to my demand.

And that is more than I will yield unto:
I kno[SEQ_SPLITTER]w I am too mean to be your queen,
And yet too good[SEQ_SPLITTER] to be your concubine.

Have other some: why, 'tis a happy thing
[SEQ_SPLITTER]To be the father unto many sons.
Answer no more, f[SEQ_SPLITTER]or thou shalt be my queen.

Her suit is gran[SEQ_SPLITTER]ted for her husband's lands.

Nobleman:
My graciou[SEQ_SPLITTER]s lord, Henry your foe is taken,
And brought your [SEQ_SPLITTER]prisoner to your palace gate.

KING EDWARD IV:
See[SEQ_SPLITTER] that he be convey'd unto the Tower:
And go we, br[SEQ_SPLITTER]others, to the man that took him,
To question of h[SEQ_SPLITTER]is apprehension.
Widow, go you along. Lords, use h[SEQ_SPLITTER]er honourably.

GLOUCESTER:
Ay, Edward will use wo[SEQ_SPLITTER]men honourably.
Would he were wasted, marrow, bone[SEQ_SPLITTER]s and all,
That from his loins no hopeful branch m[SEQ_SPLITTER]ay spring,
To cross me from the golden time I look[SEQ_SPLITTER] for!
And yet, between my soul's desire and me--
T[SEQ_SPLITTER]he lustful Edward's title buried--
Is Clarence, He[SEQ_SPLITTER]nry, and his son young Edward,
And all the unlook'[SEQ_SPLITTER]d for issue of their bodies,
To take their rooms, [SEQ_SPLITTER]ere I can place myself:
A cold premeditation for m[SEQ_SPLITTER]y purpose!
Why, then, I do but dream on sovereignt[SEQ_SPLITTER]y;
Like one that stands upon a promontory,
And spi[SEQ_SPLITTER]es a far-off shore where he would tread,
Wishing h[SEQ_SPLITTER]is foot were equal with his eye,
And chides the se[SEQ_SPLITTER]a that sunders him from thence,
Saying, he'll lade[SEQ_SPLITTER] it dry to have his way:
So do I wish the crown, b[SEQ_SPLITTER]eing so far off;
And so I chide the means that kee[SEQ_SPLITTER]ps me from it;
And so I say, I'll cut the causes o[SEQ_SPLITTER]ff,
Flattering me with impossibilities.
My eye's t[SEQ_SPLITTER]oo quick, my heart o'erweens too much,
Unless my h[SEQ_SPLITTER]and and strength could equal them.
Well, say there[SEQ_SPLITTER] is no kingdom then for Richard;
What other pleasu[SEQ_SPLITTER]re can the world afford?
I'll make my heaven in a [SEQ_SPLITTER]lady's lap,
And deck my body in gay ornaments,
And[SEQ_SPLITTER] witch sweet ladies with my words and looks.
O mis[SEQ_SPLITTER]erable thought! and more unlikely
Than to accompli[SEQ_SPLITTER]sh twenty golden crowns!
Why, love forswore me in [SEQ_SPLITTER]my mother's womb:
And, for I should not deal in he[SEQ_SPLITTER]r soft laws,
She did corrupt frail nature with som[SEQ_SPLITTER]e bribe,
To shrink mine arm up like a wither'd shr[SEQ_SPLITTER]ub;
To make an envious mountain on my back,
Where [SEQ_SPLITTER]sits deformity to mock my body;
To shape my legs o[SEQ_SPLITTER]f an unequal size;
To disproportion me in every pa[SEQ_SPLITTER]rt,
Like to a chaos, or an unlick'd bear-whelp
Tha[SEQ_SPLITTER]t carries no impression like the dam.
And am I the[SEQ_SPLITTER]n a man to be beloved?
O monstrous fault, to harbo[SEQ_SPLITTER]ur such a thought!
Then, since this earth affords [SEQ_SPLITTER]no joy to me,
But to command, to cheque, to o'erbe[SEQ_SPLITTER]ar such
As are of better person than myself,
I'll [SEQ_SPLITTER]make my heaven to dream upon the crown,
And, while[SEQ_SPLITTER]s I live, to account this world but hell,
Until my[SEQ_SPLITTER] mis-shaped trunk that bears this head
Be round im[SEQ_SPLITTER]paled with a glorious crown.
And yet I know not ho[SEQ_SPLITTER]w to get the crown,
For many lives stand between m[SEQ_SPLITTER]e and home:
And I,--like one lost in a thorny wood[SEQ_SPLITTER],
That rends the thorns and is rent with the thorn[SEQ_SPLITTER]s,
Seeking a way and straying from the way;
Not kn[SEQ_SPLITTER]owing how to find the open air,
But toiling desper[SEQ_SPLITTER]ately to find it out,--
Torment myself to catch th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e English crown:
And from that torment I will free[SEQ_SPLITTER] myself,
Or hew my way out with a bloody axe.
Why,[SEQ_SPLITTER] I can smile, and murder whiles I smile,
And cry '[SEQ_SPLITTER]Content' to that which grieves my heart,
And wet m[SEQ_SPLITTER]y cheeks with artificial tears,
And frame my face [SEQ_SPLITTER]to all occasions.
I'll drown more sailors than the[SEQ_SPLITTER] mermaid shall;
I'll slay more gazers than the bas[SEQ_SPLITTER]ilisk;
I'll play the orator as well as Nestor,
Dec[SEQ_SPLITTER]eive more slily than Ulysses could,
And, like a Si[SEQ_SPLITTER]non, take another Troy.
I can add colours to the c[SEQ_SPLITTER]hameleon,
Change shapes with Proteus for advantage[SEQ_SPLITTER]s,
And set the murderous Machiavel to school.
Can [SEQ_SPLITTER]I do this, and cannot get a crown?
Tut, were it fa[SEQ_SPLITTER]rther off, I'll pluck it down.
3 KING HENRY VI

KI[SEQ_SPLITTER]NG LEWIS XI:
Fair Queen of England, worthy Margare[SEQ_SPLITTER]t,
Sit down with us: it ill befits thy state
And b[SEQ_SPLITTER]irth, that thou shouldst stand while Lewis doth si[SEQ_SPLITTER]t.

QUEEN MARGARET:
No, mighty King of France: now[SEQ_SPLITTER] Margaret
Must strike her sail and learn awhile to[SEQ_SPLITTER] serve
Where kings command. I was, I must confess,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Great Albion's queen in former golden days:
But n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ow mischance hath trod my title down,
And with dis[SEQ_SPLITTER]honour laid me on the ground;
Where I must take li[SEQ_SPLITTER]ke seat unto my fortune,
And to my humble seat con[SEQ_SPLITTER]form myself.

KING LEWIS XI:
Why, say, fair queen,[SEQ_SPLITTER] whence springs this deep despair?

QUEEN MARGARET[SEQ_SPLITTER]:
From such a cause as fills mine eyes with tears
[SEQ_SPLITTER]And stops my tongue, while heart is drown'd in car[SEQ_SPLITTER]es.

KING LEWIS XI:
Whate'er it be, be thou still [SEQ_SPLITTER]like thyself,
And sit thee by our side:
Yield not [SEQ_SPLITTER]thy neck
To fortune's yoke, but let thy dauntless [SEQ_SPLITTER]mind
Still ride in triumph over all mischance.
Be [SEQ_SPLITTER]plain, Queen Margaret, and tell thy grief;
It shal[SEQ_SPLITTER]l be eased, if France can yield relief.

QUEEN MAR[SEQ_SPLITTER]GARET:
Those gracious words revive my drooping tho[SEQ_SPLITTER]ughts
And give my tongue-tied sorrows leave to spe[SEQ_SPLITTER]ak.
Now, therefore, be it known to noble Lewis,
Th[SEQ_SPLITTER]at Henry, sole possessor of my love,
Is of a king [SEQ_SPLITTER]become a banish'd man,
And forced to live in Scotl[SEQ_SPLITTER]and a forlorn;
While proud ambitious Edward Duke o[SEQ_SPLITTER]f York
Usurps the regal title and the seat
Of Engl[SEQ_SPLITTER]and's true-anointed lawful king.
This is the cause[SEQ_SPLITTER] that I, poor Margaret,
With this my son, Prince E[SEQ_SPLITTER]dward, Henry's heir,
Am come to crave thy just and[SEQ_SPLITTER] lawful aid;
And if thou fail us, all our hope is [SEQ_SPLITTER]done:
Scotland hath will to help, but cannot help;[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Our people and our peers are both misled,
Our tre[SEQ_SPLITTER]asures seized, our soldiers put to flight,
And, as[SEQ_SPLITTER] thou seest, ourselves in heavy plight.

KING LEWI[SEQ_SPLITTER]S XI:
Renowned queen, with patience calm the storm[SEQ_SPLITTER],
While we bethink a means to break it off.

QUEEN[SEQ_SPLITTER] MARGARET:
The more we stay, the stronger grows ou[SEQ_SPLITTER]r foe.

KING LEWIS XI:
The more I stay, the more I[SEQ_SPLITTER]'ll succor thee.

QUEEN MARGARET:
O, but impatienc[SEQ_SPLITTER]e waiteth on true sorrow.
And see where comes the [SEQ_SPLITTER]breeder of my sorrow!

KING LEWIS XI:
What's he ap[SEQ_SPLITTER]proacheth boldly to our presence?

QUEEN MARGARET:[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Our Earl of Warwick, Edward's greatest friend.

K[SEQ_SPLITTER]ING LEWIS XI:
Welcome, brave Warwick! What brings [SEQ_SPLITTER]thee to France?

QUEEN MARGARET:
Ay, now begins a [SEQ_SPLITTER]second storm to rise;
For this is he that moves bo[SEQ_SPLITTER]th wind and tide.

WARWICK:
From worthy Edward, Ki[SEQ_SPLITTER]ng of Albion,
My lord and sovereign, and thy vowed[SEQ_SPLITTER] friend,
I come, in kindness and unfeigned love,
F[SEQ_SPLITTER]irst, to do greetings to thy royal person;
And the[SEQ_SPLITTER]n to crave a league of amity;
And lastly, to confi[SEQ_SPLITTER]rm that amity
With a nuptial knot, if thou vouchsa[SEQ_SPLITTER]fe to grant
That virtuous Lady Bona, thy fair sist[SEQ_SPLITTER]er,
To England's king in lawful marriage.

QUEEN M[SEQ_SPLITTER]ARGARET:

WARWICK:

QUEEN MARGARET:
King Lewis and[SEQ_SPLITTER] Lady Bona, hear me speak,
Before you answer Warwi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ck. His demand
Springs not from Edward's well-mean[SEQ_SPLITTER]t honest love,
But from deceit bred by necessity;
[SEQ_SPLITTER]For how can tyrants safely govern home,
Unless abr[SEQ_SPLITTER]oad they purchase great alliance?
To prove him tyr[SEQ_SPLITTER]ant this reason may suffice,
That Henry liveth sti[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll: but were he dead,
Yet here Prince Edward stand[SEQ_SPLITTER]s, King Henry's son.
Look, therefore, Lewis, that [SEQ_SPLITTER]by this league and marriage
Thou draw not on thy d[SEQ_SPLITTER]anger and dishonour;
For though usurpers sway the [SEQ_SPLITTER]rule awhile,
Yet heavens are just, and time suppre[SEQ_SPLITTER]sseth wrongs.

WARWICK:
Injurious Margaret!

PRINC[SEQ_SPLITTER]E EDWARD:
And why not queen?

WARWICK:
Because thy[SEQ_SPLITTER] father Henry did usurp;
And thou no more are prin[SEQ_SPLITTER]ce than she is queen.

OXFORD:
Then Warwick disann[SEQ_SPLITTER]uls great John of Gaunt,
Which did subdue the grea[SEQ_SPLITTER]test part of Spain;
And, after John of Gaunt, Henr[SEQ_SPLITTER]y the Fourth,
Whose wisdom was a mirror to the wis[SEQ_SPLITTER]est;
And, after that wise prince, Henry the Fifth,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Who by his prowess conquered all France:
From the[SEQ_SPLITTER]se our Henry lineally descends.

WARWICK:
Oxford, [SEQ_SPLITTER]how haps it, in this smooth discourse,
You told no[SEQ_SPLITTER]t how Henry the Sixth hath lost
All that which Hen[SEQ_SPLITTER]ry Fifth had gotten?
Methinks these peers of Franc[SEQ_SPLITTER]e should smile at that.
But for the rest, you tell[SEQ_SPLITTER] a pedigree
Of threescore and two years; a silly t[SEQ_SPLITTER]ime
To make prescription for a kingdom's worth.

O[SEQ_SPLITTER]XFORD:
Why, Warwick, canst thou speak against thy [SEQ_SPLITTER]liege,
Whom thou obeyed'st thirty and six years,
A[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd not bewray thy treason with a blush?

WARWICK:
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Can Oxford, that did ever fence the right,
Now buc[SEQ_SPLITTER]kler falsehood with a pedigree?
For shame! leave H[SEQ_SPLITTER]enry, and call Edward king.

OXFORD:

My elder brother, the [SEQ_SPLITTER]Lord Aubrey Vere,
Was done to death? and more than[SEQ_SPLITTER] so, my father,
Even in the downfall of his mellow[SEQ_SPLITTER]'d years,
When nature brought him to the door of d[SEQ_SPLITTER]eath?
No, Warwick, no; while life upholds this arm[SEQ_SPLITTER],
This arm upholds the house of Lancaster.

WARWIC[SEQ_SPLITTER]K:
And I the house of York.

KING LEWIS XI:
Queen [SEQ_SPLITTER]Margaret, Prince Edward, and Oxford,
Vouchsafe, at[SEQ_SPLITTER] our request, to stand aside,
While I use further [SEQ_SPLITTER]conference with Warwick.

QUEEN MARGARET:
Heavens [SEQ_SPLITTER]grant that Warwick's words bewitch him not!

KING [SEQ_SPLITTER]LEWIS XI:

Is Edward your true king? for I were loath[SEQ_SPLITTER]
To link with him that were not lawful chosen.

WA[SEQ_SPLITTER]RWICK:
Thereon I pawn my credit and mine honour.

[SEQ_SPLITTER]KING LEWIS XI:
But is he gracious in the people's [SEQ_SPLITTER]eye?

WARWICK:
The more that Henry was unfortunate[SEQ_SPLITTER].

KING LEWIS XI:

Tell me for truth the measure of his love[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Unto our sister Bona.

WARWICK:
Such it seems
As [SEQ_SPLITTER]may beseem a monarch like himself.
Myself have oft[SEQ_SPLITTER]en heard him say and swear
That this his love was [SEQ_SPLITTER]an eternal plant,
Whereof the root was fix'd in vi[SEQ_SPLITTER]rtue's ground,
The leaves and fruit maintain'd wit[SEQ_SPLITTER]h beauty's sun,
Exempt from envy, but not from dis[SEQ_SPLITTER]dain,
Unless the Lady Bona quit his pain.

KING LE[SEQ_SPLITTER]WIS XI:
Now, sister, let us hear your firm resolve[SEQ_SPLITTER].

BONA:
Your grant, or your denial, shall be mine[SEQ_SPLITTER]:
Yet I confess that often ere this day,
When I ha[SEQ_SPLITTER]ve heard your king's desert recounted,
Mine ear ha[SEQ_SPLITTER]th tempted judgment to desire.

KING LEWIS XI:
The[SEQ_SPLITTER]n, Warwick, thus: our sister shall be Edward's;
An[SEQ_SPLITTER]d now forthwith shall articles be drawn
Touching t[SEQ_SPLITTER]he jointure that your king must make,
Which with h[SEQ_SPLITTER]er dowry shall be counterpoised.

That Bona shall be wife[SEQ_SPLITTER] to the English king.

To Edward, b[SEQ_SPLITTER]ut not to the English king.

From giv[SEQ_SPLITTER]ing aid which late I promised.
Yet shall you have [SEQ_SPLITTER]all kindness at my hand
That your estate requires [SEQ_SPLITTER]and mine can yield.

Where having nothing, nothing[SEQ_SPLITTER] can he lose.

You have a father able to maintain you;
An[SEQ_SPLITTER]d better 'twere you troubled him than France.

KING LEWIS XI:[SEQ_SPLITTER]

And to repair[SEQ_SPLITTER] my honour lost for him,
I here renounce him and r[SEQ_SPLITTER]eturn to Henry.

3 KING HENRY [SEQ_SPLITTER]VI

Yet hasty marriage seldom [SEQ_SPLITTER]proveth well.

3 KING HENRY VI

WARWICK:
Trust me, m[SEQ_SPLITTER]y lord, all hitherto goes well;
The common people [SEQ_SPLITTER]by numbers swarm to us.
But see where Somerset and[SEQ_SPLITTER] Clarence come!
Speak suddenly, my lords, are we a[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll friends?

CLARENCE:
Fear not that, my lord.

WA[SEQ_SPLITTER]RWICK:
Then, gentle Clarence, welcome unto Warwick[SEQ_SPLITTER];
And welcome, Somerset: I hold it cowardice
To re[SEQ_SPLITTER]st mistrustful where a noble heart
Hath pawn'd an [SEQ_SPLITTER]open hand in sign of love;
Else might I think that[SEQ_SPLITTER] Clarence, Edward's brother,
Were but a feigned fr[SEQ_SPLITTER]iend to our proceedings:
But welcome, sweet Claren[SEQ_SPLITTER]ce; my daughter shall be thine.
And now what rests[SEQ_SPLITTER] but, in night's coverture,
Thy brother being care[SEQ_SPLITTER]lessly encamp'd,
His soldiers lurking in the towns[SEQ_SPLITTER] about,
And but attended by a simple guard,
We may[SEQ_SPLITTER] surprise and take him at our pleasure?
Our scouts[SEQ_SPLITTER] have found the adventure very easy:
That as Ulyss[SEQ_SPLITTER]es and stout Diomede
With sleight and manhood stol[SEQ_SPLITTER]e to Rhesus' tents,
And brought from thence the Th[SEQ_SPLITTER]racian fatal steeds,
So we, well cover'd with the [SEQ_SPLITTER]night's black mantle,
At unawares may beat down Ed[SEQ_SPLITTER]ward's guard
And seize himself; I say not, slaught[SEQ_SPLITTER]er him,
For I intend but only to surprise him.
You[SEQ_SPLITTER] that will follow me to this attempt,
Applaud the [SEQ_SPLITTER]name of Henry with your leader.
Why, then, let's o[SEQ_SPLITTER]n our way in silent sort:
For Warwick and his frie[SEQ_SPLITTER]nds, God and Saint George!
3 KING HENRY VI

First [SEQ_SPLITTER]Watchman:
Come on, my masters, each man take his s[SEQ_SPLITTER]tand:
The king by this is set him down to sleep.

[SEQ_SPLITTER]Second Watchman:
What, will he not to bed?

First [SEQ_SPLITTER]Watchman:
Why, no; for he hath made a solemn vow
N[SEQ_SPLITTER]ever to lie and take his natural rest
Till Warwick[SEQ_SPLITTER] or himself be quite suppress'd.

Second Watchman:[SEQ_SPLITTER]
To-morrow then belike shall be the day,
If Warwic[SEQ_SPLITTER]k be so near as men report.

Third Watchman:
But s[SEQ_SPLITTER]ay, I pray, what nobleman is that
That with the ki[SEQ_SPLITTER]ng here resteth in his tent?

First Watchman:
'Tis[SEQ_SPLITTER] the Lord Hastings, the king's chiefest friend.

T[SEQ_SPLITTER]hird Watchman:
O, is it so? But why commands the k[SEQ_SPLITTER]ing
That his chief followers lodge in towns about [SEQ_SPLITTER]him,
While he himself keeps in the cold field?

Se[SEQ_SPLITTER]cond Watchman:
'Tis the more honour, because more [SEQ_SPLITTER]dangerous.

Third Watchman:
Ay, but give me worshi[SEQ_SPLITTER]p and quietness;
I like it better than a dangerous[SEQ_SPLITTER] honour.
If Warwick knew in what estate he stands,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
'Tis to be doubted he would waken him.

First Wat[SEQ_SPLITTER]chman:
Unless our halberds did shut up his passage[SEQ_SPLITTER].

But follow me, and Edward shall be ours.

S[SEQ_SPLITTER]tay, or thou diest!

KING EDWARD IV:
The duke![SEQ_SPLITTER] Why, Warwick, when we parted,
Thou call'dst me ki[SEQ_SPLITTER]ng.

WARWICK:
Ay, but the case is alter'd:
When yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]u disgraced me in my embassade,
Then I degraded yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]u from being king,
And come now to create you Duke[SEQ_SPLITTER] of York.
Alas! how should you govern any kingdom,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
That know not how to use ambassadors,
Nor how to [SEQ_SPLITTER]be contented with one wife,
Nor how to use your br[SEQ_SPLITTER]others brotherly,
Nor how to study for the people'[SEQ_SPLITTER]s welfare,
Nor how to shroud yourself from enemies[SEQ_SPLITTER]?

KING EDWARD IV:

Nay, then I see that Edward needs mu[SEQ_SPLITTER]st down.
Yet, Warwick, in despite of all mischance[SEQ_SPLITTER],
Of thee thyself and all thy complices,
Edward wi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll always bear himself as king:
Though fortune's m[SEQ_SPLITTER]alice overthrow my state,
My mind exceeds the comp[SEQ_SPLITTER]ass of her wheel.

WARWICK:

But Henry now shall wear t[SEQ_SPLITTER]he English crown,
And be true king indeed, thou bu[SEQ_SPLITTER]t the shadow.
My Lord of Somerset, at my request,

Unto my[SEQ_SPLITTER] brother, Archbishop of York.
When I have fought w[SEQ_SPLITTER]ith Pembroke and his fellows,
I'll follow you, and[SEQ_SPLITTER] tell what answer
Lewis and the Lady Bona send to [SEQ_SPLITTER]him.
Now, for a while farewell, good Duke of York.[SEQ_SPLITTER]

What fates impose, that men must[SEQ_SPLITTER] needs abide;
It boots not to resist both wind and[SEQ_SPLITTER] tide.

And see hi[SEQ_SPLITTER]m seated in the regal throne.

There shall I rest secure from force[SEQ_SPLITTER] and fraud.

See how the surly Warwick mans the[SEQ_SPLITTER] wall!

O unbid spite! is sportful Edward[SEQ_SPLITTER] come?
Where slept our scouts, or how are they sed[SEQ_SPLITTER]uced,
That we could hear no news of his repair?

A[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd he shall pardon thee these outrages.

And, ten to one, you'll meet him in the T[SEQ_SPLITTER]ower.

3 KING[SEQ_SPLITTER] HENRY VI

KING EDWARD IV:

For Warwick was a bug tha[SEQ_SPLITTER]t fear'd us all.

That Warwick's bones may keep thine compa[SEQ_SPLITTER]ny.

WARWICK:
Ah, who is nigh? come to me, friend [SEQ_SPLITTER]or foe,
And tell me who is victor, York or Warwick[SEQ_SPLITTER]?
Why ask I that? my mangled body shows,
My blood,[SEQ_SPLITTER] my want of strength, my sick heart shows.
That I [SEQ_SPLITTER]must yield my body to the earth
And, by my fall, t[SEQ_SPLITTER]he conquest to my foe.
Thus yields the cedar to th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e axe's edge,
Whose arms gave shelter to the princ[SEQ_SPLITTER]ely eagle,
Under whose shade the ramping lion slep[SEQ_SPLITTER]t,
Whose top-branch overpeer'd Jove's spreading tr[SEQ_SPLITTER]ee
And kept low shrubs from winter's powerful wind[SEQ_SPLITTER].
These eyes, that now are dimm'd with death's bla[SEQ_SPLITTER]ck veil,
Have been as piercing as the mid-day sun,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
To search the secret treasons of the world:
The w[SEQ_SPLITTER]rinkles in my brows, now filled with blood,
Were l[SEQ_SPLITTER]iken'd oft to kingly sepulchres;
For who lived kin[SEQ_SPLITTER]g, but I could dig his grave?
And who durst mine w[SEQ_SPLITTER]hen Warwick bent his brow?
Lo, now my glory smear'[SEQ_SPLITTER]d in dust and blood!
My parks, my walks, my manors[SEQ_SPLITTER] that I had.
Even now forsake me, and of all my la[SEQ_SPLITTER]nds
Is nothing left me but my body's length.
Why, [SEQ_SPLITTER]what is pomp, rule, reign, but earth and dust?
And[SEQ_SPLITTER], live we how we can, yet die we must.

SOMERSET:

We migh[SEQ_SPLITTER]t recover all our loss again;

WARWICK:

Thou lovest me not; for, b[SEQ_SPLITTER]rother, if thou didst,

That glues my lips and will no[SEQ_SPLITTER]t let me speak.

SOMERSET:

And to the latest gasp cried out for Wa[SEQ_SPLITTER]rwick,
And said 'Commend me to my valiant brother.[SEQ_SPLITTER]'
And more he would have said, and more he spoke,

That moug[SEQ_SPLITTER]ht not be distinguished; but at last

3 KING HENRY VI

KING EDW[SEQ_SPLITTER]ARD IV:
Thus far our fortune keeps an upward cours[SEQ_SPLITTER]e,
And we are graced with wreaths of victory.
But,[SEQ_SPLITTER] in the midst of this bright-shining day,
I spy a [SEQ_SPLITTER]black, suspicious, threatening cloud,
That will en[SEQ_SPLITTER]counter with our glorious sun,
Ere he attain his e[SEQ_SPLITTER]aseful western bed:
I mean, my lords, those powers[SEQ_SPLITTER] that the queen
Hath raised in Gallia have arrived[SEQ_SPLITTER] our coast
And, as we hear, march on to fight with[SEQ_SPLITTER] us.

CLARENCE:
A little gale will soon disperse t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hat cloud
And blow it to the source from whence it[SEQ_SPLITTER] came:
The very beams will dry those vapours up,
F[SEQ_SPLITTER]or every cloud engenders not a storm.

GLOUCESTER:[SEQ_SPLITTER]
The queen is valued thirty thousand strong,
And S[SEQ_SPLITTER]omerset, with Oxford fled to her:
If she have time[SEQ_SPLITTER] to breathe be well assured
Her faction will be fu[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll as strong as ours.

KING EDWARD IV:

That they do hold the[SEQ_SPLITTER]ir course toward Tewksbury:
We, having now the bes[SEQ_SPLITTER]t at Barnet field,
Will thither straight, for will[SEQ_SPLITTER]ingness rids way;
And, as we march, our strength w[SEQ_SPLITTER]ill be augmented
In every county as we go along.
S[SEQ_SPLITTER]trike up the drum; cry 'Courage!' and away.
3 KING[SEQ_SPLITTER] HENRY VI

QUEEN MARGARET:
Great lords, wise men n[SEQ_SPLITTER]e'er sit and wail their loss,
But cheerly seek how[SEQ_SPLITTER] to redress their harms.
What though the mast be n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ow blown overboard,
The cable broke, the holding-a[SEQ_SPLITTER]nchor lost,
And half our sailors swallow'd in the [SEQ_SPLITTER]flood?
Yet lives our pilot still. Is't meet that h[SEQ_SPLITTER]e
Should leave the helm and like a fearful lad
Wit[SEQ_SPLITTER]h tearful eyes add water to the sea
And give more [SEQ_SPLITTER]strength to that which hath too much,
Whiles, in h[SEQ_SPLITTER]is moan, the ship splits on the rock,
Which indust[SEQ_SPLITTER]ry and courage might have saved?
Ah, what a shame![SEQ_SPLITTER] ah, what a fault were this!
Say Warwick was our a[SEQ_SPLITTER]nchor; what of that?
And Montague our topmost; wha[SEQ_SPLITTER]t of him?
Our slaughter'd friends the tackles; wha[SEQ_SPLITTER]t of these?
Why, is not Oxford here another anchor[SEQ_SPLITTER]?
And Somerset another goodly mast?
The friends of[SEQ_SPLITTER] France our shrouds and tacklings?
And, though uns[SEQ_SPLITTER]kilful, why not Ned and I
For once allow'd the ski[SEQ_SPLITTER]lful pilot's charge?
We will not from the helm to [SEQ_SPLITTER]sit and weep,
But keep our course, though the roug[SEQ_SPLITTER]h wind say no,
From shelves and rocks that threate[SEQ_SPLITTER]n us with wreck.
As good to chide the waves as spe[SEQ_SPLITTER]ak them fair.
And what is Edward but ruthless sea?[SEQ_SPLITTER]
What Clarence but a quicksand of deceit?
And Rich[SEQ_SPLITTER]ard but a ragged fatal rock?
All these the enemies[SEQ_SPLITTER] to our poor bark.
Say you can swim; alas, 'tis bu[SEQ_SPLITTER]t a while!
Tread on the sand; why, there you quick[SEQ_SPLITTER]ly sink:
Bestride the rock; the tide will wash you[SEQ_SPLITTER] off,
Or else you famish; that's a threefold death[SEQ_SPLITTER].
This speak I, lords, to let you understand,
If c[SEQ_SPLITTER]ase some one of you would fly from us,
That there'[SEQ_SPLITTER]s no hoped-for mercy with the brothers
More than w[SEQ_SPLITTER]ith ruthless waves, with sands and rocks.
Why, cou[SEQ_SPLITTER]rage then! what cannot be avoided
'Twere childish [SEQ_SPLITTER]weakness to lament or fear.

PRINCE EDWARD:
Methin[SEQ_SPLITTER]ks a woman of this valiant spirit
Should, if a cow[SEQ_SPLITTER]ard heard her speak these words,
Infuse his breast[SEQ_SPLITTER] with magnanimity
And make him, naked, foil a man [SEQ_SPLITTER]at arms.

For[SEQ_SPLITTER] did I but suspect a fearful man
He should have le[SEQ_SPLITTER]ave to go away betimes,
Lest in our need he might [SEQ_SPLITTER]infect another
And make him of like spirit to hims[SEQ_SPLITTER]elf.

Let him[SEQ_SPLITTER] depart before we need his help.

Be valiant and give signal to the fight.

And I[SEQ_SPLITTER] will speak, that so my heart may burst.

3 KING HENRY VI

G[SEQ_SPLITTER]LOUCESTER:
Good day, my lord. What, at your book s[SEQ_SPLITTER]o hard?

KING HENRY VI:
Ay, my good lord:--my lord[SEQ_SPLITTER], I should say rather;
'Tis sin to flatter; 'good'[SEQ_SPLITTER] was little better:
'Good Gloucester' and 'good de[SEQ_SPLITTER]vil' were alike,
And both preposterous; therefore,[SEQ_SPLITTER] not 'good lord.'

GLOUCESTER:
Sirrah, leave us to[SEQ_SPLITTER] ourselves: we must confer.

KING HENRY VI:
So fli[SEQ_SPLITTER]es the reckless shepherd from the wolf;
So first t[SEQ_SPLITTER]he harmless sheep doth yield his fleece
And next h[SEQ_SPLITTER]is throat unto the butcher's knife.
What scene of [SEQ_SPLITTER]death hath Roscius now to act?

GLOUCESTER:
Suspic[SEQ_SPLITTER]ion always haunts the guilty mind;
The thief doth [SEQ_SPLITTER]fear each bush an officer.

KING HENRY VI:
The bir[SEQ_SPLITTER]d that hath been limed in a bush,
With trembling w[SEQ_SPLITTER]ings misdoubteth every bush;
And I, the hapless ma[SEQ_SPLITTER]le to one sweet bird,
Have now the fatal object in[SEQ_SPLITTER] my eye
Where my poor young was limed, was caught [SEQ_SPLITTER]and kill'd.

GLOUCESTER:
Why, what a peevish fool [SEQ_SPLITTER]was that of Crete,
That taught his son the office [SEQ_SPLITTER]of a fowl!
An yet, for all his wings, the fool was[SEQ_SPLITTER] drown'd.

KING HENRY VI:
I, Daedalus; my poor boy[SEQ_SPLITTER], Icarus;
Thy father, Minos, that denied our cours[SEQ_SPLITTER]e;
The sun that sear'd the wings of my sweet boy
T[SEQ_SPLITTER]hy brother Edward, and thyself the sea
Whose envio[SEQ_SPLITTER]us gulf did swallow up his life.
Ah, kill me with [SEQ_SPLITTER]thy weapon, not with words!
My breast can better b[SEQ_SPLITTER]rook thy dagger's point
Than can my ears that trag[SEQ_SPLITTER]ic history.
But wherefore dost thou come? is't for[SEQ_SPLITTER] my life?

GLOUCESTER:
Think'st thou I am an execu[SEQ_SPLITTER]tioner?

KING HENRY VI:
A persecutor, I am sure, t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hou art:
If murdering innocents be executing,
Why,[SEQ_SPLITTER] then thou art an executioner.

GLOUCESTER:
Thy so[SEQ_SPLITTER]n I kill'd for his presumption.

KING HENRY VI:
Ha[SEQ_SPLITTER]dst thou been kill'd when first thou didst presume[SEQ_SPLITTER],
Thou hadst not lived to kill a son of mine.
And [SEQ_SPLITTER]thus I prophesy, that many a thousand,
Which now m[SEQ_SPLITTER]istrust no parcel of my fear,
And many an old man'[SEQ_SPLITTER]s sigh and many a widow's,
And many an orphan's wa[SEQ_SPLITTER]ter-standing eye--
Men for their sons, wives for t[SEQ_SPLITTER]heir husbands,
And orphans for their parents timel[SEQ_SPLITTER]ess death--
Shall rue the hour that ever thou wast[SEQ_SPLITTER] born.
The owl shriek'd at thy birth,--an evil sig[SEQ_SPLITTER]n;
The night-crow cried, aboding luckless time;
Do[SEQ_SPLITTER]gs howl'd, and hideous tempest shook down trees;
T[SEQ_SPLITTER]he raven rook'd her on the chimney's top,
And chat[SEQ_SPLITTER]tering pies in dismal discords sung.
Thy mother fe[SEQ_SPLITTER]lt more than a mother's pain,
And, yet brought for[SEQ_SPLITTER]th less than a mother's hope,
To wit, an indigeste[SEQ_SPLITTER]d and deformed lump,
Not like the fruit of such a [SEQ_SPLITTER]goodly tree.
Teeth hadst thou in thy head when tho[SEQ_SPLITTER]u wast born,
To signify thou camest to bite the wo[SEQ_SPLITTER]rld:
And, if the rest be true which I have heard,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Thou camest--

GLOUCESTER:
I'll hear no more: die,[SEQ_SPLITTER] prophet in thy speech:
For this amongst the rest,[SEQ_SPLITTER] was I ordain'd.

KING HENRY VI:
Ay, and for much [SEQ_SPLITTER]more slaughter after this.
God forgive my sins, an[SEQ_SPLITTER]d pardon thee!

GLOUCESTER:
What, will the aspirin[SEQ_SPLITTER]g blood of Lancaster
Sink in the ground? I thought[SEQ_SPLITTER] it would have mounted.
See how my sword weeps for[SEQ_SPLITTER] the poor king's death!
O, may such purple tears b[SEQ_SPLITTER]e alway shed
From those that wish the downfall of [SEQ_SPLITTER]our house!
If any spark of life be yet remaining,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Down, down to hell; and say I sent thee thither:
I[SEQ_SPLITTER], that have neither pity, love, nor fear.
Indeed, [SEQ_SPLITTER]'tis true that Henry told me of;
For I have often [SEQ_SPLITTER]heard my mother say
I came into the world with my [SEQ_SPLITTER]legs forward:
Had I not reason, think ye, to make [SEQ_SPLITTER]haste,
And seek their ruin that usurp'd our right?[SEQ_SPLITTER]
The midwife wonder'd and the women cried
'O, Jesu[SEQ_SPLITTER]s bless us, he is born with teeth!'
And so I was; [SEQ_SPLITTER]which plainly signified
That I should snarl and bi[SEQ_SPLITTER]te and play the dog.
Then, since the heavens have [SEQ_SPLITTER]shaped my body so,
Let hell make crook'd my mind t[SEQ_SPLITTER]o answer it.
I have no brother, I am like no broth[SEQ_SPLITTER]er;
And this word 'love,' which graybeards call di[SEQ_SPLITTER]vine,
Be resident in men like one another
And not [SEQ_SPLITTER]in me: I am myself alone.
Clarence, beware; thou k[SEQ_SPLITTER]eep'st me from the light:
But I will sort a pitchy[SEQ_SPLITTER] day for thee;
For I will buz abroad such propheci[SEQ_SPLITTER]es
That Edward shall be fearful of his life,
And t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hen, to purge his fear, I'll be thy death.
King He[SEQ_SPLITTER]nry and the prince his son are gone:
Clarence, thy[SEQ_SPLITTER] turn is next, and then the rest,
Counting myself [SEQ_SPLITTER]but bad till I be best.
I'll throw thy body in ano[SEQ_SPLITTER]ther room
And triumph, Henry, in thy day of doom.
[SEQ_SPLITTER]3 KING HENRY VI

KING EDWARD IV:
Once more we sit [SEQ_SPLITTER]in England's royal throne,
Re-purchased with the b[SEQ_SPLITTER]lood of enemies.
What valiant foemen, like to autu[SEQ_SPLITTER]mn's corn,
Have we mow'd down, in tops of all thei[SEQ_SPLITTER]r pride!
Three Dukes of Somerset, threefold renown[SEQ_SPLITTER]'d
For hardy and undoubted champions;
Two Clifford[SEQ_SPLITTER]s, as the father and the son,
And two Northumberla[SEQ_SPLITTER]nds; two braver men
Ne'er spurr'd their coursers a[SEQ_SPLITTER]t the trumpet's sound;
With them, the two brave be[SEQ_SPLITTER]ars, Warwick and Montague,
That in their chains fe[SEQ_SPLITTER]tter'd the kingly lion
And made the forest tremble[SEQ_SPLITTER] when they roar'd.
Thus have we swept suspicion fr[SEQ_SPLITTER]om our seat
And made our footstool of security.
Co[SEQ_SPLITTER]me hither, Bess, and let me kiss my boy.
Young Ned[SEQ_SPLITTER], for thee, thine uncles and myself
Have in our ar[SEQ_SPLITTER]mours watch'd the winter's night,
Went all afoot i[SEQ_SPLITTER]n summer's scalding heat,
That thou mightst reposs[SEQ_SPLITTER]ess the crown in peace;
And of our labours thou sh[SEQ_SPLITTER]alt reap the gain.

GLOUCESTER:

KING EDWARD IV:
C[SEQ_SPLITTER]larence and Gloucester, love my lovely queen;
And [SEQ_SPLITTER]kiss your princely nephew, brothers both.

CLARENC[SEQ_SPLITTER]E:
The duty that I owe unto your majesty
I seal up[SEQ_SPLITTER]on the lips of this sweet babe.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Thanks, noble Clarence; worthy brother, thanks.

G[SEQ_SPLITTER]LOUCESTER:
And, that I love the tree from whence t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hou sprang'st,
Witness the loving kiss I give the [SEQ_SPLITTER]fruit.

KING EDWARD IV:
Now am I seated as my soul[SEQ_SPLITTER] delights,
Having my country's peace and brothers'[SEQ_SPLITTER] loves.

CLARENCE:
What will your grace have done [SEQ_SPLITTER]with Margaret?
Reignier, her father, to the king o[SEQ_SPLITTER]f France
Hath pawn'd the Sicils and Jerusalem,
And[SEQ_SPLITTER] hither have they sent it for her ransom.

KING ED[SEQ_SPLITTER]WARD IV:
Away with her, and waft her hence to Fran[SEQ_SPLITTER]ce.
And now what rests but that we spend the time
[SEQ_SPLITTER]With stately triumphs, mirthful comic shows,
Such [SEQ_SPLITTER]as befits the pleasure of the court?
Sound drums a[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd trumpets! farewell sour annoy!
For here, I hope[SEQ_SPLITTER], begins our lasting joy.

ARCHIDAMUS:
If you shal[SEQ_SPLITTER]l chance, Camillo, to visit Bohemia, on
the like o[SEQ_SPLITTER]ccasion whereon my services are now on
foot, you s[SEQ_SPLITTER]hall see, as I have said, great
difference betwixt[SEQ_SPLITTER] our Bohemia and your Sicilia.

CAMILLO:
I think, [SEQ_SPLITTER]this coming summer, the King of Sicilia
means to p[SEQ_SPLITTER]ay Bohemia the visitation which he justly owes him[SEQ_SPLITTER].

ARCHIDAMUS:
Wherein our entertainment shall sha[SEQ_SPLITTER]me us we will be
justified in our loves; for indee[SEQ_SPLITTER]d--

CAMILLO:
Beseech you,--

ARCHIDAMUS:
Verily, [SEQ_SPLITTER]I speak it in the freedom of my knowledge:
we cann[SEQ_SPLITTER]ot with such magnificence--in so rare--I know
not [SEQ_SPLITTER]what to say. We will give you sleepy drinks,
that [SEQ_SPLITTER]your senses, unintelligent of our insufficience,
m[SEQ_SPLITTER]ay, though they cannot praise us, as little accuse[SEQ_SPLITTER]
us.

CAMILLO:
You pay a great deal too dear for w[SEQ_SPLITTER]hat's given freely.

ARCHIDAMUS:
Believe me, I spe[SEQ_SPLITTER]ak as my understanding instructs me
and as mine ho[SEQ_SPLITTER]nesty puts it to utterance.

CAMILLO:
Sicilia cann[SEQ_SPLITTER]ot show himself over-kind to Bohemia.
They were tr[SEQ_SPLITTER]ained together in their childhoods; and
there root[SEQ_SPLITTER]ed betwixt them then such an affection,
which cann[SEQ_SPLITTER]ot choose but branch now. Since their
more mature [SEQ_SPLITTER]dignities and royal necessities made
separation of[SEQ_SPLITTER] their society, their encounters,
though not perso[SEQ_SPLITTER]nal, have been royally attorneyed
with interchange[SEQ_SPLITTER] of gifts, letters, loving
embassies; that they ha[SEQ_SPLITTER]ve seemed to be together,
though absent, shook han[SEQ_SPLITTER]ds, as over a vast, and
embraced, as it were, from[SEQ_SPLITTER] the ends of opposed
winds. The heavens continue t[SEQ_SPLITTER]heir loves!

ARCHIDAMUS:
I think there is not in t[SEQ_SPLITTER]he world either malice or

CAMILLO:
I very we[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll agree with you in the hopes of him: it

subject, m[SEQ_SPLITTER]akes old hearts fresh: they that went on

ARCHIDAMUS:
Would they else be content to d[SEQ_SPLITTER]ie?

CAMILLO:
Yes; if there were no other excuse w[SEQ_SPLITTER]hy they should
desire to live.

ARCHIDAMUS:
If the[SEQ_SPLITTER] king had no son, they would desire to live
on cru[SEQ_SPLITTER]tches till he had one.

POLIXENES:
Nine changes of[SEQ_SPLITTER] the watery star hath been
The shepherd's note sin[SEQ_SPLITTER]ce we have left our throne
Without a burthen: time[SEQ_SPLITTER] as long again
Would be find up, my brother, with [SEQ_SPLITTER]our thanks;
And yet we should, for perpetuity,
Go [SEQ_SPLITTER]hence in debt: and therefore, like a cipher,
Yet s[SEQ_SPLITTER]tanding in rich place, I multiply
With one 'We tha[SEQ_SPLITTER]nk you' many thousands moe
That go before it.

LEO[SEQ_SPLITTER]NTES:
Stay your thanks a while;
And pay them when [SEQ_SPLITTER]you part.

POLIXENES:
Sir, that's to-morrow.
I am [SEQ_SPLITTER]question'd by my fears, of what may chance
Or bree[SEQ_SPLITTER]d upon our absence; that may blow
No sneaping wind[SEQ_SPLITTER]s at home, to make us say
'This is put forth too t[SEQ_SPLITTER]ruly:' besides, I have stay'd
To tire your royalty[SEQ_SPLITTER].

LEONTES:
We are tougher, brother,
Than you can [SEQ_SPLITTER]put us to't.

POLIXENES:
No longer stay.

LEONTES:[SEQ_SPLITTER]
One seven-night longer.

POLIXENES:
Very sooth, t[SEQ_SPLITTER]o-morrow.

LEONTES:
We'll part the time between's [SEQ_SPLITTER]then; and in that
I'll no gainsaying.

POLIXENES:

There is no tongue [SEQ_SPLITTER]that moves, none, none i' the world,
So soon as yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]urs could win me: so it should now,

'Twere needful I [SEQ_SPLITTER]denied it. My affairs
Do even drag me homeward: wh[SEQ_SPLITTER]ich to hinder

To you a charge and trouble: to save both,
Far[SEQ_SPLITTER]ewell, our brother.

speak you.

HERMIONE:

Charge him too coldly. [SEQ_SPLITTER]Tell him, you are sure

The by-gone day proclaim'd: say this[SEQ_SPLITTER] to him,
He's beat from his best ward.

LEONTES:
W[SEQ_SPLITTER]ell said, Hermione.

HERMIONE:
To tell, he longs t[SEQ_SPLITTER]o see his son, were strong:
But let him say so the[SEQ_SPLITTER]n, and let him go;
But let him swear so, and he sh[SEQ_SPLITTER]all not stay,
We'll thwack him hence with distaffs[SEQ_SPLITTER].

PO[SEQ_SPLITTER]LIXENES:

POLIXENES:
I may not, verily.

HERMIONE:
Verily!
[SEQ_SPLITTER]You put me off with limber vows; but I,
Though you[SEQ_SPLITTER] would seek to unsphere the
stars with oaths,
Shou[SEQ_SPLITTER]ld yet say 'Sir, no going.' Verily,
You shall not [SEQ_SPLITTER]go: a lady's 'Verily' 's
As potent as a lord's. Wi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll you go yet?
Force me to keep you as a prisoner,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Not like a guest; so you shall pay your fees
When[SEQ_SPLITTER] you depart, and save your thanks. How say you?
My[SEQ_SPLITTER] prisoner? or my guest? by your dread 'Verily,'
On[SEQ_SPLITTER]e of them you shall be.

POLIXENES:
Your guest, th[SEQ_SPLITTER]en, madam:
To be your prisoner should import offen[SEQ_SPLITTER]ding;
Which is for me less easy to commit
Than you[SEQ_SPLITTER] to punish.

HERMIONE:
Not your gaoler, then,
But [SEQ_SPLITTER]your kind hostess. Come, I'll question you
Of my l[SEQ_SPLITTER]ord's tricks and yours when you were boys:
You wer[SEQ_SPLITTER]e pretty lordings then?

POLIXENES:
We were, fair [SEQ_SPLITTER]queen,
Two lads that thought there was no more beh[SEQ_SPLITTER]ind
But such a day to-morrow as to-day,
And to be [SEQ_SPLITTER]boy eternal.

HERMIONE:
Was not my lord
The verier[SEQ_SPLITTER] wag o' the two?

POLIXENES:
We were as twinn'd la[SEQ_SPLITTER]mbs that did frisk i' the sun,
And bleat the one a[SEQ_SPLITTER]t the other: what we changed
Was innocence for inn[SEQ_SPLITTER]ocence; we knew not
The doctrine of ill-doing, nor[SEQ_SPLITTER] dream'd
That any did. Had we pursued that life,
A[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd our weak spirits ne'er been higher rear'd
With [SEQ_SPLITTER]stronger blood, we should have answer'd heaven
Bol[SEQ_SPLITTER]dly 'not guilty;' the imposition clear'd
Hereditar[SEQ_SPLITTER]y ours.

HERMIONE:

You have trip[SEQ_SPLITTER]p'd since.

POLIXENES:
O my most sacred lady!
Temp[SEQ_SPLITTER]tations have since then been born to's; for
In tho[SEQ_SPLITTER]se unfledged days was my wife a girl;
Your preciou[SEQ_SPLITTER]s self had then not cross'd the eyes

HERMIONE:
Grace to boot!
Of this make[SEQ_SPLITTER] no conclusion, lest you say

I' fecks!

We must be [SEQ_SPLITTER]neat; not neat, but cleanly, captain:

HE[SEQ_SPLITTER]RMIONE:
He something seems unsettled.

LEON[SEQ_SPLITTER]TES:
No, in good earnest.
How sometimes nature wil[SEQ_SPLITTER]l betray its folly,
Its tenderness, and make itsel[SEQ_SPLITTER]f a pastime

No, my lord, I'll fight.

He's all my exerc[SEQ_SPLITTER]ise, my mirth, my matter,

My parasite, my soldier, statesma[SEQ_SPLITTER]n, all:
He makes a July's day short as December,
A[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd with his varying childness cures in me

How [SEQ_SPLITTER]she holds up the neb, the bill to him!
And arms he[SEQ_SPLITTER]r with the boldness of a wife
To her allowing husb[SEQ_SPLITTER]and!
Gone already!
Inch-thick, knee-deep, o'er hea[SEQ_SPLITTER]d and
ears a fork'd one!

Play too, but so disgraced a p[SEQ_SPLITTER]art, whose issue
Will hiss me to my grave: contemp[SEQ_SPLITTER]t and clamour
Will be my knell. Go, play, boy, pla[SEQ_SPLITTER]y.
There have been,
Or I am much deceived, cuckold[SEQ_SPLITTER]s ere now;
And many a man there is, even at this p[SEQ_SPLITTER]resent,
Now while I speak this, holds his wife by [SEQ_SPLITTER]the arm,
That little thinks she has been sluiced i[SEQ_SPLITTER]n's absence
And his pond fish'd by his next neighb[SEQ_SPLITTER]our, by
Sir Smile, his neighbour: nay, there's com[SEQ_SPLITTER]fort in't
Whiles other men have gates and those ga[SEQ_SPLITTER]tes open'd,
As mine, against their will. Should al[SEQ_SPLITTER]l despair
That have revolted wives, the tenth of m[SEQ_SPLITTER]ankind
Would hang themselves. Physic for't there i[SEQ_SPLITTER]s none;
It is a bawdy planet, that will strike
Whe[SEQ_SPLITTER]re 'tis predominant; and 'tis powerful, think it,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]From east, west, north and south: be it concluded,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
No barricado for a belly; know't;
It will let in [SEQ_SPLITTER]and out the enemy
With bag and baggage: many thous[SEQ_SPLITTER]and on's
Have the disease, and feel't not. How now[SEQ_SPLITTER], boy!

Praise her but for thi[SEQ_SPLITTER]s her without-door form,
Which on my faith deserve[SEQ_SPLITTER]s high speech, and straight
The shrug, the hum or [SEQ_SPLITTER]ha, these petty brands
That calumny doth use--O, I[SEQ_SPLITTER] am out--
That mercy does, for calumny will sear
V[SEQ_SPLITTER]irtue itself: these shrugs, these hums and ha's,
W[SEQ_SPLITTER]hen you have said 'she's goodly,' come between
Ere[SEQ_SPLITTER] you can say 'she's honest:' but be 't known,
From[SEQ_SPLITTER] him that has most cause to grieve it should be,
S[SEQ_SPLITTER]he's an adulteress.

Should a villain sa[SEQ_SPLITTER]y so,

I am gone for ever.

Shepherd:
I would th[SEQ_SPLITTER]ere were no age between sixteen and

best sheep, wh[SEQ_SPLITTER]ich I fear the wolf will sooner find
than the mast[SEQ_SPLITTER]er: if any where I have them, 'tis by

will what[SEQ_SPLITTER] have we here! Mercy on 's, a barne a very
pretty [SEQ_SPLITTER]barne! A boy or a child, I wonder? A

Time:
I[SEQ_SPLITTER], that please some, try all, both joy and terror

Now seems to it. Your patience this allowi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ng,

If ever you have spent time worse ere now;
[SEQ_SPLITTER]If never, yet that Time himself doth say
He wishes[SEQ_SPLITTER] earnestly you never may.

AUTOLYCUS:
When daffod[SEQ_SPLITTER]ils begin to peer,
With heigh! the doxy over the d[SEQ_SPLITTER]ale,
Why, then comes in the sweet o' the year;
For[SEQ_SPLITTER] the red blood reigns in the winter's pale.
The wh[SEQ_SPLITTER]ite sheet bleaching on the hedge,
With heigh! the [SEQ_SPLITTER]sweet birds, O, how they sing!
Doth set my pugging[SEQ_SPLITTER] tooth on edge;
For a quart of ale is a dish for a[SEQ_SPLITTER] king.
The lark, that tirra-lyra chants,
With heig[SEQ_SPLITTER]h! with heigh! the thrush and the jay,
Are summer [SEQ_SPLITTER]songs for me and my aunts,
While we lie tumbling i[SEQ_SPLITTER]n the hay.
I have served Prince Florizel and in my[SEQ_SPLITTER] time
wore three-pile; but now I am out of service[SEQ_SPLITTER]:
But shall I go mourn for that, my dear?
The pale[SEQ_SPLITTER] moon shines by night:
And when I wander here and [SEQ_SPLITTER]there,
I then do most go right.
If tinkers may hav[SEQ_SPLITTER]e leave to live,
And bear the sow-skin budget,
The[SEQ_SPLITTER]n my account I well may, give,
And in the stocks a[SEQ_SPLITTER]vouch it.
My traffic is sheets; when the kite buil[SEQ_SPLITTER]ds, look to
lesser linen. My father named me Autol[SEQ_SPLITTER]ycus; who
being, as I am, littered under Mercury, [SEQ_SPLITTER]was likewise
a snapper-up of unconsidered trifles.[SEQ_SPLITTER] With die and
drab I purchased this caparison, and[SEQ_SPLITTER] my revenue is
the silly cheat. Gallows and knock [SEQ_SPLITTER]are too powerful
on the highway: beating and hangi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ng are terrors to
me: for the life to come, I slee[SEQ_SPLITTER]p out the thought
of it. A prize! a prize!

Apprehend

Humbling their deities[SEQ_SPLITTER] to love, have taken

Became a bull, and bellow'd; the green [SEQ_SPLITTER]Neptune

POLIX[SEQ_SPLITTER]ENES:

A fair one are you--well you fi[SEQ_SPLITTER]t our ages
With flowers of winter.
