Are our carnations and st[SEQ_SPLITTER]reak'd gillyvors,
Which some call nature's bastard[SEQ_SPLITTER]s: of that kind
Our rustic garden's barren; and I [SEQ_SPLITTER]care not
To get slips of them.

POLIXENES:
Wherefo[SEQ_SPLITTER]re, gentle maiden,

POLIXENES:
Say there be;
Yet nature is made bette[SEQ_SPLITTER]r by no mean
But nature makes that mean: so, over [SEQ_SPLITTER]that art
Which you say adds to nature, is an art
T[SEQ_SPLITTER]hat nature makes. You see, sweet maid, we marry
A [SEQ_SPLITTER]gentler scion to the wildest stock,
And make conce[SEQ_SPLITTER]ive a bark of baser kind
By bud of nobler race: th[SEQ_SPLITTER]is is an art
Which does mend nature, change it rat[SEQ_SPLITTER]her, but
The art itself is nature.

PERDITA:
So it[SEQ_SPLITTER] is.

POLIXENES:
Then make your garden rich in gil[SEQ_SPLITTER]lyvors,
And do not call them bastards.

PERDITA:
I[SEQ_SPLITTER]'ll not put
The dibble in earth to set one slip of[SEQ_SPLITTER] them;
No more than were I painted I would wish
Th[SEQ_SPLITTER]is youth should say 'twere well and only therefore[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Desire to breed by me. Here's flowers for you;
Ho[SEQ_SPLITTER]t lavender, mints, savoury, marjoram;
The marigold[SEQ_SPLITTER], that goes to bed wi' the sun
And with him rises [SEQ_SPLITTER]weeping: these are flowers
Of middle summer, and I[SEQ_SPLITTER] think they are given
To men of middle age. You're[SEQ_SPLITTER] very welcome.

CAMILLO:

PER[SEQ_SPLITTER]DITA:
Out, alas!
You'd be so lean, that blasts of [SEQ_SPLITTER]January
Would blow you through and through.
Now, m[SEQ_SPLITTER]y fair'st friend,
I would I had some flowers o' th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e spring that might
Become your time of day; and y[SEQ_SPLITTER]ours, and yours,
That wear upon your virgin branch[SEQ_SPLITTER]es yet
Your maidenheads growing: O Proserpina,
For[SEQ_SPLITTER] the flowers now, that frighted thou let'st fall
F[SEQ_SPLITTER]rom Dis's waggon! daffodils,
That come before the [SEQ_SPLITTER]swallow dares, and take

But sweeter than the lids of Ju[SEQ_SPLITTER]no's eyes
Or Cytherea's breath; pale primroses
Tha[SEQ_SPLITTER]t die unmarried, ere they can behold
Bight Phoebus[SEQ_SPLITTER] in his strength--a malady
Most incident to maids;[SEQ_SPLITTER] bold oxlips and

The flower-de-luce being one! O, these I l[SEQ_SPLITTER]ack,
To make you garlands of, and my sweet friend,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
To strew him o'er and o'er!

FLORIZEL:

Methinks I play as I have seen them do
[SEQ_SPLITTER]In Whitsun pastorals: sure this robe of mine

Stil[SEQ_SPLITTER]l betters what is done. When you speak, sweet.
I'l[SEQ_SPLITTER]d have you do it ever: when you sing,
I'ld have yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]u buy and sell so, so give alms,
Pray so; and, for[SEQ_SPLITTER] the ordering your affairs,
To sing them too: when[SEQ_SPLITTER] you do dance, I wish you
A wave o' the sea, that [SEQ_SPLITTER]you might ever do
Nothing but that; move still, st[SEQ_SPLITTER]ill so,
And own no other function: each your doing[SEQ_SPLITTER],
So singular in each particular,
Crowns what you [SEQ_SPLITTER]are doing in the present deed,
That all your acts [SEQ_SPLITTER]are queens.

Being now awake, I'll que[SEQ_SPLITTER]en it no inch farther,
But milk my ewes and weep.

Ay, sir.

Seco[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd Gentleman:

AUTOLYCUS:

DUKE VINCENTIO:

More[SEQ_SPLITTER] grave and wrinkled than the aims and ends
Of burn[SEQ_SPLITTER]ing youth.

How I have ever loved the life removed
[SEQ_SPLITTER]And held in idle price to haunt assemblies
Where y[SEQ_SPLITTER]outh, and cost, and witless bravery keeps.
I have [SEQ_SPLITTER]deliver'd to Lord Angelo,
A man of stricture and f[SEQ_SPLITTER]irm abstinence,
My absolute power and place here i[SEQ_SPLITTER]n Vienna,
And he supposes me travell'd to Poland;
[SEQ_SPLITTER]For so I have strew'd it in the common ear,
And so[SEQ_SPLITTER] it is received. Now, pious sir,
You will demand o[SEQ_SPLITTER]f me why I do this?

FRIAR THOMAS:
Gladly, my lord[SEQ_SPLITTER].

DUKE VINCENTIO:
We have strict statutes and mos[SEQ_SPLITTER]t biting laws.
The needful bits and curbs to heads[SEQ_SPLITTER]trong weeds,
Which for this nineteen years we have[SEQ_SPLITTER] let slip;
Even like an o'ergrown lion in a cave,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]That goes not out to prey. Now, as fond fathers,
H[SEQ_SPLITTER]aving bound up the threatening twigs of birch,
Onl[SEQ_SPLITTER]y to stick it in their children's sight
For terror[SEQ_SPLITTER], not to use, in time the rod
Becomes more mock'd [SEQ_SPLITTER]than fear'd; so our decrees,
Dead to infliction, t[SEQ_SPLITTER]o themselves are dead;
And liberty plucks justice [SEQ_SPLITTER]by the nose;
The baby beats the nurse, and quite a[SEQ_SPLITTER]thwart
Goes all decorum.

FRIAR THOMAS:
It rested [SEQ_SPLITTER]in your grace
To unloose this tied-up justice when[SEQ_SPLITTER] you pleased:
And it in you more dreadful would ha[SEQ_SPLITTER]ve seem'd

DUKE VINCENTIO:

Sith 'twas my fault to give[SEQ_SPLITTER] the people scope,
'Twould be my tyranny to strike[SEQ_SPLITTER] and gall them
For what I bid them do: for we bid [SEQ_SPLITTER]this be done,
When evil deeds have their permissiv[SEQ_SPLITTER]e pass
And not the punishment. Therefore indeed, m[SEQ_SPLITTER]y father,
I have on Angelo imposed the office;
Who[SEQ_SPLITTER] may, in the ambush of my name, strike home,
And y[SEQ_SPLITTER]et my nature never in the fight
To do in slander. [SEQ_SPLITTER]And to behold his sway,

Lik[SEQ_SPLITTER]e a true friar. More reasons for this action

Only, this one:[SEQ_SPLITTER] Lord Angelo is precise;
Stands at a guard with en[SEQ_SPLITTER]vy; scarce confesses
That his blood flows, or that[SEQ_SPLITTER] his appetite
Is more to bread than stone: hence s[SEQ_SPLITTER]hall we see,
If power change purpose, what our see[SEQ_SPLITTER]mers be.

Gu[SEQ_SPLITTER]iltier than him they try. What's open made to just[SEQ_SPLITTER]ice,
That justice seizes: what know the laws
That [SEQ_SPLITTER]thieves do pass on thieves? 'Tis very pregnant,
Th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e jewel that we find, we stoop and take't
Because [SEQ_SPLITTER]we see it; but what we do not see
We tread upon, a[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd never think of it.

For I have had such faults; but rather te[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll me,

And nothi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ng come in partial. Sir, he must die.

From thee, even from thy virtue!
What[SEQ_SPLITTER]'s this, what's this? Is this her fault or mine?
T[SEQ_SPLITTER]he tempter or the tempted, who sins most?
Ha!
Not [SEQ_SPLITTER]she: nor doth she tempt: but it is I
That, lying b[SEQ_SPLITTER]y the violet in the sun,
Do as the carrion does, n[SEQ_SPLITTER]ot as the flower,
Corrupt with virtuous season. Ca[SEQ_SPLITTER]n it be
That modesty may more betray our sense
Tha[SEQ_SPLITTER]n woman's lightness? Having waste ground enough,
S[SEQ_SPLITTER]hall we desire to raze the sanctuary
And pitch our[SEQ_SPLITTER] evils there? O, fie, fie, fie!
What dost thou, or[SEQ_SPLITTER] what art thou, Angelo?
Dost thou desire her foull[SEQ_SPLITTER]y for those things
That make her good? O, let her [SEQ_SPLITTER]brother live!
Thieves for their robbery have autho[SEQ_SPLITTER]rity
When judges steal themselves. What, do I love[SEQ_SPLITTER] her,
That I desire to hear her speak again,
And f[SEQ_SPLITTER]east upon her eyes? What is't I dream on?
O cunnin[SEQ_SPLITTER]g enemy, that, to catch a saint,
With saints dost [SEQ_SPLITTER]bait thy hook! Most dangerous
Is that temptation t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hat doth goad us on
To sin in loving virtue: never[SEQ_SPLITTER] could the strumpet,
With all her double vigour, a[SEQ_SPLITTER]rt and nature,
Once stir my temper; but this virtu[SEQ_SPLITTER]ous maid
Subdues me quite. Even till now,
When men[SEQ_SPLITTER] were fond, I smiled and wonder'd how.

P[SEQ_SPLITTER]rovost:
I am the provost. What's your will, good f[SEQ_SPLITTER]riar?

DUKE VINCENTIO:
Bound by my charity and my [SEQ_SPLITTER]blest order,
I come to visit the afflicted spirits[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Here in the prison. Do me the common right
To let[SEQ_SPLITTER] me see them and to make me know
The nature of the[SEQ_SPLITTER]ir crimes, that I may minister
To them accordingly[SEQ_SPLITTER].

Provost:

Who, falling in the flaws of her own youth,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Hath blister'd her report: she is with child;
And [SEQ_SPLITTER]he that got it, sentenced; a young man
More fit to[SEQ_SPLITTER] do another such offence
Than die for this.

And you shall be conducted.

I do; and bear the shame most patiently.

'Tis pity of him.

ANGELO:
When I would pray an[SEQ_SPLITTER]d think, I think and pray
To several subjects. Hea[SEQ_SPLITTER]ven hath my empty words;
Whilst my invention, hear[SEQ_SPLITTER]ing not my tongue,
Anchors on Isabel: Heaven in my[SEQ_SPLITTER] mouth,
As if I did but only chew his name;
And in[SEQ_SPLITTER] my heart the strong and swelling evil
Of my conce[SEQ_SPLITTER]ption. The state, whereon I studied
Is like a good[SEQ_SPLITTER] thing, being often read,
Grown fear'd and tedious[SEQ_SPLITTER]; yea, my gravity,
Wherein--let no man hear me--I [SEQ_SPLITTER]take pride,
Could I with boot change for an idle p[SEQ_SPLITTER]lume,
Which the air beats for vain. O place, O for[SEQ_SPLITTER]m,
How often dost thou with thy case, thy habit,
W[SEQ_SPLITTER]rench awe from fools and tie the wiser souls
To th[SEQ_SPLITTER]y false seeming! Blood, thou art blood:
Let's writ[SEQ_SPLITTER]e good angel on the devil's horn:
'Tis not the dev[SEQ_SPLITTER]il's crest.
How now! who's there?

Servant:
One Is[SEQ_SPLITTER]abel, a sister, desires access to you.

ANGELO:
Te[SEQ_SPLITTER]ach her the way.
O heavens!
Why does my blood thus[SEQ_SPLITTER] muster to my heart,
Making both it unable for its[SEQ_SPLITTER]elf,
And dispossessing all my other parts
Of neces[SEQ_SPLITTER]sary fitness?
So play the foolish throngs with one[SEQ_SPLITTER] that swoons;
Come all to help him, and so stop th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e air
By which he should revive: and even so
The g[SEQ_SPLITTER]eneral, subject to a well-wish'd king,

Must needs app[SEQ_SPLITTER]ear offence.

As [SEQ_SPLITTER]to put metal in restrained means
To make a false o[SEQ_SPLITTER]ne.

ISABELLA:

It is no sin at all, but[SEQ_SPLITTER] charity.

Were equal poise of sin and charity.

But graciously to[SEQ_SPLITTER] know I am no better.

If I do lose thee, I do lose [SEQ_SPLITTER]a thing
That none but fools would keep: a breath t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hou art,

That[SEQ_SPLITTER] dost this habitation, where thou keep'st,
Hourly [SEQ_SPLITTER]afflict: merely, thou art death's fool;
For him th[SEQ_SPLITTER]ou labour'st by thy flight to shun
And yet runn'st[SEQ_SPLITTER] toward him still. Thou art not noble;
For all the[SEQ_SPLITTER] accommodations that thou bear'st
Are nursed by ba[SEQ_SPLITTER]seness. Thou'rt by no means valiant;
For thou dost[SEQ_SPLITTER] fear the soft and tender fork
Of a poor worm. Thy[SEQ_SPLITTER] best of rest is sleep,
And that thou oft provokes[SEQ_SPLITTER]t; yet grossly fear'st
Thy death, which is no more[SEQ_SPLITTER]. Thou art not thyself;
For thou exist'st on many [SEQ_SPLITTER]a thousand grains
That issue out of dust. Happy th[SEQ_SPLITTER]ou art not;
For what thou hast not, still thou str[SEQ_SPLITTER]ivest to get,
And what thou hast, forget'st. Thou [SEQ_SPLITTER]art not certain;
For thy complexion shifts to stra[SEQ_SPLITTER]nge effects,
After the moon. If thou art rich, tho[SEQ_SPLITTER]u'rt poor;
For, like an ass whose back with ingots[SEQ_SPLITTER] bows,
Thou bear's thy heavy riches but a journey,[SEQ_SPLITTER]
And death unloads thee. Friend hast thou none;
Fo[SEQ_SPLITTER]r thine own bowels, which do call thee sire,
The m[SEQ_SPLITTER]ere effusion of thy proper loins,
Do curse the gou[SEQ_SPLITTER]t, serpigo, and the rheum,

But, as it were, [SEQ_SPLITTER]an after-dinner's sleep,
Dreaming on both; for all[SEQ_SPLITTER] thy blessed youth
Becomes as aged, and doth beg t[SEQ_SPLITTER]he alms

Thou hast neither heat, affection, limb, nor[SEQ_SPLITTER] beauty,
To make thy riches pleasant. What's yet i[SEQ_SPLITTER]n this
That bears the name of life? Yet in this li[SEQ_SPLITTER]fe

That makes these odds all even.

In corporal sufferance finds a pan[SEQ_SPLITTER]g as great

CLAUDIO:

That thus can make [SEQ_SPLITTER]him bite the law by the nose,
When he would force [SEQ_SPLITTER]it? Sure, it is no sin,
Or of the deadly seven, it[SEQ_SPLITTER] is the least.

ISABELLA:
Which is the least?

CLA[SEQ_SPLITTER]UDIO:
If it were damnable, he being so wise,
Why w[SEQ_SPLITTER]ould he for the momentary trick
Be perdurably fine[SEQ_SPLITTER]d? O Isabel!

ISABELLA:
What says my brother?

CLA[SEQ_SPLITTER]UDIO:
Death is a fearful thing.

ISABELLA:
And sha[SEQ_SPLITTER]med life a hateful.

CLAUDIO:
Ay, but to die, and [SEQ_SPLITTER]go we know not where;
To lie in cold obstruction a[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd to rot;
This sensible warm motion to become
A k[SEQ_SPLITTER]neaded clod; and the delighted spirit
To bathe in [SEQ_SPLITTER]fiery floods, or to reside
In thrilling region of [SEQ_SPLITTER]thick-ribbed ice;
To be imprison'd in the viewless[SEQ_SPLITTER] winds,
And blown with restless violence round abo[SEQ_SPLITTER]ut
The pendent world; or to be worse than worst
Of[SEQ_SPLITTER] those that lawless and incertain thought
Imagine [SEQ_SPLITTER]howling: 'tis too horrible!
The weariest and most [SEQ_SPLITTER]loathed worldly life
That age, ache, penury and im[SEQ_SPLITTER]prisonment
Can lay on nature is a paradise
To what[SEQ_SPLITTER] we fear of death.

ISABELLA:
Alas, alas!

CLAUDIO[SEQ_SPLITTER]:
Sweet sister, let me live:
What sin you do to sa[SEQ_SPLITTER]ve a brother's life,
Nature dispenses with the dee[SEQ_SPLITTER]d so far
That it becomes a virtue.

O yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]u beast!

W[SEQ_SPLITTER]ilt thou be made a man out of my vice?
Is't not a [SEQ_SPLITTER]kind of incest, to take life
From thine own sister[SEQ_SPLITTER]'s shame? What should I think?
Heaven shield my mo[SEQ_SPLITTER]ther play'd my father fair!
For such a warped slip[SEQ_SPLITTER] of wilderness
Ne'er issued from his blood. Take m[SEQ_SPLITTER]y defiance!
Die, perish! Might but my bending down[SEQ_SPLITTER]
Reprieve thee from thy fate, it should proceed:
I[SEQ_SPLITTER]'ll pray a thousand prayers for thy death,
No word[SEQ_SPLITTER] to save thee.

CLAUDIO:

the tyrant.

Provost:
A bawd[SEQ_SPLITTER] of eleven years' continuance, may it please
your [SEQ_SPLITTER]honour.

My lord, this is one L[SEQ_SPLITTER]ucio's information against me.

ESC[SEQ_SPLITTER]ALUS:

G[SEQ_SPLITTER]ood even, good father.

DUK[SEQ_SPLITTER]E VINCENTIO:

To use it for my time: I am a brother
Of g[SEQ_SPLITTER]racious order, late come from the See
In special b[SEQ_SPLITTER]usiness from his holiness.

ESCALUS:
What news abr[SEQ_SPLITTER]oad i' the world?

DUKE VINCENTIO:
None, but that [SEQ_SPLITTER]there is so great a fever on

novelty is only in r[SEQ_SPLITTER]equest; and it is as dangerous

ESCALUS:
One th[SEQ_SPLITTER]at, above all other strifes, contended
especially [SEQ_SPLITTER]to know himself.

DUKE VINCENTIO:

ESCALUS:

DUKE VINCENTIO:
Peace be w[SEQ_SPLITTER]ith you!
He who the sword of heaven will bear
Shou[SEQ_SPLITTER]ld be as holy as severe;
Pattern in himself to kno[SEQ_SPLITTER]w,
Grace to stand, and virtue go;
More nor less to[SEQ_SPLITTER] others paying
Than by self-offences weighing.
Sha[SEQ_SPLITTER]me to him whose cruel striking
Kills for faults of[SEQ_SPLITTER] his own liking!
Twice treble shame on Angelo,
To [SEQ_SPLITTER]weed my vice and let his grow!
O, what may man wit[SEQ_SPLITTER]hin him hide,
Though angel on the outward side!
Ho[SEQ_SPLITTER]w may likeness made in crimes,
Making practise on [SEQ_SPLITTER]the times,
To draw with idle spiders' strings
Most[SEQ_SPLITTER] ponderous and substantial things!
Craft against v[SEQ_SPLITTER]ice I must apply:
With Angelo to-night shall lie
H[SEQ_SPLITTER]is old betrothed but despised;
So disguise shall, [SEQ_SPLITTER]by the disguised,
Pay with falsehood false exactin[SEQ_SPLITTER]g,
And perform an old contracting.


MARIANA:
Brea[SEQ_SPLITTER]k off thy song, and haste thee quick away:
Here co[SEQ_SPLITTER]mes a man of comfort, whose advice
Hath often stil[SEQ_SPLITTER]l'd my brawling discontent.
I cry you mercy, sir; [SEQ_SPLITTER]and well could wish
You had not found me here so m[SEQ_SPLITTER]usical:
Let me excuse me, and believe me so,
My mi[SEQ_SPLITTER]rth it much displeased, but pleased my woe.

Wh[SEQ_SPLITTER]at is the news from this good deputy?

ISABELLA:
H[SEQ_SPLITTER]e hath a garden circummured with brick,
Whose west[SEQ_SPLITTER]ern side is with a vineyard back'd;
And to that vi[SEQ_SPLITTER]neyard is a planched gate,
That makes his opening [SEQ_SPLITTER]with this bigger key:
This other doth command a li[SEQ_SPLITTER]ttle door
Which from the vineyard to the garden le[SEQ_SPLITTER]ads;
There have I made my promise
Upon the heavy m[SEQ_SPLITTER]iddle of the night
To call upon him.

With whispering and most guilty diligence,
In a[SEQ_SPLITTER]ction all of precept, he did show me
The way twice[SEQ_SPLITTER] o'er.

Provost:

POMPEY:

cut off a wo[SEQ_SPLITTER]man's head.

Provost:

fe[SEQ_SPLITTER]llow partner.

Every true man's apparel fits your thi[SEQ_SPLITTER]ef: if it be

POMPEY:

Forthlight the tilter, and bra[SEQ_SPLITTER]ve Master Shooty the
great traveller, and wild Hal[SEQ_SPLITTER]f-can that stabbed
Pots, and, I think, forty more;[SEQ_SPLITTER] all great doers in
our trade, and are now 'for th[SEQ_SPLITTER]e Lord's sake.'

A ghostly father, beli[SEQ_SPLITTER]ke. Who knows that Lodowick?

I do not like the m[SEQ_SPLITTER]an: had he been lay, my lord
For certain words he [SEQ_SPLITTER]spake against your grace
In your retirement, I had[SEQ_SPLITTER] swinged him soundly.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
Words again[SEQ_SPLITTER]st me? this is a good friar, belike!
And to set on[SEQ_SPLITTER] this wretched woman here

Who is as free from touch or soil w[SEQ_SPLITTER]ith her

LU[SEQ_SPLITTER]CENTIO:
Tranio, since for the great desire I had
T[SEQ_SPLITTER]o see fair Padua, nursery of arts,
I am arrived fo[SEQ_SPLITTER]r fruitful Lombardy,
The pleasant garden of great [SEQ_SPLITTER]Italy;
And by my father's love and leave am arm'd
[SEQ_SPLITTER]With his good will and thy good company,
My trusty[SEQ_SPLITTER] servant, well approved in all,
Here let us breath[SEQ_SPLITTER]e and haply institute
A course of learning and ing[SEQ_SPLITTER]enious studies.
Pisa renown'd for grave citizens
G[SEQ_SPLITTER]ave me my being and my father first,
A merchant of[SEQ_SPLITTER] great traffic through the world,
Vincetino come o[SEQ_SPLITTER]f Bentivolii.
Vincetino's son brought up in Floren[SEQ_SPLITTER]ce
It shall become to serve all hopes conceived,
T[SEQ_SPLITTER]o deck his fortune with his virtuous deeds:
And th[SEQ_SPLITTER]erefore, Tranio, for the time I study,
Virtue and [SEQ_SPLITTER]that part of philosophy
Will I apply that treats o[SEQ_SPLITTER]f happiness
By virtue specially to be achieved.
Te[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll me thy mind; for I have Pisa left
And am to Pad[SEQ_SPLITTER]ua come, as he that leaves
A shallow plash to plun[SEQ_SPLITTER]ge him in the deep
And with satiety seeks to quenc[SEQ_SPLITTER]h his thirst.

TRANIO:
Mi perdonato, gentle master[SEQ_SPLITTER] mine,
I am in all affected as yourself;
Glad that[SEQ_SPLITTER] you thus continue your resolve
To suck the sweets[SEQ_SPLITTER] of sweet philosophy.
Only, good master, while we [SEQ_SPLITTER]do admire
This virtue and this moral discipline,
L[SEQ_SPLITTER]et's be no stoics nor no stocks, I pray;
Or so dev[SEQ_SPLITTER]ote to Aristotle's cheques
As Ovid be an outcast q[SEQ_SPLITTER]uite abjured:
Balk logic with acquaintance that yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]u have
And practise rhetoric in your common talk;
[SEQ_SPLITTER]Music and poesy use to quicken you;
The mathematic[SEQ_SPLITTER]s and the metaphysics,
Fall to them as you find yo[SEQ_SPLITTER]ur stomach serves you;
No profit grows where is no[SEQ_SPLITTER] pleasure ta'en:
In brief, sir, study what you mos[SEQ_SPLITTER]t affect.

And other books, good ones, I w[SEQ_SPLITTER]arrant ye.

For thou are pleasant, gamesome, passing courte[SEQ_SPLITTER]ous,
But slow in speech, yet sweet as spring-time [SEQ_SPLITTER]flowers:
Thou canst not frown, thou canst not look[SEQ_SPLITTER] askance,
Nor bite the lip, as angry wenches will,[SEQ_SPLITTER]

But t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hou with mildness entertain'st thy wooers,

Is straight and slender[SEQ_SPLITTER] and as brown in hue

First were we sad, fearing y[SEQ_SPLITTER]ou would not come;
Now sadder, that you come so un[SEQ_SPLITTER]provided.
Fie, doff this habit, shame to your esta[SEQ_SPLITTER]te,
An eye-sore to our solemn festival!

TRANIO:
A[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd tells us, what occasion of import
Hath all so l[SEQ_SPLITTER]ong detain'd you from your wife,
And sent you hith[SEQ_SPLITTER]er so unlike yourself?

PETRUCHIO:

Sufficeth I am come t[SEQ_SPLITTER]o keep my word,
Though in some part enforced to di[SEQ_SPLITTER]gress;
Which, at more leisure, I will so excuse
As[SEQ_SPLITTER] you shall well be satisfied withal.
But where is [SEQ_SPLITTER]Kate? I stay too long from her:
The morning wears,[SEQ_SPLITTER] 'tis time we were at church.

TRANIO:

T[SEQ_SPLITTER]o me she's married, not unto my clothes:
Could I r[SEQ_SPLITTER]epair what she will wear in me,

'Twere well for Kate and b[SEQ_SPLITTER]etter for myself.

When I should bid good morrow to my bride,
[SEQ_SPLITTER]And seal the title with a lovely kiss!

[SEQ_SPLITTER]Of greater sums than I have promised.
So shall you[SEQ_SPLITTER] quietly enjoy your hope,

I'[SEQ_SPLITTER]ll keep mine own, despite of all the world.

TRANI[SEQ_SPLITTER]O:

But[SEQ_SPLITTER] after many ceremonies done,

PETRUCHIO:
Thus have I [SEQ_SPLITTER]politicly begun my reign,
And 'tis my hope to end [SEQ_SPLITTER]successfully.
My falcon now is sharp and passing e[SEQ_SPLITTER]mpty;
And till she stoop she must not be full-gorg[SEQ_SPLITTER]ed,
For then she never looks upon her lure.
Anothe[SEQ_SPLITTER]r way I have to man my haggard,
To make her come a[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd know her keeper's call,
That is, to watch her, [SEQ_SPLITTER]as we watch these kites
That bate and beat and wil[SEQ_SPLITTER]l not be obedient.
She eat no meat to-day, nor non[SEQ_SPLITTER]e shall eat;
Last night she slept not, nor to-nigh[SEQ_SPLITTER]t she shall not;
As with the meat, some undeserved[SEQ_SPLITTER] fault
I'll find about the making of the bed;
And [SEQ_SPLITTER]here I'll fling the pillow, there the bolster,
Thi[SEQ_SPLITTER]s way the coverlet, another way the sheets:
Ay, an[SEQ_SPLITTER]d amid this hurly I intend
That all is done in rev[SEQ_SPLITTER]erend care of her;
And in conclusion she shall wat[SEQ_SPLITTER]ch all night:
And if she chance to nod I'll rail a[SEQ_SPLITTER]nd brawl
And with the clamour keep her still awake[SEQ_SPLITTER].
This is a way to kill a wife with kindness;
And [SEQ_SPLITTER]thus I'll curb her mad and headstrong humour.
He t[SEQ_SPLITTER]hat knows better how to tame a shrew,
Now let him [SEQ_SPLITTER]speak: 'tis charity to show.

TRANIO:

[SEQ_SPLITTER]Fie on her! see, how beastly she doth court him!
